Bottle from Systembolaget. Powerfull smell with chili, vanilla, coffee, chocolate. Similar taste, warming finish. Very complex and powerfull beer.

Pours dark with low light brown head
Aromas of coffee, dades, vanilla, raisins, dark chocolate
Nice sweet malty taste of coffe, vanilla, liqourize, bitter dark chocolate

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Svart öl med ett ganska litet, mörk brunt skum som försvinner efter någon minut. Doft: Kaffe dajm (karamelliserat socker, rostade nötter, mjölkchokladb, körsbärs pralin, vanilj, lite alkohol och kanske lite apelsin. Smak: Kaffe, mjölkchoklad, nötter, vanilj, gräddkola, bigarråer, sött brynt smör.

On tap at the grad in Davis. Pours a black color with a decent sized tan head. Nice full flavored beer. Can definitely taste the vanilla. Solid brew.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle thanks to timfoolery: Poured a deep black with a finger frothy tan to light brown head. Aroma is strong coffee and light vanilla. Taste is strong coffee bean with roasted malts and light vanilla.
Aroma of vanilla, coffee, caramel, chocolate. Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, juniper berries and bitter coffee. Smooth, low sweetness, bitter.

Bottle.
Pours black with a small espresso coloured head consisting of tiny bubbles with some large here and there. Really nice!
Aroma has luxurious coffee and chocolate as well as loads of vanilla on the end. Faint raisin as well.
Taste has vanilla, marshmallows, coffee, cream, roasted malt, dark chocolate, salt liquorice, slight alcohol and that typical porter tartness.
Full body with quite high carbonation, round and smooth mouth feel.
After taste is roasted, grapefruit bitter and lingers on for long.
Fantastic Imperial Porter! If only the after taste had been a bit more balanced with the other sensations itd be even better.

Big Bottle from SB cons 2013-09-21 Göteborg
AR: vanilla powder, coffee, dark chocolate
AP: dark brown allmosor black colored body, high lively stouthy dark brown head
F: warming feeling, soft wee bubbles, milk vanilla chocolate, salt licorice, peppery, tar, tobaco, full bodied, over average bitternees, oily grispy textur, starting of totally asome but finishes to ruff - storage or why not my hands on one of the barrell aged variants;)
650ml Bottle - Black with a tan head. Vanilla, cocoa and coffee in the aroma. Chocolatey and roasted taste with notes of vanilla and coffee standing out. Rich and indulgent, yet easy to drink.

Bomber. Pours a deep black with a small light brown head. The head dissapates quickly but leaves moderate lacing in my snifter. Wonderful aroma of vanilla,coffee,chocolate and hints of wood. Velvety mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Sweet and bitter. Awesome beer.

Pours a pure jet black with a thin tan head. Aroma consists of strong vanilla dominant, quite a bit of smokiness, with coffee and mocha complimenting nicely. The taste is much more potent than the aroma. Huge coffee and vanilla flavors, with a mocha undertone that is mixed with very noticeable alcohol notes. Its a little sweet. Aftertaste is long, with hints of coffee but mostly alcohol. Medium to thick in body, an oily texture, with minimal carbonation. The potency of this one isnt subtle. It makes itself very apparent as soon as you begin drinking. This is an impressive effort from a brewery that is rather new to my area and has impressed me so far. The artwork on the bottle is awesome as well.

Jet black colour,beige head. Aroma of coffee, light vanilla, roasted malts,lots of coffee. Sweet flavour, vanilla, chocolate. Quite full body, sweet finish, roasted malts.
(from 66cL bottle @RBBSG II, Gent 2013. Thanks for sharing Tim - and for hosting!)

Borders on stunning, and hard to say why it's not considered a stout albeit for a chewiness that while thick is a bit less than imperial stouts. Beautiful stout -- errr, porter -- malt base. Truth in advertising: the vanilla while not overwhelming is ever present, whereas the coffee flits in and out throughout. Quite roasty, some bitterness, and no sweetness. Recommended, highly! A-

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2016 Bottle shared at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Black witha huge frothy light brown head. Powerful aroma full of coffee beans, cocoa and vanilla. Sweet flavor of mocha, coffee, vanilla, some roastiness and a drier finish, a bit bitter, slightly burnt. Thick full body. Great stuff.

Pours black, basically, with low tan head. Aroma of coffee, smoke, vanilla, chocolate malts, light german sausage. Taste is cream, vanilla balanced against heavy coffee and chocolate bitternesd, with lingering bitter finish. Body is a tad light but creamy and smooth with soft carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Quelle bière, javais entendu des bons et moins bon commentaires. La touche de vanille est si bien balancé par laamertume de café. Avoir su jen aurais acheté plus quune. Cest lune des meilleure "non-barrel aged" stout/porter que jai bu. Fortement recommandé.

Dark, dark brown almoust black with just a little beige head.
Not much lacing on the glass.
Nose: Vanilla, milk chocolate, cream, yoghurt, chili, fudge, coffee and sweet licoriche.
Taste: Coffee, roasted malt, dark chocolate, licoriche, soy sauce, wood, brown sugar, raisin and just a little bit of booze.
A full body with almoust no carbonation and so complex taste!
! just LOVE this!

Bottle, thanks to b3shine. Hearty super-dark pour with a tight brown crown. Robust malty character, lots of chocolate, some sweet soy sauce, vanilla. But the star of the show is the earthy coffee, really rounded coffee flavour, integrated perfectly with the other elements. Licorice in the finish. Delicious!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
Extremely dark black pour with thick tan head.
Aroma is strong chocolate malt, vanilla and mocha like coffee. 
Flavour is more coffee and chocolate. Nutty bitterness, lighter vanilla than aroma suggested.
Delicious and very drinkable considering alc%

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very chocolatey with notes of vanilla, biscuit, and hops. Smooth with a bit of a boozy finish. 10% is very well hidden though.

Bomber. Best before 1/2/14. Aroma consists of coffee and vanilla as described, as well as what smells like chilies; its also roasty, bready. Pours near black with a two finger tan head with good retention; leaves some lace. Taste is sweet and roasty before turning lightly tart; finishes with a lingering bitterness. Coffee, chocolate, licorice, vanilla in flavor. Mouthfeel is creamy, carbonation fine, near full body. Nice.

Pours a pitch black colour with a rocky mocha head. Aroma is of chocolate and coffee with a slight vanilla undertone. Taste is sweet with a dry bitterness throughout; nice and balanced taste. Full body, creamy thick mouth feel, and soft carbonation. A really nice beer overall.

@basunen: trevlig doft med tydlig kaffe. Vaniljen ger en lite mjölig karaktär. Smaken är mycket trevlig med mycket kaffe och söt vanilj. Eftersmaken något besk och kanske en liten aning artificiell. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 oz. bottle. Pours brown black with a tight foamy tan head that slowly settles to a thin foamy film and coating lacing. Aroma is sweet a little bitter with roasted malt coffee vanilla and marsh mellows and some nuttiness. Taste is bitter with sweet vanilla coffee and milk chocolate and some burnt roasted malt subtle cherry wood. Palate is full sticky and coating with a warming dry finish. Very nice!

Black pour, tan head, good lace/retention. Aroma is really good - chocolate, roast, vanilla, coffee, light caramel. Yes, its heavy on the vanilla but theres so much more happening that its really nice. Medium to full body, moderate to light sweetness, light alcohol, delicious. Amazing imperial porter.

Pint bottle, I reckon its a few months old. Pours thickish with a foamy tan head. Head endures. Bit of lacing. Looks good. Smell - roasted coffee is prominent, smoke and yeast in the background, maybe some floral hops. Body is medium, slightly foamy, low carbonation. Was expecting a bigger body. Taste is liquorice, coffee, background chocolate. Despite the obvious addition of coffee, its not that prominent. It shows up in the smell but in the taste its more like coffee flavoured sweets. Im getting more liquorice than coffee.  Toast in the aftertaste.  The alcohol is noticeable and brings a little sharpness, but its not bad. Decent beer overall.

10/VIII/13 - 1Pt. 6Fl. Oz. bottle @ RBBSG II, my place - BB: n/a (2013-754) Thanks to Nate for the bottle and to Paul for transport!
Clear dark brown beer, small irregular beige head, unstable. Aroma: mocha, caramel, coffee, sweet malts, brown sugar and yoghurt, pretty sweet. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: lots of vanilla, sugary, caramel, some mocha, bit sweet, little bitter. Aftertaste: vanilla, caramel, bitter hoppy touch, bit sugary, some toast.

640ml bottle, pours deep black with a small creamy tan head. Aroma of dark cocoa, roasted coffee and vanilla. Taste of dark cocoa, dark roasted coffee, a hint of vanilla and muscovado. Somewhat bitter with a slight sweetness. Full bodied, creamy texture and almost flat carbonation. I would have liked the vanilla to stand out more in the taste, but still one of the best imperial porters I have had.

Black with half finger tan head. Aroma is medium coffee, strong vanilla, and muted alcohol. Flavor is very strong with coffee, big vanilla in the finish. Coffee beer isnt my thing, but this isnt too bad.

split with wife pours moonless midnight sky black with a tan head that leaves behind an oil slick mass of lacing. nose of black coffee, dark chocolate. light vanilla bean is added in taste. body is big and burly, but leaves with a creamy finish.

2013 bomber to a tulip glass. Pours virtually black with a foamy off-white head. Aroma is coffee and mocha and vanilla. Taste is dark roasted coffee, milk chocolate, vanilla, some nuttiness and a bold grassy hop bitterness at the end. Some alcohol present as well. Full, luscious mouthfeel that has a bit of a dry quality due to the bitterness.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from big bottle. Number 900!!! Coffee, nut, malt and vanilla in aroma. Definitely porter - solid black, thin tan head. Coffee flavor definitely there, but not overpowering. Also flavors of nut, licorice, dry cocoa, vanilla, brownie edges, grassy hops. A bit of alcohol in the back. Very earthy aftertaste. Im not a coffee lover, but have to admire this one. Well done.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Bottle. I enjoyed the this spl beer at pub with pretty lady. It has glorious black body like sexy lady. I have several of this drink but like anyway. Chocolate and vanilla smell like nice spl lady.

Pours an opaque brown color with a finger of tan head with good lacing. Aroma of vanilla and mocha with some coffee. Taste is vanilla and mocha with a dark rich coffee flavor and moderate bitterness. Mouthfeel is creamy and full bodied with medium carbonation. Very good mocha flavor. Really liked.

Dark almost black, a little bit of off white head. Smells of tobacco, coffee grounds, cocoa, mocha, vanilla. Big mocha taste, black coffee, vanilla in the distance. Some hop bitter at the end and a little spice. Good big porter. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap. Strong flavors in this one. A mild sweetness gives way to huge roasted flavors and a strong bitter aftertaste that sticks with you. The roasting was too heavy for my tastes (seemed burned) and the bitter finish was disagreeable to my palate. Ill stick with imperial stouts.

Bomber from QFC University Village. 

Seems strange to be in Santa Barbara yesterday and then buy Ballast Point today, but what a delight that they are now available in Seattle. A vigorous pour into my duvel tulip yields an inky black topped with a vigorous brown head. Nose of vanilla and cocoa, light touch of ash and chocolate cake, the vinous notes of a porter rather than a stout. Intense, intense flavors: black coffee and vanilla, mocha midrange, the vinousness from the aroma, bitter coffee and very very late a mint tic-tac close. A hint of soy sauce as it warms to room temperature. Alcohol is well hidden -- Id have guessed 8% rather than 10%, full but not thick in body, a bit of warmth late. Extremely nice beer and an interesting switch-up from the imperial stouts I drink more commonly. This could even go 4.2 with a 17 overall.

Im on the 4-5 borderline for appearance - very good label (a bit too cluttered), great graphic, great cap and company logo, standard 22-oz US bomber. 10w-40 (after 20k miles) pour, big tan head. Initially the aroma is green olives and plums - after breathing, it turns sweet theres a nice roast and an almost hazelnut tone - cafe au lait, bittersweet choco - mmm. Up front, the bittersweet chocolate hits you like a bag full of nickels, followed by a modest sweetness, and trailing off with a coffee/roast bitterness. Nicely played. Slightly heavy medium body. Warming, roast and dark choco finish, with a little pepper. The only slight quibble I had was the leading edge of the aroma, but this is an exceptional beer with no major flaws. New Leaf Market - cheaper than anyplace else in town.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2015 Black pour, small tan head. Aroma is rich, roasted coffee, vanilla and some malts. Taste is strong and the roastiness especially dominates it. Rounds out toward some bitterness in the end. The coffee taste lingers for quite a while Mouthfeel is rich and silky smooth. Its still an awesome beer if you enjoy the style.

Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with a half inch of very fine, dense tan/brown foam. Aroma is of roasted malts and coffee, maybe a hint of vanilla. Taste is very roasty and sweet -- coffee, dark chocolate, vanilla, caramel. Mouthfeel is rather thick and creamy. Best porter I have ever had.

Lovely but not overpowering vanilla with not as much coffee as expected on the nose. Viscous dark brown pour with thick tan head, fades slowish. Soft sweet caramel and chocolate taste followed by powerful hop and coffee bitterness. Good complexity. Constant but light vanilla presence. Thick palate but you can tell its a porter not a stout. Cracking beer, defied my expectations of it being super sweet.

22oz bottle pours black with an extremely dense, lasting, creamy tan head. Seriously it is a mat I could float a quarter on. Big roasty aroma with a lot of coffee. Lots of bitter dark roast and coffee again. Attenuated and sharp. Lingering bitter chocolate and ash. Good, but not quite to the hype.

This is awesome! All the aggressiveness that I was expecting with lots of coffee and a smooth finish. Still, the thin body on porters is sometime a down side for my personal taste. But in hot weather, I certainly see the appeal. Overall, you should seriously buy this and try it!

650 mL bottle. Looks like a porter. Not much head. Like Dieu du Ciel, only a porter. And this clearly is an IP, not an IS. Mouthfeel and all. Milder aroma. Mild vanilla. Roast. No booze. Bit of soy sauce. Perfect level of carbonation. Toasty bitterness in the finish. Good stuff.

Sampled from bottle @ RBBSG II. Opaque pitch black color, small to medium sized light brown head. Smell and taste malts, lightly hops, roasty, bitter, some chocolate. Very bitter and bitter chocolate in the finish. Full body and medium to full carbonation. Great beer!

Delicious with its loads of rich dark roasted malts, crushed up roasted dark coffee beans, subtle hints of vanilla, and bitter dark chocolate influences. Im not sure I could ask for much more out of an American Porter than this one offers. At 10%, this one could hammer you quickly but I cant detect a single tinge of booze out of this one. Its masterfully crafted....The thick creaminess of this one makes it a real pleasure to enjoy as well. Its thick and rich but not in a cloying way at all. World class in my opinionEarlier Rating: 1/12/2013 Total Score: 4.6Pours a dark black with light tan head. The smell is outstanding. Lots of bitter coffee and vanilla extract and some dark chocolate. Taste is out of this world delicious. Starts with big sweet vanilla and sweetened iced coffee and finishes with bitter unsweetened coffee and vanilla extract alcohol. This is one balanced beer. Bold flavors but everything gets a fair shake. Mouthfeel is slightly thin when compared to similar beers. This gives founders breakfast stout a run for its money.

opaque black with a short-lived tan head. full body but not creamy or silky. medium carbonation.

aroma: kahlua, astringent acidic roast malt, cola.

taste: kahlua, vanilla, harsh woody coffee, leafy hop bitterness, and sour minerality.

very one-note. lacks depth and complexity and subtlety.

Courtesy of tderoeck. Thx! 65 cl. bottle sampled @ RBBSG II. Great label. Blackish appearance, mocha head. Nose is heavy roast, very rich on chocolate, sweet mocha, coffee, light espresso, light vanilla, Taste is bitter & sweet roast, lots of sweet chocolate, so much chocolate, thick vanilla with sweet coffee, chunk of mocha, brownie, caramel, brown sugar, cappuccino, Thick and creamy. Utterly delicious, easily the best Porter I have ever head, ace beer.
Porters dont get much better than this. Bourbon, vanilla, a bit of smoke. Great stuff. (Had it on hand pump)
22 ounce bomber. Dark dark brown pour, small head. Vanilla, coffee, alcohol presence. Damn, this is good.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2013 Delicious way to lead into the home stretch of an epic tasting session. I regret missing its brief appearance on tap at a local craft beer bar a few months back but doubt it could be too much better than the bottled version I just enjoyed.

If you can still call this a porter, its the best porter ive ever had. Wow, really nice flavors going on here. Vanilla and espresso are dominant, but there are strong elements of cinnamon, cocoa powder, nutmeg, and orange chocolate. Coats the throat but never too heavy. Totally worth seeking out, Only negative is the vanilla is so strong it turns ever so slightly bitter/sour...
2010 vintage. This didnt age very well. Pours black with thin tan head. Flavor of roast with a flavor that I cant place. I can definitely tell its old.

22oz bomber thanks to Cleg via local for local swap chapter 4. Pours a jet black color with a creamy thin dark tan head. Aroma of roasted coffee, caramel, and a hint of vanilla. Taste is rich espresso, chocolate, roasted malt, and again a hint of vanilla in the aftertaste.
Black pour from bottle. Chocolate malty piece of heaven. As good as a porter gets.

brown, nearly black, medium brown head with moderate retention and a lot of lacing. coffee, vanilla, chocolate, roast, caramel, alcohol. medium sweet, medium-heavy bitter. full body, thick and creamy feel, soft carb, warm. dessert-y without being cloyingly sweet
Aroma is full of coffee and vanilla. Obviously the taste is coffee and vanilla with a hint of chocolate. Has a slightly bitter finish. Very tasty, can taste a little alcohol, not much though.
Pours black color with a thin tan head. Aroma is mostly coffee with a little malt. Taste is mostly coffee with just a hint of vanilla. Nice bitterness at the finish. Very nice taste.

Bottle, dark red black pour with tan foam. Aroma of straight vanilla beans, light coffee notes, moka, latte, smells like starbucks. Taste is sweet, vanilla, desserty, powdery cocoa, light coffee finish. Palate is thick, chewy with a balanced finish (not too sweet). The focus seems to be on vanilla more than coffee. Quite enjoyable.

Pours black with only slight glints of sepia when backlit. Based on color, it could be a stout. Thick light-brown head which fades to a few millimeters. Aroma is vanilla salt-water taffy, cold-press coffee and fake-chocolate. Fresh tree after rain. Body is heavy, somewhat syrupy. Flavor is massive vanilla, melted chocolate, light soy, more vanilla, hot hops on a lake shore with mud baking in a summer sun. Good, but too much vanilla.

Bomber - Pours jet black with a cola head. Nice coffee aroma and quite possibly the deepest, darkest coffee taste Ive ever had in a porter. I didnt really detect the vanilla but it did have a malty sweet finish.
Aroma is coffee appearance is dark with little kahki head, taste us strong coffee flavors lingers on palate, great coffee beer

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2015 Impressive. Pours a deep black-brown cola... beauty. The head is substantial. The aroma is wonderful, enjoyable, I cant get enough.... MALT! Caramel, bread, chocolate, cereal, coffee, nuts, toast, and roasty. The hops give an aroma of resin more than pine... YEASTY! Dough, leather, earthy, leaves, basement aromas... WOW! Alcohol, licorice, raisin, vanilla, The taste is sublime but hard o pin down. Sour and bitter overpower a light sweetness. Theres salt.... Full bodied thick beer with soft carb and a loooong bitter finish. Best beer Ive ever bought at a grocery store... Quite a superior offering. Thank you Ballast Point.
Tap, pizza port San Clemente. Dark black, light head. Strong flavor of coffee, vanilla, malt. Powerful, flavorful beer.
Bottle from 16 Tons Taphouse, Eugene. Pours incredibly dark, slight tan head. Aroma roasty, coffee, chocolate, very rich. Body roasty and thick, finish retains a slight bitterness, really lovely!

From a growler into a wide bottomed tulip. 

A: Very nice coffee and chocoalte notes. Very smooth. Not bitter. 
A: Looks nice. Dark black. Dark brown head dissipates quickly.
T: Tastes pretty solid. Again, nice coffee and chocolate notes (more on the coffee side). A little acidic in the finish. Not really getting the vanilla undertone... perhaps its overpowered by the other strong notes/
P: A little acidic and boozy on the finish. Fully bodied. Carbonation is good.

overall this is a really nice beer. Great flavor notes. A bit of earthiness adds to it. The finish is a tad too acidic with a lingering bitterness. Better finish that some, worse than others.

Dark brown pour. Big tan head that quickly falls leaving a wake of paint behind. Aroma of coffee, molasses and chocolate. Taste is a big vanilla up front. Follow that up with some coffee and yum. Very rich velvety mouth. Nice beer.

Was pleased to find this top beer in Apalachicola, Florida. Great change of pace after pounding Jai Alai all vacation. Pours black like oil with light brown head. Coffee and dark chocolate dominate the nose. Flavor is hugely sweet but nicely balanced by a bitter back end. Oily mouthfeel. Bottle - Honey Hole Liquors -Apalachicola, FL

22oz bottle, split. Thrilled that Ballast Point is delivering beers to Oregon

A: Lightless mahogany with a rim of cappuccino head. Not much in the way of legs, surprisingly, but Ill manage.

N: The vanilla strikes first, but its soft and almost supple. coffee and dark chocolate firm up the base, and theres a hint of molasses and similar flavors to oak. I get a whiff of charcoal, too. 

T: Very bitter like fresh-pressed espresso mixed with some smoked wood. Malty sweetness and vanilla do a good job of rounding this out so that its not one-dimensional. Hop greenness also rears its head. Hits multiple parts of the tongue. 

M: Oily with a medium-heavy mouthfeel. Alcohol is well-hidden. 

O: A really well-built Imperial Porter that never allows any one of its elements to overwhelm the others. Ill be buying this one on a regular basis.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2013 Black with mocha head. Aroma is vanilla chocolate and coffee. Maybe a touch of heaven. Taste is rich roast chocolate and coffee. This is what baby seal tastes like to a polar bear.
Thick, thick, thick. Nice coffee and vanilla bean very visible in the palate. Nice light aroma.

Pours black with thick dark tan head. Coffee, roasted malts, chocolate and vanilla aromas. Chocolate, coffee, vanilla and roasted malt flavors. Some alcohol taste present. Sweet chocolate finish and full body. Very good.

Really excellent beer. Not at its best when it is too cold (but thats usually true), there is just such excellence in the balance of the coffee within the porter--not overdone, with vanilla and caramel appearing, too. Rich palate. On tap at the Publican, Chicago.

Poured from a 22 oz. bottle into a tulip. 

Coffee Vanilla Imperial Porter comes out of the bottle looking dark and brooding. The beer itself pours a dark obsidian color. The head starts as a dark tan foam, bubbling up through the beer and rising up the glass. The foam eventually rises a few inches to reach the top of the glass. A slow recession leaves plenty of lace sticking to the glass.

The aroma provides a blast of roasted malt notes and deep, full coffee. There is a little bit of bitter dark chocolate in the back, but the aroma is mainly a blast of roasted malt and bitter coffee.

My first impression is that this beer is big, bold, and makes no apologies for being so. Dark roasted malt has hints of smoke and dark chocolate. A jolt of vanilla breaks up the bitter transition from fully roasted malt to intense coffee. The coffee starts strong, with the bitterness coming after. With each sip the cumulative bitterness grows, reminding me of just how intense of a beer this is.

Perhaps it is some kind of magic trick, but this beer does not drink like it has 10% alcohol. There is almost no alcohol present in the taste; it is only noticeable in a slight tingle on my tongue and gums. There is a great creamy nature to the carbonation, more so that the beer. If anything, the flaw with this beer is how light the body feels compared to the robustness of the flavor and carbonation. There is a little bit of bitter and sweet sticky residue left on my lips.

This is truly a great beer and may be the best porter I have had so far. The combination of flavors and level of intensity really do it for me.

Draft. Pours opaque black with a beige head. Aroma is rich roasted malts, dark chocolate, light citrus, and some caramel. Tastes like roasted malts, licorice, dark chocolate, cherries, wood, caramel, coffee and vanilla. Smooth, thick feel. Full body and low carbonation. Roasty, vanilla, grassy finish with mellow sweetness.

Bottle, finally available in Seattle market. Pours nearly black with full, dense tan head. No lacing. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and I'm feeling generous so vanilla is (barely) present. Taste is big on the coffee - ample bitterness reminiscent of black coffee in the finish, along with some caramel notes, vaguely tangy finish as well. Medium body, slick texture, soft carb. Overall: this is pretty nice, and decent price point compared to other great imperial porters. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Appearance - Black with ruby highlights. Thin mocha head that settles into a lace cap that remains throughout.

Aroma - Coffee, cant smell anything past all that coffee.

Taste - Coffee, with a hint of vanilla. Bitter, but in a coffee way, not hops.

Mouthfeel - Full body with moderate carbonation. Finishes dry.

Overall - Well crafted porter, seek this one out!

On tap at The Common Table.  Pours black with a thick tan head.  The aromas are vanilla, roasted coffee, chocolate.  The mouthfeel is dry, bitter and has a heavy body with light carbonation.  Lots of roasty goodness going on here!  Cheers!

Black as the bottom of the sea. Split this with dad in Father's Day after a great meal. Would've gone great with a cigar but neither if us were holding.  Can definitely taste the coffee and vanilla. Balanced perfectly with malt.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

At Seo Carlo. Aroma was super coffee and chocolate with lovely dark roasted malts. Taste was much the same, with an amazing balance of alcohol with malted sweetness.  I was very pleased with this.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 ounce bottle divided up into tulip glasses. This is one of the best imperial porters Ive had in a long time.  It has a big coffee and chocolate presence that is somehow different from the type of thing youd find in a stout.  Its sweet and toasted, as if your tasting a dark cake. Thick in body, mild carbonation, mouth coating and durable in flavor and very approachable. They do a really good job masking the 10% abv.  At $7.99 for a big bottle, this stuff is a steal.

Very dark, not something to start with if your not beer drinker. Aroma is good and strong. It starts with a sweet taste (vanilla) then you taste the coffee, subtle finish with what I feel is a bland after taste but enjoyable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma of boozy cookies and cream. Chocolate, cream, coffee. Black, with ligt brown head. Taste s slight roast, chocolate, vanilla. Delicious..
Bottle. Dark brown almost black beer with a minimal head. Vanilla, chocolate, coffee and malty aroma. Coffee, vanilla, chocolate, malty and a bit licorice flavour.

Tallahassee, Fl - ABC Fine Wine and Spirits - 22 oz bomber. Pours a dark as coal black with a frothy, creamy khaki colored head. Aroma has some marshmallow accents, a hint of milk chocolate, a touch of creosote,  Flavor as bold and superb with some light Kahlua notes, some marshmallows, a touch of bittersweet chocolate, a touch of black topsoil. Nice thick, slightly chalky mouthfeel. Excellent porter.

Pours black with a small mocha head.  Smells of dark chocolate, earthy coffee, and vanilla.  Tastes dark chocolate and coffee up front, the vanilla comes through on the finish.  As you drink more, the smooth vanilla comes through even more.  Great beer
Plummy bouquet, which is weird. Doesnt taste plummy, which is less weird.  Tasty vanilla and smoky coffee notes.  Full mouth feel. Overall good experience.

Huge coffee notes in this one.  The vanilla smells like a homemade vanilla extract I made a while ago with vanilla beans and vodka.  Lots of booze in this one and the 10 ABVs are prevalent.  First sweet then followed by an everlasting roasted bitterness on the tongue that reminds me of chewing on espresso beans and fresh vanilla beans.  The roasted notes were expected from a Porter.  I found the Vanilla, Roasted Coffee and the booze which rectified the fact that it is definitely an Imperial Porter.  If they could find a better way to mask the booze I would have enjoyed it more.     My rating was originally lower, but then I thought about it again and they really did satisfy everything that the label on this beer said it would be.
@Magic City Brewfest. Black with a small head. Aroma of coffee and roasted malts. Coffee, caramel and notes of vanilla.

Bottle from Binnys in Orland Park, nice dark brown pour with a brownish head. Big coffee aroma with a nice malt backing, milk chocolate and a bit of vanilla. Taste is very similar, bitter chocolate, coffee roast and vanilla, solid beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

65 cl bottle @ lusikka, enjoy by 17.10.2013
Aroma has coffee notes, salty licorice and vanilla. Flavour has mocha coffee, vegetables, some chocolate, vanlla and salty licorice. A bit too salty but not bad anyway. I like the vanilla notes here.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2017 355 ml bottle.
Coffee is very evident on the nose, quite fresh actually, roasty, chocolaty. Flavor has bitter malts and dry coffee, cocoa and faint bready tones. Very pleasant, more coffee-forward than I remembered. Slightly better than the first taste was.

65 cl bottle.
Rating: 9-4-8-4-15=4.0

Pours pitch black color with a small head. Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate and vanilla. Flavor of coffee, roasted malts, chocolate and cocoa.Very balanced and tasty brew. Excellent.
4516

650ml bottle from a trade, thanks Hugonaut13!
Enjoy by 10/17/13 - Pours pitch black with a light brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, cocoa, vanilla, mocha and espresso. Taste is roasty, heavy with coffee notes, espresso, cocoa, vanilla and mocha. Finish is sweetish, roasty and heavy in coffee notes, hints of vanilla and cocoa as well. Quite smooth, well balanced and tasty imperial porter with loads of coffee.

650 ml bottle.
Pours a pitch black colour with a beige head. Aroma of rich roasted malts, mudcake, dark chocolate, weak citrus and some caramel. Flavour of roasted malts, salty licorice, dark chocolate, cherries, wood, caramel, coffee and vanilla. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel and a roasty, vanilla, grass finish with mellow sweetness. Smooth and very well balanced. Excellent stuff.
Bottle.  Completely clack, nice thick brown head.  Aroma of coffee, vanilla, molasses.  Taste is rich and roasty shoo-fly pie, espresso, vanilla.  Delicious.

Aroma: Coffee, milk chocolate.
Appearance: Solid black, mostly white lacy head.
Taste: Bitter sweet chocolate
Palate: Mild carbonation, somewhat dry, medium body. Slightly bitter chocolate finish with a hint of vanilla.
Overall: Less complex than I imagined, but solid overall. The lingering bitter chocolate aftertaste detracts from the overall beer somewhat.

A strong porter. Vanilla is very present but a perfect balance. Not too sweet as some porters are. Nice lacing. Perfect head. Solid mouthfeel.  Substance and balance. This is a great beer. A great brewery.

Pours a deep dark brown almost black in color.  Aroma is of robust coffee with a tinge of vanilla.  Tatse is of rich, chocolate coffee throughout with a hint of burnt caramel.  The aftertaste leaves a burnt coco flavor, a true imperial strong porter in my opinion.

This deep black porter has a strong chocolate aroma. It has a head which looks like a latte. It has a strong coffee flavor with hints of vanilla which remind me of bourbon. Very well put together and flavorful. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black, two finger thick khaki head thin lacing that sticks around.  Aroma is coffee grounds, chocolate, vanilla up front, sweet vanilla, milk chocolate lingers, no alcohol on the nose at all.  Taste is sweet vanilla, milk chocolate, coffee grounds at the front, bitter coffee, dark chocolate and vanilla mid mouth,  bitter sweet chocolate and espresso on the finish.  Low carbonation, fuller body, bit of alcohol warming and spicyness.  Overall real good, very tasty and complex, you should seek this beer out.

Smells malty, chocolate and coffee.  Pours deep impenetrable black with a thick brown head.  Delicious chocolate, coffee and caramel, with a hint of something peppery.  Nice thick and creamy beer with a bitter finish.

You can smell the vanilla, coffee, roasted beans, the alcohol, beautiful deep dark brown color, the taste is bitter chocolate with a hint of sweetness, the bitter after taste is not overpowering just sits there long enough, if you dont like strong coffee taste, I mean strong, stay away because the first thing you taste when you swallow is coffee. This is one of the best porters I have ever had, love it!

Bomber shared. Pours almost opaque brown. Very dark with creamy mocha colored head. Deep dark roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and hints of alcohol. The flavor works like this, roasted coffee followed by roasted malts and cocoa powder followed by medium alcohol burn. Silky smooth throughout. Imperial porter by any other name would not be victory at sea. Incredible beer.

Shared in line for GTMW tickets. Ink black, thin mocha head. Huge black coffee, a hint of cream, vanilla bean and chocolate. The coffee is pretty astringent on the palate, and helps to balance the sweetness of the vanilla. Pretty great.

Bomber at home. Pours dark brown with khaki head and stubborn lacing. Aroma is roasty coffee with a touch of vanilla.  Taste is more coffee, caramel and some booze. Full mouth. The worlds best porter.

Bottle shared at GTMW line, pours black with a thin tan head and lacing, the aroma has a ton of chocolate mixed in with a the coffee, blends together really well, the flavor has a nice sweet front end with the bitterness of the black coffee in the finish, vanilla also comes through, really enjoyable.

Pours black with tan head. Aroma is roasty coffee with vanilla. Very rich creamy texture, excellent malt profile. Roast coffee with some caramel malt flavors and a vanilla on the back end. Hides the alcohol exceptionally well also. Great beer.

$10 even at Learys. Shared with Jblauvs at his Amesbury flat. Going to make this as simplified as I can: I got a healthy amount of black liquorice, molasses, and cold-pressed coffee. Booze and vanilla were quite prominent as well. Smokiness and yeast, by swallow. Yummy. I remember previous years being a little more balanced and sweet, but I like this just fine.
Bomber->snifter.  Deep brown with small tan head.  Aroma: roasted malt, chocolate, coffee.  Taste: bitter coffee, dark chocolate, dark fruits.  Excellent.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2013 Nice! Near perfection. Beautiful beer. Full of complex flavours. However where this beer falls short is in aroma. Which is not really a big deal with a flavour profile like this. Damn.

Pours brownish-black with a decent sized tan porteresque head that leaves light lacing. Aromas are sweet coffee, cream, vanilla and just a hint of caramel and chocolate. Flavors are similar to the aroma though the vanilla hits first as sweet and creamy, then a lovely coffee bitterness edges in followed by a very long and pronounced bittersweet chocolate finish. Palate is heavy if you serve this cold but reaches perfection when it is allowed to warm. Overall this is probably the best Imp Porter I have had the pleasure of drinking.

Appearance- Thick black with a thin tan head. Average lacing.
Aroma- Rich roasted coffee, dark chocolate, hint of sweet vanilla
Flavor- Bitter roasted coffee, bittersweet chocolate, vanilla background

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2015 Tap. Black with minimal head. Big and boozy porter with huge vanilla and light coffee. Sweet with tons of flavor. Interesting but bordering on overdone.

Had this again from a bottle, and found the coffee to be much more forward with light vanilla. Much better balance. Re rating based on this.

Finally got to this one, thick oily black witha short tan head. Big roast malt an coffee aroma and vanilla. Can taste a pretty decent hit of vanilla, with a nice coffee, some smokiness and a hot booziness. Fantastic stuff.

Had this at the Monkeypod in Kihei, Maui. It pours a dark cola brown, with a short root beer colored head. Aromas of coffee, fresh chili pepper, and tart cherry. Moutfheel is wet, full, but not thick. Just a bit of carbonation for balance. Cherry, coffee, cola and a bit of sweet vanilla in the flavor. The flavors dont quite blend as well as I would like, but it is still very nice.

Sampled at a recent Wirtz Beverage/Illinois seminar, and viscously dispensed on tap to stemware displaying a rich, opaque, black/brown color, with brownish tan head froth, and wavy cling to the thick lacing. The aroma was pronounced cocoa, with roasted coffee that was very aromatic, but took a back seat. Hints of caramel malt and vanilla were also present and very complementary. The cocoa was even more expressive in the flavor, which was smooth, full bodied, and pleasantly dry toward the finish. My favorite of the afternoon! Move over Breakfast Stout!
Coffee,vanilla, porter. In that order. Done exquisitely well, say no more, nudge, nudge, wink , wink. Fan-blimmin-tastic.

A sophisticated drink with a range of complementary flavours combining to create a sensational, satisfying experience.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

~Strong wet coffee grind flavor with burnt malt and woody notes with vanilla 
 ~Pours black with long lasting brown creamy head 
 ~Sweet malty vanilla flavor with strong roasty coffee and malt flavors 
 ~Medium creamy body with medium CO2 kinda harsh lingering burnt roasty finish 
 ~Enjoyable beer but the strong roast and heavy sweetness dont really blend as well as they should. They are very seperate from each other and a bit intense.

A great porter, may be one of the best weve had. Pours the usual thick black with brown head. Smells of sweet nuts, like macadamia nuts, and coffee. Taste is awesome, lots of vanilla and nuts, some coffee. Sweeter then most porters. Damn good. Had on tap at Mill Valley Beerworks. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a solid black with a light brown head and lots of lacing. It has a rich aroma of dark chocolate, coffee, and vanilla, and the same notes are in the flavor up front, leading to a coffee and chocolate aftertaste over medium-heavy body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2015 Rerate:  No chalk.  No bitter.  Nice coffee.  

Okay it starts out amazing.  Coffee aroma  is perfect.  Has a nice thick head, it fades, but still for an Imperial porter, very nice.  This is the end of perfect.  Has a chalky thick flavor on the tongue.  Sweet with a chalky bitter flavor.  In general its not to great other than to sniff.  Not horrible.  But not to buy again.
Very aroma of this beer. Heavy and hard of it are much flavor. Long and intense aftertaste. A real tough guy beer if I say so.

Bomber pour into snifter..dark black hue..aroma is quite intricate..popping with solid coffee..vanilla bean..roasty goodness..more carbonation than expected..light brown head stays around and coats the glass..mouthfeel is very complex and completely masks the 10 percent..very well done..would be a great brunch match..so smooth..

22 ounce bottle into snifter, best before 12/10/2013.  Pours dense pitch black color with a 1 finger dense dark tan head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers.  Light spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass.  Aromas of big vanilla, cream, milk chocolate, caramel, toffee, coffee, light roasted malt, and dark bread.  Incredible aromas with great balance and complexity of dark malt and sweet vanilla notes.  Taste of milk chocolate, vanilla, cream, roasted malt, caramel, coffee, light char, toast, floral, and light pine.  Lingering notes of vanilla, milk chocolate, cream, roasted malt, caramel, coffee, light char, toast, dark bread, floral, and light pine on the finish for a while.  Fantastic balance and complexity of roasted and sweet creamy vanilla malty flavor; with a good malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying sweetness present after the finish.  Medium carbonation and full bodied; with a very creamy, slick, and slightly syrupy mouthfeel that is great.  Alcohol is very well hidden with only a small warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a fantastic imperial vanilla porter!  Great balance and complexity of roasted and sweet malty flavors; and extremely smooth to sip on for 10%.  A highly enjoyable offering.

On tap at Barleys Taprooms in Greenville, SC. Pours an almost impenetrable black. Aromas of coffee and heavy cacao on the nose. Has a sweet scent, yet a heavy alcohol presence. First sip was a delight, having a lot more coffee than I had anticipated. Chocolate rolls off the back of the palate and a decent alcohol burn towards the end. Strong for a porter, and very flavorful in general.

Draft at the house of 1k. Black color. Aroma Is dominated by coffee beans. Slight cocoa aroma also. Creamy texture. Warming alcohol. Average carbonation.  Slight vanilla notes.  A real solid coffee porter.

Noire avec un mince col de mousse moka. Nez de café crème et de pain grillé. En bouche, le café se donne en spectacle. Mention spéciale pour léquilibre parfait amertume / acidité / sucré. Lalcool (10%) intensifie les saveurs sans les éclipser; la chaleur se fait surtout sentir en post-goût.

Tap at the tasting room. Near black pour with a foamy beige head. Aroma of espresso roast, bitter chocolate and dark red wine. Taste is very similar but much more bitter and wine-like than I had expected. Bitter coffee finish.
UPDATED: MAR 21, 2014 Pours dark with a tan head. Right off the bat, there are chocolate sweet roast aromas. Full bodied flavors with a very distinct vanilla flavor throughout the drink. Amazing!

Very attractive pour and aroma. Black body and tan head  aroma dominated by cocoa nibs and coffee. Flavor is a little too much alcohol burn and until it gets to room temp thats all you get. Vanilla shows through and i think bourbon barrel but probably because of the higher alcohol.

On tap at Raleigh Times. 

Sweeeeet...very sweet. The vanilla really comes out in this beer - a bit too strong got my tastes.  

Beautiful dark appearance with little head.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at the brewery in San Diego. Served in a tulip glass. Rich creamy brown head over blackness. Coffee, molasses, and hazelnut on the nose. 
More bitter hoppy notes than the aroma would suggest giving it a nice surprise. This screams coffee and vanilla throughout but it is well balanced with dry hoppy bitterness. Great imperial porter in its greater than expected complexity.

Shared a big bottle with Alden down in Dallas (cheers bud!). I do get this beer...HUGE coffee/chocolate/mocha nose and taste with the vanilla arriving afterwards. Make sure you enjoy this one cool; too cold and youre robbing yourself of the full delicious experience. Boozy; yes, but not overpowering. I initially thought it about 8% ABV, not the 10% it actually is. This brew ruined my palate...dont think I can go back to enjoying the Fullers London Porter like I once did! And...we found this brew in the grocery store!

On tap at the brewery in San Diego, served in a tulip. Pours deep chestnut with a moderate, rocky tan head that mostly remains and leaves a small amount of fine lace. On the nose there are big notes of coffee and roasted malts, along with a touch of smoke and a hint of chocolate. The flavour is assertive, but well balanced between medium-sweet with roasted malts and moderate coffee and hop bitterness. The finish is long and roasty with coffee and resinous hops. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a dryish texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a very nice imperial porter; it is complex and roasty, but has a nice blend of assertive hops. 2013-03-22

best by 11/8/13 bottle (assume 11/8/12 bottling?) pour into tulip glass.  this thing is basically vanilla.  dont sense much of the coffee.  has a sour sweet balt finish to it. rather thin on the palate. I dont see the big deal about this one.

On tap at the Amsterdam Cafe in San Francisco.  Great bubbly cream head over a black beer.  Tastes like a choclate liquor, rich and boozy.  Has a hint of coffee maltiness to it too.  Chocolate and nut aroma.  Good stuff but has to be sipped.

Bottle. Definitely one of the better porters I've had (usually don't fall in love with porters). The vanilla comes through and the beer has a great mouthfeel. Would love to have it on tap somewhere to improve the experience. Ballast Point impresses again. Can't wait to visit the brewery in SD this fall.

This beer pours black with a tan colored, well retained head.  Aromas of chocolate, vanilla and alcohol.  Beer tastes sweet with a big vanilla flavor.  Finish is dry.  Alcohol is a bit hot, IMO.  Otherwise an enjoyalbe beer.

Black. No light.  Toffee head, thin.  Dark chocolate and vanilla waft through the nose: alcohol is hiding there also.  sweet and bitter engage in a playful tug of war.  Similar to a cherry cola float with coffee beans and straight cocoa sprinkled on top. Finish cuts the sweet show short with alcohol & hops.  What a ride...YUM!
Very good imperial porter. Tried this one at Beer Revolution during San Francisco Beer Week.

I am hesitant to give a beer a higher rating then on my favorites but that is exactely what I have done. This is just like drinking a chocolate vanilla frappuccino made out of awesome beer. Unbelievable a great porter all the way around. Hope I can get more of it

Pours a nearly black, super dark brown color with a mocha colored, very bubbly head. First thing on the nose is a huge blast of coffee, then hints of vanilla and a nice roasty, toasted malt character. The vanilla is more prevalent in the taste, balances out well with the coffee. Good malty chocolatey finish. Full mouthfeel, with pretty lively carbonation. Very well balanced, incredibly smooth for 10%, absolutely delicious.

Pours a dark black color with a nice mocha head. Nose is chocolate, vanilla and malty. Taste is chocolate, with vanilla coffee and alcohol. Finishes with chocolate flavors and alcohol. Quaff Score 8 / 10

Pours black with a small brown head and aroma of roasted malt, vanilla, and alcohol. Taste is sweet and roasty, of coffee, roasted malt, and vanilla notes with a long, alcohol, burnt finish. Very good porter

Perfect imperial porter aroma: roasted malty sweet with just a hint of coffee then chocolate, would look for a little more to come out. Very dark brown in appearance just barely letting a hint of light through. Slight lacing on glass and more persistent on the surface than most porters. Bitter start changing to roast malt flavors with a slight boozy bitter coffee finish. Roast bitter coffee pleasant aftertaste. Carbonation is spot on and the beer clings to the plate without being cloying. Gives a slight warming feeling in the stomach. Overall a great representative of this style.
Den här har det tjatats om länge nu. Visst är den bra. Härligt avslut. Toner av oboy och kaffe.

Bomber.  Coffee and dessert in a bottle.  Typical dark opaque porter, but with crazy rich coffee, chocolate and vanilla flavors, a little raisin.  Can't do it all night because its so intense, but one of my favorite things in life.  A great 2nd, 3rd or last beer of the night.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured at Sac Beerfest. Aroma and flavor of vanilla, coffee, and roasted malts. Great carb and palate in general. Awesome beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

black color, tan head, aroma of coffee, vanilla, roasted malt, booze, same flavors, bitter coffee, pine hops, slight vanilla, slight milk chocolate, smooth and creamy, pretty bitter but well balanced, very enjoyable brew

Bottle, pretty much as pictured, though slightly different.  This is good, but Im surprised to see a 100 rating on it.  Smells lightly of coffee, some vanilla.  Taste is similar, a nice bit of coffee but not overbearing.  Not bad.

Pours black with a dark brown head.
Aroma of vanilla-laden chocolate.
Flavour of bitter coffee, chocolate, vanilla, malt and ash.
Ends with a slightly distracting bitter herbal hop note.

Bottle.  Appearance: black with creamy mocha head that quickly dissipates.  Aroma:  roasted malt, coffee, cocoa, vanilla and some hops.  Taste: almost some dark fruits and floral notes at the very front leading into vanilla and coffee and finishing with bittersweet cocoa and some piney and coffee ground bitterness.  Mouthfeel:  creamy, silky, smooth with little carbonation.  Overall:  this is delicious.  Its got multiple flavor characteristics that balance perfectly well together and have a great bittering finish.

Awesome pint. Pours black with thick mocha head and lacing. Pungent aroma of coffee, vanilla, roast malt and hops. Taste is coffee bitter with long lasting palate that brings out the different aromas one by one. Highly recommend. Tap at Taberna Lupulo.

Bottle @ Bruces birthday tasting. Cheers to whoever brought this along! The pours deep brown with a modest off-white head. The aromas roasted chocolate, robust charred malts, hints of vanilla and sugar-coated wood. The taste is gull of roasted malt bitterness. Robust wood. The barrel treatment is very pronounced in this. Strong vanilla, soft sweet chocolate. Medium body, quite smooth. Overall, very nice. Slightly cumbersome, but tasty.
Bottle.  Cocoa and coffee malt aroma.  Black with large tan head.  Very sweet chocolate,  coffee malt and ash flavor.   Vanilla and bitter herbal finish.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2013 Dark brown pour, with a thin ring of tan foam. Aroma is great. Roasted malt, vanilla, coffee bean, char, and wood are dominant. Taste is smooth vanilla, coffee, and roast with a nice oak complexity. Mouth feel is nice and smooth with light carbonation on the tongue. Nice porter.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2013 I guess if you do not want to taste too much coffee in a beer, you should stay away from this. Too much coofee on the nose and flavour. Vanila in the aroma, but less prominent on the flavour. Feels like the leftovers of coffee and a porter poured into a glass of bourbon. Nasty. Managed to be the worst beer at the Christchurch Beer Festival.
Yum! 2011 cellar aged bottle. Excellent balance of coffee & vanilla. Exceptional beer.

Pours black with a small light brown head.  Aroma of vanilla, toasted nuts, wood, char, dark chocolate and toast.  Pretty nice.  Flavor is less sweet than this might seems with plenty of dark roasted coffee flavor, vanilla, dirt, dark chocolate, and burnt toast.  Finishes with the vanilla becoming initially more pronounced, but then an espresso-like bitterness takes hold.  Medium-heavy bodied, moderate alcohol presence, decent mouthfeel (nothing terribly remarkable).  Good beer for sure, but I think the bitterness in the finish clashes a bit too much with the initial flavor.
Bomber.  Overall excellent.  High alcohol is not present as result of the flavors and nicely done palate.  Strong coffee but the bitterness is softened with vanilla.  Full body and smooth.

Pours black with thin tan head and some lace. Aroma is roast coffee, light chocolate, vanilla. Taste follows suite nicely with aroma with good roasted coffee predominate, some bitterness. Dry with long coffee finish.

Becoming my favorite porter. A friend brought a gallon growler for a weekend and left half, so Ill just have to do something with it. Deep, rich aroma and flavor; aroma and flavor include caramel, malts, raisins, Dr. Pepper, coffee, a hint of chocolate, vanilla, some bitterness (I assume from the coffee). Compliments both sweet and salty foods. Works best in a snifter.

This brew smells wonderful. Deep caramel caught me off guard. Big roasted notes with vanilla. Taste to me is a little tainted. There is a huge alcoholic bitterness in mid palate. The mouthfeel makes it dangerous. Very light and tight carbonation. This brew is worthy.

For porters you dont get much better than this. Nice roasted coffee aroma. Deep dark color with medium brown head. Nice mouthfeel of medium weight. Carbonation was just right. Great roasted malt flavor with coffee being more dominant than the vanilla. Well rounded with a mild hops bitterness.  Greatness.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2013 Wow! Great draft 12 oz. Pour with thin head and good lacing. Smell of cocoa, coffee and vanilla. Smells of a chocolate factory. Tastes similar. Overwhelming taste of coffee and vanilla with an ultimate smoothness. Its like when you would make chocolate milk with whole milk and Nesquick.

Bottle pours a dark black/brown with a medium tan head. Well rounded aroma of chocolate, vanilla, molasses, and coffee. Taste of tons of vanilla, chocolate, and coffee. Has a sharp bitterness in the middle maybe a mix from the alcohol and hops. Very nice!

Refrigerated brown bomber poured into snifter.  Pour black with small dark brown hightlights.  Little lacing, medium body, medium carbonation, and strong dry coffee aroma.  Taste is roasty, good coffee, and dry bitter finish.  Good porter.

Poured from a 22 ounce bottle. Pours a dense black with a khaki colored head of foam. Aroma is heavy coffee with a smoky fruitiness to it. Taste is that coffee again. Maybe a little too much coffee. Thick, velvety mouthfeel.

Draft. Inky black pour with small tan head. Nose is huge coffee, medium jerky, licorice, huge vanilla, heavy roast and earth. Flavor is strong coffee, bittersweet chocolate, roast, light earth, vanilla with a nice strong boozy finish. Prickly mouthfeel with a nice and warming finish. Excellent.

0,65l bottle. Black bordy with a creamy light brown head. Huge amount of chocolate in the aroma with milk, vanilla, coffee and chocolate notes. Lots of chocolate, vanilla and milk in the flavor with floral hoppyness. Really creamy texture. Awesome beer!

Black pour with small tan head, Big nose of vanilla and roasted malts.
Sweet creamy front, notes of vanilla, chocolate and coffee. just a hint of smoke. Bitter coffee finish
Light-Medium body.

very nice strong porter
Pours black with tan head and mica lacing.  Aroma of creme liquor.  Taste of malts, vanilla, coffee, nuts, and cough syrup.  Complex for sure.

Draft at Churchkey. Poured a dark brown, almost black color with a thick creamy tan head. Aroma was heavy on vanilla, roasted malts, coffee notes and some chocolate. Flavor was about the same, with some fresh notes of coffee, chocolate and plenty of vanilla. Pretty darn enjoyable.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2013 Pours darkdark brown to blak with a very small mocha colored head. Earthy peppery coffe on the nose, some roast with a tad of vanilla and molasses. Biye up front that soothes into lots of chocolate on the palate. Second sip is a bit more earthy coffee. Dont get a lot of vanilla, but it lingers in the aftertaste just a hint. Pretty prickly carbonation, but not too much. Medium mouthfeel but very drinkable (one of the lighter imperial porters i have had). Very nice beer.
Dark pour with a creamy head. Good lacing. Extremely gratifying beer. Coffee, vanilla and more.
Very bold and lasting flavor of roasted coffee, malt with hints of caramel and toffee. Quite dirnkable for the amount of alcohol that it packs. Outstanding porter.
Coffee and cocoa aroma.  Dark with thick tan head. Lots of coffee. A mild sweetness that may be the vanilla but I can't really tell. Earthy undertones. Clean finish. Slight alcohol warmth at the end.
Bruces birthday tasting st the craft. Black caramel colour. Brown tan head. Nose is toasty toffee caramel.flavour is big hazelnut coffee caramel.
UPDATED: APR 24, 2014 Better than actual coffee, IMO. Aroma is all about the coffee with hints of vanilla. Tastes like espresso with hints of vanilla and caramel. Lots of bitter with hints of sweet.
Has a bit of a dry chalky mouthfeel. Roasted coffee notes and a nice amount of vanilla comes through.
22 ounce. Big chocolate pour with strong vanilla tones. Coffee. Burnt cocoa. Medium body. Pretty damn tasty.

Bomber, shared.  Pours pitch black in color with a nice frothy head that lingers a bit.  Great lacing on the glass.  Love the aroma, fresh espresso coffee, vanilla, chocolate, and light roast.  Taste is just what the aroma would suggest.  Fresh espresso coffee throughout, vanilla, chocolate, light bitterness.  Silky smooth finish, a tad thin but not bad.  This beers reminds me a lot of Founders Breakfast Stout, which I love.  Great beer!
Bottle.  Taste is coffee, dark chocolate, vanilla and booze.  Smooth as silk and very well done.

Poured a thin tan head on a black body.
The aroma is all coffee with a little chocolate and vanilla. I am smelling a coffee.
It tastes like coffee, then it moves to a little sweet and quickly to bitter chocolate. Quite enjoyable and interesting.
The texture is almost perfect. Its thick with low carbonation.

Rich aroma of chocolate and coffee. The vanilla sweetens the bite a bit. Slight bitterness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
ballast point continues to impress with this imperial porter. rich dark grains, alcohol whiskey burn and a bit of hop bite on the back end make this a fantastic porter, one of the best.

Black with a nice khaki head that fades down to a film.  Strong coffee aroma with some caramel, chocolate, vanilla and booze in the background. Taste is strong espresso, chocolate, toffee, and a hint of alcohol. Silky smooth texture with alcohol warmth on the way down. Really good.

Bomber bottle. The aroma is a sweet roastiness. I am assuming it is the coffee and dark malt, and also the vanilla. The appearance is black with a tan head. The taste starts out sweet from the vanilla and the the dark malt kicks in. The beer has that sweetness through out and ends dark with a hint of booze. The palate is nice. Overall a decent beer, but i was expecting more with such a high rating. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very well balanced. The coffee is definitely present without overpowering the hop notes. And not too sweet.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Black pour, beige head. Some lacing. Nose is iced  coffee, roasted malts, cacao, some vanilla that I otherwise might not have noticed if not for the description. Taste is iced coffee, roasted malts, sugar, cocoa nibs, vanilla. Hoppy finish. Medium bodied.

Bottle at home with my dad. Pour is pitch black with a big, frothy brown head and great lacing. Big roast, coffee, cocoa nibs, a touch of vanilla, bread, sweet marshmallows, and a touch of spice in the aroma. Taste is sweet chocolate pit, marshmallows, whip cream, espresso, vanilla, a touch of nutmeg, and dark fruits with a sweet finish. Creamy mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Definitely a very sweet dessert beer, but balanced nicely with roast and light spice notes. Exceptional porter.

In! Very complex beer. Black heavy pour with thick tan head. Not much lacing. However, this is a great tasting ale. Roasted notes of coffee and malt lead with vanilla in the middle, and then bam, just the right amount of hop character to finish it off. And it packs a punch as well. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark as the midnight sea, cappes by a few tan breakers. Aroma of super rich espresso, some Oreo cookie, a slight sour tinge. Flavor is roasty with a growing bitterness. I like it.

Pours black with a minimal khaki head. Smells heavy on coffee and roasted malts. Vanilla and booze in the background. Tastes sweet up front, some hops to balance, and lots of coffee. Vanilla isnt as heavy in the flavor as Id hope it was going to be, but its there. A little bitter in the aftertaste, where most of the vanilla is. Thick, mouth coating.  Good stuff.

Pours a thick black from the bottle with fluffy tan head that dissipates to leave good lacing. Aroma of coffee and roasted malts, with an overlying vanilla note. Taste follows, with more bitter coffee than sweet vanilla though. Pretty good, a little unbalanced.

Draught at REAL A Gastropub, Honolulu, HIBlack color with persistent beige head, creamy. Good aroma of coffee and chocolate. The mouthfeel is smooth and round; good flavor of roasted malt and chocolate, quite rich, with a hint of coffee; very strong bitterness (also from the roasted malts) with some hop qualities in the background. Long final, with some alcohol.A very interesting beer, almost a coffee liquor.

On tap at Hollingsheads Delicatessen in Orange, CA. Served in a stemmed goblet.

Waves of warm espresso waft in even before landing in front of me. A mere preamble to the intensity of aromatics present. Straight from the roaster espresso conjures images of beans as dark and glistening as a beetles back along with Irish cream.

Like the label suggests, the head is reminiscent of a thin skin of midnight sea fog that settles into the charcoal black surface. Razor-thin lacing crept down the glass.

Not as overwhelming with espresso as the fragrance suggests, the flavors are more extensive. Chocolate covered raisin melts into creme de cassis and dark raspberry liqueur. Bitter baking chocolate provides a good balance to an otherwise decadent draught.

Chewy and mouth-filling, the palate is more akin to taking a bite of German chocolate cake than drinking.
Deep black point and tan head. Coffee chocolate vanilla aroma. Similar taste more roasted bitterness. Dry finish light sour finish I enjoy with porters. Hides the alcohol really well.

Type: 22-oz. bomber 
Glass: Oversized wine glass 
From: Holiday Wine Cellar in Escondido, Calif.
Price: $9.99 
Purchased: Dec. 27, 2012
Consumed: Jan. 23, 2013
Misc.: Enjoy by 12/10/13

Poured a black color with two fingers of bubbly tan head. Lots of thick, sporadic, foamy lacing on the sides. Good retention on the top.

Smelled very bitter coffee malts up front. Also strong notes of toffee, caramel and dark chocolate, and a light whiff of vanilla.

Tasted a smoother, milder version of the smell. Got bitter coffee malts, dark chocolate, Oreo cookie, smoky fire, roasty malts and burnt toast. Alcohol is well hidden. Nowhere near as good as the smell.

Full body. Slick-to-thick texture. Average carbonation. Long, smooth finish. Got better as it went down. Toffee and caramel really come through, and even got some light vanilla notes late. 

I have to say I was a bit disappointed. I saved this beer for the longest out of any of the others I purchased on Dec. 27. Good, but not great.
Dark brown in color with rich brown tan head... Aroma of chocolate malts and coffee... Flavor is intensely rich, tons of chocolate notes with a finish of coffee bitterness... Superb beer

Reviewed 12/31/2012. Thanks to Momar42 for the bottle share! Part of a 22 oz bottle poured into a Hunahpus snifter. Notes from last nights Skins/Cowboys game.

A: Pours a nicely opaque black color. The head is a one finger offwhite color with decent levels of lacing on the glass.

S: Lots of vanilla to start off - and Im impressed by how naturally it comes off, as well. After that comes a moderate coffee profile...and then after that, tons of chocolaty dark (not necessarily roasted) malts. Not the greatest aroma ever, but I really like how it evolves in its layering.

T: The very first sip is a little harsh with vanilla, though it will smooth out after a few more sips. I really enjoy the layering of the flavors; first vanilla, than subtle mocha coffee, and finally a chocolate and licorice finish. Theres a vegetal component in there that I feel harms the balance. Quite good, apart from the overboard vanilla bittersweetness - but some aging will tone it down nicely.

M: The finish is pure sticky, wet sweetness, which fits what this tries to accomplish as a dessert beer. I could do without the slight sugar burn, though. In general, its lighter in texture and more sharply carbonated than a typical imperial stout - but its best feature is how superbly the alcohol is hidden. I didnt get a look at the ABV on the bottle, but I could easily guess it to be 5.5% rather than 10%.

O: I hope it was just palate fatigue from drinking a quartet of sours before hand, because this was a bit of a letdown. Regardless, this a damn solid dessert beer that can become a really great one after the vanilla fades some. This wipes the floor with certain vanilla porters that will remain nameless, at least.

Poured into a snifter out of a 22oz bomber.

Pours pitch black and reminds me of used motor oil. Not much in the way of a head but the wisps of lacing left on the sides of the glass is truly impressive considering the abv.

The aroma is extremely pleasant and soft. Dark roast coffee and some light hints of caramel. The vanilla is there but it is very subtle, much more so than any other vanilla flavored beer I have had before. Dark chocolate is also mixed in. Sort of reminds me of a mocha coffee drink.

The flavor is even more impressive and substantial than the aroma. The vanilla is extremely subtle and well-integrated becoming most apparent immediately after the sip. Dark roast coffee and vanilla quickly followed by a shot of caramel. Bitterness reminiscent of dark chocolate and espresso followed then by more vanilla and moderate sweetness. Mouthfeeel is on the sticky side and there is a little bit of tannic bitterness on the roof of the mouth.

Overall, an extremely well done coffee vanilla porter. For once the vanilla is not overdone and is perfectly integrated. A sipper for sure but perfect for the cold winter months and one to savor over the course of an evening.

Bottle from Proof. Black pour with a thick creamy tan head that laces. Big roasted coffee, creamy vanilla, raosted malts and chocolate on the nose. Sweet, creamy vanilla on the front of the tongue blending into roasted malts, strong coffee and chewy chocolate brownies with a light bitter ending. Fantastic balance with a slight sweet body. Great beer.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2013 Totally black with a creamy khaki head. Smells of coffee, vanilla, light hops a malts. The flavor is identical to the smell but very full and robust. Roasted flavors and malts finish a complex beer. This is absolutely phenomenal. Cannot stress how good this is.

Smoky coffee cocoa aroma.  Pours black in the glass.  More creamy coffee cocoa in the flavors.  Wow, really awesome.  I feel like Im drinking an iced coffee.  Overall, quite good.... Tasty. Thanks to BarZigKin for sharing!

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2015 Jet black with a healthy tan foamy head,.  Aroma of coffee and perhaps a hint of vanilla.  Tastes strong of coffee, vanilla and alcohol.  Some burn but awesome creamy mouthfeel though some bitterness.  Awesome beer.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2014 Magnificent beer.  Rich robust full bodied with real intent to overwhelm the palate with flavour.  

RERATE: Having just tried a beer that I gave 4.4 how can I not improve on this? Previously this was in my top five.  Where do I go from here? If you like full flavoured dark beers, then this is one of the finest examples you will see.

Bomber, pourds opaque black wih a foamy peated head, rich aroma of cream, cocoa, vanilla, some burnt sugar, flavor is full, rich, and sweet, tons of chocolatey round elements and super creamy, fairly assertive lingering bitterness, really delicious

Bottle (22 oz) 2012. Traded by Reynold314, thanks Matt! Dark brown (almost black) with a medium brown head and huge lacing. Aroma of vanilla,roasted malt and coffee. Taste is about the same with slight caramel notes. Medium body. Alcohol is well hidden. This Imperial Porter is super tasty and pleasant to drink, but not very complex (vanilla/coffee) and pretty straightforward.
draft at Coles, Buffalo. dark pour, tan head. roast, vanilla, coffee notes in both aroma and flavor. very drinkable at 10%. Fuller bodied. Very nice porter

Bomber to glass. Nice roasted aroma with small amount of vanilla. Dark dark pour with beige head. Taste is smooth with slight vanilla.  I found the roasted flavor to be too strong. Really was more charred than roasted

Black, with a moderate light brown head. Light spotty lacing. Aroma of vanilla, coffee, dark chocolate, and light roast. Taste is rich with some sweetness and tons of coffee and dark chocolaty bitterness. Pretty full bodied and creamy with a mild alcohol sting. Excellent.

12oz bottle, Im usually not one for the imperial taste, but this one is excellent.  Black pour, small tan head, aroma of roasted nut hops,, taste of roasted vanilla, chocolate malts, earthy tones (maybe from the coffee flavors).  Well balanced, complexity, warming alcohol, nice brew from Ballast.

Draught.  black, syrupy, and little head.   The aroma is  just sweet vanilla and mediocre coffee.  The flavor is way too sweet and bad flavored coffee bitter. Texture is slick with little life and a little drying end.  This is terribly balanced and ill conceived.  flavored coffee is gross and imperial porters dont work as a style t
for me.

Aroma of rich coffee, chocolate, and roasted malts. An opaque blackish brown pour with a rapidly dissipating tan head and abundant lacing. The taste is amazing! Dark roasted coffee up front, a hoppy bitterness in the middle, and a vanilla chocolatety finish. Full bodied with medium carbonation. Overall, another Ballast Point success!
Pours a pitch black from the bottle, one can definitely taste the intermingling of the coffee and vanilla throughout, pretty crisp tasting with minimal aftertaste

Roasty malty, coffee, and a more subtle vanilla aroma. Taste is coffee up front, a little alcohol heat, and vanilla on the finish. Moderate amount of carbonation and little to no head. Overall one of my favorite porters and definitely one Id recommend.

Very black color, not much head, moderate lacing. Smell of coffee and vanilla, somewhat faint though. Taste is same with more prominent dark chocolate flavor present and warming alcohol. Bitter finish. Very good.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2015 Draft at Alewife in Baltimore.  Dark black with brown head.  Aroma of coffee, vanilla, chocolate and roasty malt.  Taste has big flavor and thick.  Oily creamy mouth-feel with dry finish.  Very good stuff.
Draft - pours black with light brown head and good lacing. Nose is dark coffee. Flavor adds chocolate, vanilla, very bitter. Big body.

On draft at Whole Foods Chandlers Watering Hole. Pours the shade of a cloudless midnight sky with a two-finger cardboard-color head. Big vanilla nose (more like vanilla syrup as opposed to the bean) complemented by a deep espresso aroma. The taste goes perfectly from vanilla to chocolate malts to coffee with a subtle touch of molasses. Velvety slick texture with a refreshing long finish. I cant get enough of this brew.

Simply beautiful on the pour. Opaque with a pillowy head.

Aroma is coffee and roasty with hint of vanilla & chocolate. A twist cone of soft ice cream. Ice cream with no sugar. A real macchiato....espresso with a touch of foam on top. Palate is very dry!

Hoppy finish. Lovely body. I do love a porter but this one is maybe a  tad too bitter for me.
Simply the best imperial porter I have ever tasted. I joined BA just to make a comment on this beer.

Very black body with lasting tan suds. Aroma is of roasted coffee beans. A little oily on the palate and light. Alcohol well hidden. Taste is bitter and the vanilla is not noticeable to me, but enjoyable.

Draft at craft ale house. Pours pitch black with a big tan head that sticks around. Gorgeous looking beer. The aroma has big chocolate, coffee, coffee grinds, caramel. The taste is big coffee, mocha, milk chocolate, big bitter finish.. Warming alcohol.

22 ounce bottle.  Thanks Peter!  Pours almost black with a nice reddish brown head.  Aroma of roasted malt, vanilla, chocolate, and coffee.  Taste is roasted malt, vanilla, dark chocolate, coffee, and caramel. Great balance. Wow!

One of the best from Ballast Point. Smooth, rich, tasty. Full body beer. Bring on more and lots of it .

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

What a beautiful beer!  Theres something about a beer poured into a short glass.  If not the "small packages carry big punches" factor, theres also, simply, how good it looks in the glass.  This is a very dark, almost black beer with a thin, dense cream/light-brown colored head.  The aroma is of roasted malts, with sweet coffee and fresh cocoa, but much more dense and concentrated than what youd expect from your everyday porter or stout.  Where this impresses is in the mouth.  Its not only smooth and silky, but also offers a warm, dessert-like sweetness that Ive never experienced before.  Theres something about it thats a cross between Belgian candi sugar, chocolate, and peppers.  In fact, its very reminiscent of mole sauce.  Theres a smoothness in the body that makes the roasted and chocolate sweetness palatable, but keeps it sharp.  I dont think Ive ever had an imperial porter so smooth and (extremely) tasty with hardly any obviousness of an alcohol presence.

Comes out of the bottle a rich sable just a skeezix above black with a thick and fine-bubbled tan head. Rich, smoky aroma has notes of sweet chocolate, fine coffee, vanilla and caramel and just a hint of molasses. Mouth-filling flavor delights the palate with roast malt, chocolate, nutty, vanilla, coffee and caramel tones with more than a hint of bitter, woody hops. Each sip seems to be subtly different. Its a little like drinking cold quality coffee that has a kick like an angry mule. Smooth, rich texture has a firm tingle that persists; finish is smoky, hoppy and a little chocolate-sweet. I havent given out a perfect score in some time. Love the bottle - Ill keep it and use it as a Halloween decoration. (Yes, I use beer bottles for Halloween deco!)

dark opaque brown. tan head. spotty lacing. Rich, milky coffee aroma with cocoa. rich coffee flavor with a hint of chocolate on the finish. so smooth it doesnt even taste alcoholic. someone talented brewed this.

Strong authentic coffee flavor, roasted malt holds its own I'm getting some hop bitterness, alcohol well hidden, maybe just a little too much carbonation, otherwise a very very good imperial porter 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(22oz Bottle) A nice find by Keg_Juggler. Pours a deep brown with long-lasting head and persistent lacing. Aroma of brewed coffee and vanilla extract. Flavors of well roasted malts, vanilla, coffee and alcohol. An essential winter selection. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black with reddish-tan head that lingers throughout. Aroma of coffee and vanilla are prominent and the flavor is an amalgam of both - both equally there! This is crazy good! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Black with brown head. Hops come through the coffee which is surprising. Solid beer but not amazing. Not getting any vanilla. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

So happy to see this on tap again, it's [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ season! Huge vanilla notes in the nose accompany the roasty malt base and dry porter yeast. Coffee shows up on my palate; fades to leave its bitterness on the roof of my mouth.

Earlier in my beer career I just lumped this in with imperial stouts, but now I can clearly differentiate this dry porter yeast. And man, this stands out brightly among the other imperial porters out there.

Draught > Common Table. Wow, this is delicious. Big but a super easy drinker. I was worried that it would be overly sweet b/c of the vanilla but thats not the case. Great balance. I wish the palate was creamier but thats being picky. Not really more I can add.

Pours pitch black with a small brown head. Smells strongly of roasted coffee. Taste dominated by coffee and vanilla with a roasted undertone. Full-bodied with a smooth texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Ballast Point Victory at Sea finishes with a coffee bitterness and some vanilla tones.

22 ounce bottle, stamp says enjoy by 11/26/13.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours dark brown/black with about a half inch tan head that sticked around for a while.  Theres also a good amount of lacing.  Aroma is nice, the brew smells like coffee, vanilla, roasted malt, and bittersweet chocolate.  The taste is pretty much just like the aroma, it tastes like coffee, roasted and burnt/charred malt, bittersweet chocolate, vanilla, and a bit of caramel.  It starts off bitter, and then the sweet flavors catch up to balance things out.  Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, its a bit creamy and has moderate carbonation.  The 10% ABV is well hidden.  I have to say this is a pretty good overall brew.  As soon as I heard Ballast Point was coming to Ohio, this was the beer from them that I was wanting to try the most, and it hasnt disappointed!  $8.99 a bomber, I know Ill be buying this again.

On tap at Brodys in Jamul.  Pours dark black with a medium to large head.  Aroma is coffee, vanilla and chocolate.  Flavor is vanilla forward with coffee, roast, nuts, chocolate.  Really nice mouthfeel, medium body.  Very good.

Bomber. Pours nearly black with a slight tan head that fades fast leaving moderate lacing. Aroma is coffee and vanilla. Taste is BIG on the vanilla, too much so. There is a nice dry bitterness to balance some of the sweetness. But overall this tastes like a vanilla/hazelnut latte. The alcohol burn doesnt really hit until the very end.
