bomber poured into a snifter, poured black with a coffee brown color head which didnt last past the first sip.  smell is coffee and roasted malt.  Flavor is rich, coffee, roasted nuts, sweetness of vanilla, carmelized sugar and booze.  The abv is pretty well masked, but you get a nice warm sensation on the back of your throat

This bottled brew from rbsg #21 poured a very small sized head of frothy large sized light brown colored bubbles that were and left behind a no visible carbonation opaque dark brown colored body and a poor lacing. The aroma was coffee dark malt and woody. The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and strongly tingly at the finish with a mild coffee bite and a strong roasted dark malt aftertaste. The flavor contained notes of roasted malt coffee and dark malt. Delicious and one I would certainly like to have again.

22 oz. bottle, sent from coryking (thanks Cory), pours a red-tinged black with a small tan head. Nose brings out loads of vanilla beans and roasted coffee beans, atop a bit of roast, chocolate and caramel underneath. Flavour brings out more of the roast than the nose suggests, with somewhat harsh roasted malt qualities upfront, transitioning to dark roasted coffee and subtle vanilla flavours. Finishes on the harsh roast, with subtle vanilla and caramel undertones. Quite oily and silky on the palate, with the aforementioned harshness from the roast / coffee. Great stuff, but overrated I feel.
UPDATED: APR 30, 2015 Tap, brown pour, white head, nose and taste are super chocolate, coffee, some vanilla for days

22oz bottle. Enjoy by date is 11/26/13. Dark, but still somewhat translucent color. Little thin light brown head. Wow, big bitter turkish coffee flavor. Bits of lace. Bigger body, smooth crisp carbonation. Creamier texture. HUGE coffee. Drowns out most of the vanilla, but whats there is still a welcome addition. I like these things more bitter than sweet anyway. Awesome coffee beer.

Big coffee and nut aroma, pours an opaque black with a large tan head.  The flavor has notes of peanut, vanilla, coffee, chocolate and roast, with a long lingering finish and a slightly slick mouthfeel.  This is one fine imperial porter, with the alcohol amazingly well hidden.

Bottle from Appalachian vintner. Pours black with an inch of khaki foam. Nice coffee aroma on the nose that doesnt overpower the beer. Solid coffee with a hint of vanilla on the tongue. Hides its alcohol well. Very nice!

Bottle @ home... from Santa 2013 .... It pours high blank opaque black with a long lasting and living tan head .... The aroma is roasted malt, coffee beans and vanilla......The flavor is very nice chocolate, roasted malt, coffee beans and vanilla...... Very enjoyable!... Very nice!....

Bottle pours a dark black cola with a medium mocha head and intense lacing.  Aroma begins with most intense enjoyable coffee and dark chocolate followed by hints of vanilla and roasted malt.  Taste has slightly less powerful roasted coffee and cocoa flavors leading to a wave of smokiness and palatable espresso bitterness on the finish.  Nice creamy and sticky mouthfeel with coffee notes lingering.  Most impressive coffee aroma in this amazing imperial porter.
outstanding beer for its type. smell and taste are wonderful. If you like coffee porters, you will love this beer!

bastard bad boy sea brew kicked my ass last night. maybe because i was in the army? cocoa a bit of caramel and light smoke. beer seems moderate and gets dense and murky like hot  cocoa in coal with the alcohol totally hidden since it took me a pint to even notice it. balanced with vanilla this beer is satisfying. im a coffee prude as well so i didnt get that much there. from the best taps on the Eastern Seaboard R&H NYC.

Pours black with 2 finger khaki head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt and alcohol. Taste reveals prominent coffee note and lots of alcohol that kind of obscures the vanilla. Probably needs to be aged a bit to take the sting out of the alcohol. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft from Valhalla.  Pours opaque brown black with tan small head.  Roasted malts and coffee.  Dark chocolate.  Well done.
This is the best porter I've ever had. The vanilla dominates in aroma and taste but is nicely balanced by the coffee. It's all about the vanilla here and it's amazing.

Pours like motor oil with minimal head. 

Smells like a pot of cold coffee. 

Tastes like coffee on the front and the vanilla comes in on the back end.

Has the bitterness you would expect of a carbonated coffee. 

Really great for a 10% abv. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Massive coffee roast, fudge and molasses on the nose. Pitch black in color with a mahogany tint. Big roasty flavors of caramel, coffee beans, espresso, fudge chocolate, cocoa beans and hinted vanilla. Big booze on the finish. Texture is very smokey and thick. Overall, this is a strong, full bodied beer with mean coffee and fudge overtones. Id give this an A rating.

Draft at Khyber Pass. Pitch black oily pour. Only in holding the ring up to a very bright light could I discern that it was really a pitch black brown. Tan head left fairly quickly. Wonderful big boozy dark flavors. Charcoal. Ash. Coffee grounds. Tobacco. Burnt toast. Vanilla beans. Devils Food Cake left in the oven and burnt to a crisp. Fantastic!

Draft.  Poured nearly black with a thin tan head.  Aroma and flavor was lots of roasted malt, mild vanilla, mild coffee, some chocolate and caramel.  Low bitterness, moderate sweetness.  Slightly creamy mouthfeel.  Thought it could have used a touch more bitterness for balance.  But still quite tasty.

On tap 4 oz. pour at Meridian Pint in Columbia Heights, Washington, DC.

Opaque near black with khaki head and excellent lacing.

Aroma of vanilla, chocolate, coffee, oak and roasted malt.

Taste of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, pepper, vanilla and oak.

Full body and and low/medium carbonation.

An outstanding brew.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma of malt, light coffee and vanilla. Pours an opaque brown with very nice tan head. Smooth chocolate, some roastines. Vanilla sweetness is understated but present in the finish. Slight alcohol burn. Very enjoyable.

Bottle. Pours an almost black color with very little head. I dont get much nose off this, but there is a little bit of coffee and roasting that I detect. Taste is just a tad sweet, but with coffee and roasting in there as well. Very interesting brew...

bomber. Thanks Billy for sending this. Enjoyed at fridge temp in a snifter.

A - Pitch black. 3 finger creamy coffee coloured head that fades very slowly. 

S - I smell coffee and vanilla from 2 feet away. On the nose, latte and espresso like smells, creamy and very roast. 

T - WOW. Huge acidic coffee notes. The finish is creamy sugar, nice vanilla bean taste. Very much like a vanilla latte thats carbonated. fresh roasted coffee, sugar and cream. Wow 

M - Heavy body, medium carb, dry roasted finish

O - I was not expecting such a terrific beer. Worth seeking out. Wow.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2013 Tap. Pours clear deep black-brown with a small tan head and nice lacing. Vanilla dominates the aroma, with notes of espresso, smoke, and chocolate. The flavor is about the same, medium sweet with a light coffee bitter finish. Medium body with a well masked ABV.

22oz bottle from TomZ, Thanks!. really a solid imperial porter, the vanilla is hidden to me, it finds its way out only once in a great while, whats awesome is holding this beer up to a christmas tree and seeing no light, shes thick and dark.. well suited for fireside drinking.. not overly sweet like some ST offerings either.

Pour from a bomber that was a bonus beer from Heatwaves - thanks!! Dark pour, pretty thick! Malty coffee nose. Nice hops and bitterness complements the coffee - I dont get any vanilla, but I dont have the most discerning palet. I do know that it is quite good though!
UPDATED: MAR 15, 2015 On tap at Hop City, pours black with a small cream colored head. Nose is coffee, oats, cocoa, vanilla. Medium mouthfeel, medium carbonation. This is a very well done beer.
An amazing imperial that can fill out the palate. Of all the dark beers, this one falls as one of my more favorites.

Tap. Foamy tan head that leaves oil slick spots on a very dark brown, nearing on black body. Sharp espresso and lots of vanilla in the aroma, with some booze and sweet spice. Flavor is dark sweet fruit, vanilla shake, bitter bitter bitter coffee and a touch roasty in the finish. Medium cottony body.

Taken from my BA account, reviewed on 2/22/12
Live tasting, bomber into Duvel tulip...

Appearance; pours black with two fingers of bubbly mocha colored head... Retention is decent with the head hanging around for a couple minutes before falling to a thin film... Lacing is good, with blotches and spiderwebs all over the glass.

Smell; coffee and vanilla!! And not much else... Try as I might, I cant get any more aroma from this brew...

Taste; holy moly, this is a vanilla latte lovers dream brew!! Tons of coffee and vanilla... Smoothly roasted and not overly bitter or burnt tasting, great flavors of vanilla bean... As the coffee and vanilla fades out with hints of malt and chocolate sneaking in...

Mouthfeel; on lighter side of full bodied, with good carbonation... Slightly bitter finish.. 

Overall; a damn good beer all around, the vanilla and coffee work exceptionally well together!! Ill definitely track this one down again, absolutely worth the effort to obtain!

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2012 22oz bottle into tulip. Pours a dark black with hints of mahogany in the light. Aromas of caramel, roastiness, a little vanilla and huge coffee. Taste is smokey roasted black coffee, toffee, and a little vanilla. Very full mouth feel with a long lasting, coffee grounds, aftertaste. Very well done beer.

Love this stuff, cant wait every year when this one shows up.  Very Black pour with a nice contrasting tan head.  Coffee aromas jump out, followed by vanilla, and chocolate.  Lots of coffee flavors mixed with vanilla and chocolate against a well balanced mild sweetness.  These flavor overlap into the finish.  Damn good.

Bottle - 2012 batch. Strong coffee nose, limited vanilla. Pours jet Black with a wispy tan head. Heavy coffee flavor hides the vanilla some, but it starts to shine as it warms. Long lasting, very pleasing palate.

22oz bottle, best by October 17, 2013.  Served at around 45F and allowed to warm.

Pours thick black with a small light brown head that leaves some spotty lacing behind and recedes to a light cap and ring.

Aroma is big and bold vanilla and coffee, in fact those two are so strong Im having a hard time picking up much else, maybe some underlying notes of roasted malts, chocolate and caramel.  Excellent strength.

Flavor starts with a big wave of vanilla, moving towards some dark bakers chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, a little dark fruit, very little hop presence, moderate sweetness, some alcohol but well integrated at this level of ABV.  Really tasty.

Mouthfeel is full bodied, rich, creamy, somewhat sticky, good carbonation.

Man, this stuff is delicious!  A vanilla bomb!  Such a treat to get to try this.  One of my customers brought me a bottle after a trip to the West Coast, so a big shout-out to Mark for this one!

Bottle pours thick black with beautiful firm thick chocolate head. Aroma chocolate and dark fruits.  Taste chocolate, coffee, vanilla, roast, ash, some malty sweetness especially as it warms.  Finish prolonged roast and unsweetened chocolate, some alcohol burn.  Finish of chocolate brownies at times,  palate thick and creamy.
Outstanding imperial porter worthy of the name.

22oz bottle.  Pours a pitch black with thin tan head.  Has a nice coffee grind and vanilla aroma that is heavenly.  Smells like candy.  Flavor is coffee, chocolate, vanilla.  Virtually no trace of the 10% abv which is amazing.  Lingering finish.  Amazing stuff, wish they made it year round.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Black with big, creamy, brown head / Strong nose of coffee, vanilla, and chocolate / Medium to full body, inky and intense, sweet and cloying, malty, with some hop balance and bitter finish / Strong flavors of cold coffee, vanilla, bittersweet chocolate, and caramel / Probably for those who like flavored coffee, but for me, too cloying, too much vanilla, and not enough hops.
Bottle, pours a nice black, good light head, aroma is lots of vanillia and flavour is so as well, this one had a nice roasty body, overall very smooth and flavourful, tasty offering
Bottle (bomber), courtesy of tkrjukoff. Black with beige head. Strong roasted coffee aroma, vanilla, salmiak and gunpowder. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. Semi dry with medium bitterness.

Bomber courtesy of tkrjukoff. Pours black with a frothy dark chocolate head that slowly dissipates while leaving some trace and lacing on the glass. Smell is sweet and malty with roasted malts, dark roast coffee, vanilla essence, liquorice root, alcohol, roasted nuts and dark honey. Taste is sweet with roasted malts, vanilla essence, "American" coffee, bitter chocolate, alcohol, toffee, hazelnut skins and hints of bergamot. Mouthfeel is soft, round, tiny boozy and medium to full bodied. Finish is slightly sweet and slightly bitter with roasted malts, vanilla fudge, dark roast coffee, bitter chocolate and hints of grass. Good but was a bit put off by the intense vanilla.

Bottle at USA comes to Skövde. Pitch black beer with a nice brownish head. Coffee and vanilla aroma, hay, peat notes, dark chocolate, licorice, vanilla fudge, raisins, milk, licorice, roasted, almost burnt, bitter notes, caramel. Vanilla flavor, coffee beans, licorice, dark chocolate, cocoa powder, hay, peat notes, fruity, raisins, caramel notes.
Sampled at UCTS testing. Pours pitch black with a big brown head. Smells vanilla, roasted malt and coffee. Tastes vanilla and smoky roasted malt.

Sampled at USSkovde
Black. Almost no head. 
Coffee and coffee-beans in the aroma. 
Loads of sweet vanilla in the flavour.  Coffee and milky chocolate. 
Light body, low bitterness. 
Too much vanilla.

Bottle @ rlgks tasting. Pours pitch black with a  small tense brown head leaving lacing. Aroma is coffee vanilla roasted malty ashy dry. Flavor is vanilla vanilla sweet heavily roasted malty coffee chocolate and bitter. Finishes bitter sweet vanilla.
Vanille en plein extase dans ce liquide dense mais très facile à boire. Jai été surpris par son manque de panache, je mattendais à une bière moins unidimensionnelle. Quand même très solide.

Poured from a bomber into my Founders snifter. Split the bottle with my old man during the Homerun Derby.

A: Pours a very dark brown, almost black with a wonderful bubble dark brown head. Leaves some wonderful sheet lace behind with some bubbles trying to to keep the head afloat.

S: Big dark coffee beans. Roasted to the point where its almost slighty burnt and bitter, but in a good way. Some slight dark chocolate notes are present as well.

T: Big coffee right up front. That same REALLY toasted flavor is even more present, but after the initial assault on the taste buds it makes way for some light sweet chocolate and vanilla. Im also picking up a burnt sugar/caramel flavoring as well.

M: Medium to heavy bodied, almost chewy in nature. Leaves a great roasted coffee bean flavor with a mild sweetness on the tongue. Leaves an oily feeling on the palate which is highly enjoyable as it allows the taste to linger LONG after Ive swallowed this black gold.

O: Im becoming more and more a fan of brews with heavy coffee flavorings and this might be one of favorites. Its not as balanced as others Ive had, but its still a wonderfully crafted brew and I would LOVE to try this on draft.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-12-2011
Bottle from Marcus has a pepper chilli aroma. Taste is ash trey. Some burnt malt. Not a big fan

From 650ml brown bottle. Black pour, med sized beige head with nice creaminess. Huge coffee nose, a little sweetness as well. Taste has big black coffee, toffee, roasty. Dry finish, lingering coffee and vanilla notes. Medium body. Smooth, very nice strong porter.
Black with a thick beige head. Rich chocolate, vanilla, roasted malts, espresso, and a bit of hops. Smooth mouthfeel with a bitter coffee finish. Alcohol blends in very well.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2012 Bottle from trade with Bobertkuekn. Black pour, low head, moderate carbonation. Aroma is sweet roasted malt. Taste has very noticeable coffee and chocolate notes along with the expected roasted malt flavor and just the right amount of vanilla. Bolder and more complex than just about any other porter. Finish is lingering flavors and significant right  hop bitterness. Alcohol is mostly hidden. Mouth feel is slightly thick and velvety. A very very tasty porter and a new favorite. Also tried a 2-year old version that was more mellow, less bitter, but retained the good flavor well, so this is worth aging for a couple years if you want to take some of the bitterness out. Will also thin out slightly with time.

A-- Poured black with tints of red. Settled black. One finger dark mocha colored head. Very fluffy, very good head retention. On swirling some noticeable alcohol.

S-- Coffee. Not really overpowering but there. Roasted malts and some hints of vanilla as well.

T-- Coffee, vanilla and carmel. The carmel really stood out. Reminded me more of an iced coffee. Quite nice.

M-- Medium light body and a bit velvety. Carmel and vanilla in the front and roasted malts and coffee finish. Was a little bitter in the end with a vanilla finish.

D-- Well balanced. Sometimes coffee, sometimes vanilla and sometimes carmel. No taste able alcohol to this. Was a bit light in spots but very, very good, Easily could have had a second bomber of it and been happy and not had an issue with it. Very happy to have had one of the beers I have been wanting for a while. Did not disappoint one bit.

A - Pours a very dark brown with a finger of frothy chocolate colored head. The head fades down fairly slowly leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is full of roasted chocolate and coffee with some dark fruits, vanilla, and a bit of booze.

T - Starts off with some roasted dark chocolate and coffee beans with some vanilla, raisin, and other dark fruits. Through the middle, some more roasted and lightly bitter coffee comes through with some stronger vanilla. The finish is a mix of roasted bittersweet chocolate with some coffee, vanilla, dark fruits, and booze.

M - Medium-full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a roasted, dry, and warming finish.

D - Very drinkable. Bold but perfectly balanced. The coffee, chocolate, and vanilla flavors go very well together.

Received in trade. Pours black with a three finger tan fluffy head. Smell strong Baltic porter with some sweet vanilla, some roast. Taste FANTASTIC, strong vanilla and roast up front, coffee on the tail. Bit of alcohol but not overpowering. Best Impy Porter Ive had so far.

Absolutely drenched in coffee, vanilla, and chocolate aroma and taste. Dark brown, frothy head. Super rich, smooth, huge boozy kick at the end, almost like its bourbon barrel aged. Perhaps some raisin. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2014 Re-rated at Ballast Point Tasting Room, Little Italy, 13/11/14.

Needed to tone down early amateur rating of 5.0 !!!

Still a solid imperial, lots of coffee and tempered well with roasted notes, drinks way under the ABV.

RR to 4.4.

Poured from a 22oz/650ml bottle into a growler (drank Apr12) , thanks to Bruce for packing this in his case and shifting it 6,000 miles for me!!!

Looks a real treat - pours a rich black with a decent beige/tan head after a straight glass/vigourous pour into a Belgian snifter. Head thins after a minute but retains. Lots of lacing above the beer line.

Served at room temperature.

Great smelling beer - coffee hits you immediately and when you withdraw your nose and savour the full spectrum you get the vanilla breaching through, sweet chocolate and malts.

Everything I want from an Imperial Porter in the taste! Chocolate, coffee, sweet and roasted malts and a decent hunk of vanilla in there. Ive had a few vanilla porters where you just dont get that V hit, but here you have no choice !!! A well balanced beer packing flavours and strength but disguising them all well.

The mouthfeel is perfection for a beer of this ilk. Full bodied with a little carbonation, every mouthful makes you return.

One of the best beers Ive had and in my favourite style - the all 5 rating is a real one off but for me this is how it should be as it is right up there for me!!!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
This bottle was a gift from drabmuh. Thanks Matt!

A: A flawless appearance. The beer is jet black and completely opaque. There is a dense, thick, foamy head of a dark tan color. The head retention is great and the glass is coated in lacing.

S: Fresh coffee beans. I am a coffee drinker, and I appreciate the aroma of fresh coffee. We are off to a great start with this beer. Also noted are scents of roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, and alcohol.

T: The beer tastes great. The coffee is more present than the vanilla. The beer leads off with coffee and segues to vanilla and chocolate intertwined in roasted malt. Very impressive. As good as it is, I wish Ballast Point would use authentic vanilla instead of natural flavors. This beer is so close to being amazing. Its the little things that often make the biggest difference.

M: The beer is very flavorful and smooth. The 10% alcohol is disguised very well. Its creamy and thick, with the perfect carbonation level.

D: Its so good, Im drinking it too fast, but not as fast as last time (see notes). This stuff can catch up to you quickly. I thoroughly enjoy this beer. Im taking down the bomber by myself tonight, as I have been really looking forward to a good night to enjoy it, but honestly, its probably best shared a few ways.

Note: Chugging this beer midway through an epic tasting can lead to immediate and irreversible intoxication (even if your friend grills you chicken in the middle of the night) and palate wrecking, causing the imbiber to not be able to differentiate Kate the Great from Alpha Kong. Seriously.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-23-2010

Pours black with a thin off white head. Aroma is rich, coffee mostly. Roasted malts, mild sweetness. Flavor is more vanilla with coffee, roasted malts, caramel, marshmallow perhaps. Medium body with decent lacing.

Draft @ Brickstore Anniversary party.  Pours black with decent tan head. Aromas of coffee, chocolate, sweet vanilla and roasted malt. Tastes are espresso and chocolate, but the vanilla creeps in and really accomodates.  Nice full bodied. Overall, a very nice brew that hides the booze and just balances the heavy coffee and chocolate with the delicate vanilla flavors.

22 ounce bottle

Opening one of two bottles on a quiet evening I found myself faced with a solid imperial porter. The next one may not last long as I continue to whittle down the cellar to a more manageable size. If Ballast Point were available locally I might purchase some other releases from time to time.

Aroma / Appearance - The inky black base slinks into the glass along with a soft cocoa head. Hops, sweet cocoa powder, coffee, and a generous cup of genuine hot chocolate simmer below the surface. Topping it all is a generous dollop of whipped cream.

Flavor / Palate - Subdued hops are probably a result of waiting a few months to open this. The cocoa and black coffee emerge over time. A dash of malt highlights the smooth dry finish. This is a well rounded and robust release that deserves the respect it seems to be getting.

Bottle. Pours a coffee color with a nice brown head that fades, but lingers. The aroma is full of roasted malt, some coffee and sweet notes. The coffee and malt hit you right away. Very full bodied beer. Finishes strong and clean. A great porter. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
65cl, American brew, with vanilla and coffee, thx to Secret Santa!, very complex sweet Porter, roasted/sweet and slightly spicy, not too heavy, balanced, hazy, good head, top class!, yet expensive
Poured out of a 22 ounce bottle. Nice dark color with a dark brown head. You can definitely taste the roasted coffee. I would have another if given a chance.

Undated bottle served in a goblet. Beer is black and forms a thin brown head. Carbonation is low and so is lacing.

There is a nice coffee aroma with a slight hint of vanilla. As the beer warms closer to room temperature the aroma develops more and there is more of a vanilla character to it, also more sweetness.

There is a strong coffee flavor and bitterness in the back palate. The front palate detects a mild sweetness. The beer is smooth, no carbonation on the palate. Beer is lighter in body than expected overall. The bitterness lingers but there is no aftertaste, just a flavor that holds on. Overall, pretty enjoyable and a good porter for sure.

Craft Brewers Conference 2012 
Dark brown in color, clear with a thin tan head.  Super nice Vanilla flavor and aroma.  This mixes well with the dark malts and chocolate flavors this port gives off.  They mix and infuse there brews well here.  Earlier Rating: 12/1/2009 Total Score: 3.8
22oz Bomber  Gravity Beer Market  Olympia WA  
Aroma: Big malt and vanilla/coffee and sweet aroma. 
Appearance: Dark black in color, clear with a thin head.  
Flavor: Big flavors with malt, vanilla and coffee.  
Palate:  Dry finish with a Super Mouthfeel.  
Overall: This was a great beer very sweet this was to be drank as a after dinner drink.

Pours thick and dark with a small tan head. Nose is intense coffee, wood, light vanilla and grass. Taste is sweet at first but bitter mixes in for a perfect balance taste through to the finish. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. Heavy decadent body with a long aftertaste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

28th November 2009Opaque black beer. Palate is silky but also quite crisp. Rich dark malt that is a little creamy. The coffee and vanilla are sparingly used and beautifully judged. Finishes with more smooth dark malt, dark chocolate and dark malt tang. Soft finish. Very deftly brewed beer.

Large choco brown head with good retention and lace. dark brown in color. Justa big old chocolate,roast monster with a oily mouthfeel, chewy and lasting. Notes of cherry and vanilla in the aroma and flavor, also cocoa, hersheys syrup, faint patent notes and lightly warming alcohol and coffee as it heats up, faint coconut and some smoke as well. Sweet malts balanced out with a nice roastyness. Lil sweet finish. Nice brew. Props to UDBeernut!

Ours a deep dark brown with a fizzy brown head that fades quickly. The nose and taste are of toasted malts, coffee, dry and crisp with a tart rye finish. Quite tasty would go great with French vanilla bean ice cream.

Deep brown colour, small beige head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, some toffee and mild ashy notes. Flavour is ashes, toffee, toasted malts, mild alcohol as well as some nuttyness.

Bottle. Pours an almost pitch black color with a tan head. Aroma is filled with coffee and vanilla, roasted malt, milk chocolate, dark fruits and caramel. The flavor is again with lots of coffee and vanilla, almost like an ice coffee, some roasted malt, dark fruits and dark caramel. The body is on the full side of medium with a dry mouth feel. Overall a really tasty Imperial Porter!

Bottle many thanks to coldbrewky, Almost black color with huge beige head. Coffee, vanilla, milk chocolate, toffee in aroma. Taste, coffee, caramel, vanilla, milk chocolate. Strong coffee bitter finish. Excellent complex beer.

Shared by someone at the Montes Krown tasting yesterday.  Pours black, with a tan head.  Huge vanilla notes with some roast fill the nose.  Vanilla taste is very upfront and in your face, before the roast smacks you.  Excellent beer.

05/0572012 220z bottle, shared by Matt (thanks 50belair!). Nera, densa, impenetrabile, schiuma bianco sporca, tra il beige e il cappuccino, molto persistente. Aroma di malti tostati, caffé, cioccolato fondente, con netti sentori di vaniglia. In bocca è sontuosa, ha un attacco da cioccolato fondente e una lunghissima, infinita coda amara, caffettosa, semplicemente spettacolare. Corpo medio, carbonazione soft. Birra sorprendente per intensità ed equilibrio, un vero capolavoro.

Rich caramel malt with coffee and vanilla overtones. Smooth mouthfeel and a dark velvety color.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared in line for GTMW tickets (Madison, WI). Pours a rich blackish pour, pretty dark overall with some brownish edges and glow. Dark, decent haze, not opaque. A frothy tannish head dies to a decent ring, laces small. Aromas are rich coffee roast, touches of cocoa and a firm vanilla bean essence, smmothed out sweetness with some toffee, biscuits. Coffee with cream, roast, toast. Vanilla and coffee play well. Initial is medium bodied, a bit bigger with firm roast, earthy coffee, cocoa up front. Middle shows a gentle sweetness as the finish is really what grabs me: smoothed out vanilla, roasty and sweet coffee, cream, and caramel. Fudgey, rich vanilla bean essence lingers and sets the pace as far as character. Really nice, firm and inviting. Great flavors.

Grazie a Matt&Mortlach; Ci sono giorni che hai la fortuna di bere tanto, bene e in compagnia, le cose che ti rimangono impresse però sono poche e questa birra è assolutamente tra queste. Nera, testa beige, al naso i malti tostati, gli aromi di vaniglia e cacao creano un mix perfetto. al palato le note di cacao e la piacevole amaricatura  vengono rese bevibili da un corpo leggero e da una carbonazione soft.
Truly one of the best of the style.  Perfect amount of coffee and vanilla to go along with a very nice porter.  Excited every time I see this beer.

Very nice porter indeed.  Wife and I enjoyed this at Dats in tampa and it sent the cheesecake for desert to the stratisphere.  Earlier Rating: 3/4/2012 Total Score: 4Had this in a bottle (2011) at Datz and was served at 55. Aroma was similar to a yeasty abby ale. It poured with a nice head and nice dark brown color. First taste the vanilla mostly, smooth and enjoyable. At it warmed up a bit the coffee came foward in taste. What really made this a great drink was a sip after a bite of cheesecake. WOW the "3rd" flavor you got when mixing with cheesecake was an amazing sliky smooth vanilla cheesecake flavor- Awesome!  Really liked this imperial porter.

Big bold high octane porter with a touch of vanilla on the taste and aroma. For being 10% abv it definitely delivers. A little boozy but should be excellent to age and see what happens!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Originally reviewed: 2/23/11. Thanks to steve8robin (BA) for this bottle recently!

Poured into a standard pint glass. Pours a very dark black with a thin tan head on top. Spotty lace rings stick to the glass. The nose is full of ground coffee, roasted malts, vanilla, cream, chocolate. Coffee is the obvious main-player here. 

The mouth is full and creamy. Alcohol definitely smooths this one out. The coffee comes through in the flavor with a punch. Nice dark roasted bitterness to start things off. But the vanilla commands a presence as well. Plenty of creamy sweetness to balance this one out well. Sweet finish with a melding of alcohol, vanilla, and milk chocolate. Ive had this one on my wants for quite some time, so Im glad to finally knock this one off. Excellent Porter.

A thick black body with a brown head that had some retention and mild lace.  Aroma had good cocoa notes, Vanilla and roasted coffee.  A nice presence of alcohol.  Flavor had strong vanilla and cocoa flavors.  Initially I found the coffee notes to be a little too mild, but as I drank more I enjoyed the more subtle quality of it.   Alcohol was slightly warming.  A nice full body  probably should have had with a spoon.

Bottle to snifter.  Looks good; black with nice head.  Smells good too; malty and roasty.  Tastes great; one of the best porters ive ever had (that wasnt bourbon barreled).  Mouthfeel is good too.  A great brew!
Black with a thick beige head. Rich chocolate, vanilla, roasted malts, espresso, and a bit of hops. Smooth mouthfeel with a bitter coffee finish. Alcohol blends in very well.

Pours black with a 2 finger ran head. The aroma is great. Loads if vanilla and chocolate. Taste follows with a silky smooth front to back. Nearly zero alcohol on the back end. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black. Moderate head. Nose is a wonderful rich dessert coffee, vanilla, chocolate, and mild hops. Flavor is spot on chocolate brownie, obvious vanilla, and finishes with some evident bitterness and sweetness. Vanilla is on the verge of being too much but still a good balance. Medium full body. chewy. good.

Pours obsidian, onyx black with a wispy, airy, wildly laced head. Aroma of vanilla, coffee, chocolate, toffee, noble aromatic hops, and some serious roast. Full bodied with a smooth, sweet, well-balanced mouthfeel. Finishes with a bitersweet bite and slight booziness. Outstanding Imperial porter

My neighbor and I split this last night. It was one of the best beers that I have had. It pours black with a lite brown head, aroma of vanilla and cocoa beans with a creamy chocolate/roasted coffee taste. i get a more chocolate finish than coffee. Like have Vanilla ice cream with chocoloate.
Can not wait to get another one.

Courtesy of my next door neighbor, it pours almost black in color with a beige head. It has vanilla and cocoa beans in the nose. There are some other things that im picking up but cant quite identify. Ill have to try again when I open my bottle. The taste is fantastic. Very creamy with molasses and vanilla. The coffee notes them come through and then it has big chocolate finish. Very long and silky. This is a beer that Ill definitely grab some extra bottles next time.

Pours black with very little brown head, medium lacing.  Aroma is coffee and sweet caramel.  Taste is well-balanced between sweet and bitter with vanilla, caramel and coffee all coming through really well.  Thick mouthfeel.  This stuff is amazing.

Draft at Vintner.  Pours out pitch black with a tan head on it.  Smell is roasted malts, chocolate, and a touch of alcohol.  Little bit of coffee present as well.  Tastes sweet and smooth, no alcohol noted, but a little bit of a hop kick to it.  What a great porter, I am really glad they had this one on tap.  I did not get to see the cool label though...

Aroma is sweet, milky vanilla, roasted coffee bean (with no astringency).
Taste is slightly coffee astringent, vanilla, sweetened condensed milk, a slight sourness, cocoa, and some pine bitterness.
Finish is a lingering alcohol sting that is quite surprising, considering it makes almost no appearance previously, and a slick, oily coffee.
Wow.

Pours dark with a light to medium tan head.  Aroma is vanilla, coffee, roasted malts. Flavor is big time coffee with hints of vanilla and roasted malts. Light carbonation and medium bodied.  Little too much coffee for me, but overall a good beer.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown and ruby hue with medium tan head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is choclate. Thin mouthfeel with sweet vanilla and chocolate. Very good Imperial porter from Ballast Point.
Draft. Pours near black with a beige head. Roasted coffee aroma with some light sweet malty notes. The flavor has sweet mocha coffee, milk chocolate, and lightly roasted malts. Good stuff.

Bomber with a pretty sweet label I might add. Pours a thick syrupy brown that looks near black when its all said and done. Massive two finger tan foamy head. Perfect looking porter.

Aroma is big on the coffee and vanilla notes. Rich and malty. Even picking up some maple syrup aromas.

Taste is on point here. Strong vanilla and coffee flavors here. Lots of roasted malts. Some chocholate. Great balance of coffee bitterness and vanilla sweetness.

Its medium bodied. A little thinner than I would have expected. Light carbonation. Lingering coffee finish. ABV hidden VERY well. Not even a trace.

Im really enjoying this. Not a beer you can easily find in the area. But Id def. seek out again. One of my favorite porters now.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2012 A - pours opaque coffee brown with very high fine bubbled head, almost frothy. S - smells amazing. Coffee, chocolate, vanilla up front. Hints of smoke and oak and toasted malts. M - creamy strong bodied brew. Nice strong nose, complex and bold palate. Lingering bitter maltiness with vanilla and oak. T - espresso, chocolate and toasted malts up front. Palate is nice and complex. Vanilla, oak, coffee, rye/grains , marshmallow. Lingering bitter rye, espresso, oak, and vanilla. O - easily the best porter Ive had ( ok its an imperial porter, but still). Very bold coffee chocolate vanilla porter. 8

Aroma of deep black coffee, slight roast and a hint of dirt.  Pours black with slight beige lacing.  Taste is loaded with coffee, strong vanilla bean and a nice sweet caramel aftertaste.  Very intense and great.

Bottle pours black with thin tan head.  Aromas of coffee, chocolate and roasted malt.  Tastes are espresso and chocolate, but vanilla is on the finish.  Body is full with average carbonation and a nice long roasty vanilla finish.  Overall, a tremendous Imperial Porter that is not to be missed.

Finally gonna rate this beastly brew. Nose is full of roasted malt/coffee aromas, smooth vanilla, dark chocolate, some dark fruits, and a metallic earthy note. Excellent. I love the vanilla tones in this. Body is dark, dark brown/almost black with a tan colored head. Taste is lots of roasted malt and earthy coffee. There is plenty of chocolate and coffee dominating the flavors on this porter with a light vanilla finish. This is a great porter for sure. Im so glad I got a second chance to get this brew after passing it up a few times already. What was I thinking??

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2012 Tap. Pours opaque black with thick, frothy tan head; good retention and lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, vanilla, chocolate, dark fruit, and light toffee. Flavor is malt dominate with earthy hops and faint fruit esters; dry, ashy finish. Full body with medium carbonation and warmth.

Tap at Najas.  Pours opaque with a large, frothy tan head, long retention with good lacing.  Aroma is vanilla, coffee and oak with dates and plums, licorice, chocolate and roast malt.  Flavor is malt dominant, oak, vanilla and prunes, light hops and bitterness with a dry finish.  Full body, medium warmth and carbonation.

At 2012 Avery Strong Ale Fest. Black with a thin creamy light tan head. Aroma of roasted chocolate and roasted coffee, with just a bit of creaminess. Smells just awesome. Taste is superb as well. Lots of coffee, lots of sweet milk chocolate, and a creamy vanilla tone that adds sweetness and complexity. Finish and aftertaste is sweet delicious vanilla-chocolate ice cream. Big glass of win.

Tap @ Avery, doing the 10th Annual Boulder Strong Ale Festival. Pours black with a offwhite head. Aroma of roasted malt, vanilla, dark chocolate, vanilla, dark fruit. Taste is rather sweet with malts, coffee, caramel, vanilla, dark chocolate, dark fruit. medium body, soft carbonation. 090312

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2012 Bottle with Steve and the BA crew. Dark brown appearance with a dark brown head. Delicious vanilla bean, rich dark cocoa, light espresso aroma. Creamy mouth feel. Somewhat bitter coffee, dark cocoa, rich and sweet vanilla bean, delicious dessert flavor. Fuck yeah.
Bottle shared at the RBWG in Austin.  Dark pour with a tan head.  Aroma is vanilla, chocolate, and coffee.  Taste is lots of coffee, dirty, a little chocolate, and roast.

One of the best beers Ive had in a while. A wonderful aroma of chocolate, coffee, roasty malt and vanilla. The flavor has all of the aroma and is balanced by just a bit of hops. It has a velvetty smooth feel and a lingering after taste. Looks great too.

On tap at Pinocchios.  Dark pour, dark tan pour, leaves perfect rings on the glass with each sip.  Lots of vanilla and milk chocolate, but also a roasty bite at the finish.  Rich and delicious.  Nice.

Had a ton of samples of this at GABF 2011 and thought it was the best beer there, but chose not to rate it at that time. This rating is for a 2010 bottle. Pitch black pour with a thick tan head. Aroma of milk chocolate, vanilla, coffee and malt. Flavor is malty with chocolate, vanilla before a bitter coffee and dark chocolate finish. All the flavors were balanced perfectly and the vanilla really made me rethink what a coffee beer is supposed to be. Truly amazing.
Wow..  Im a sucker for super flavorful porters with tons of adjuncts.  The coffee and vanilla are very present and nice.  The base porter is tasty and roasty with hints of dark fruit.

A lot of beer nerds, myself included, hate how imperial beers tend to be the highest rated brews across the board. Well, the fact is beers can do so much more with more energy and Ballast Point Victory at Sea is proof positive of that. A regular porter tends to be a very direct, mild beer - but what happens when you crank up the voltage? You get a very flavor, complex, robust beer thats really a fun and interesting drinking experience.

I received a 22oz bottle from a friend in San Diego (thanks, Ryan!). I split it with a friend. We each poured it into tulip glasses.

Appearance: Pitch black body with no other colors showing at all. Forms a fairly large, dark khaki creamy/foamy head which retains and laces very well for such a big beer.

Smell: Huge vanilla, chocolate, and coffee notes. Very sweet aroma to be sure, buy with traditional porter notes at the base.

Taste: I love it when beers not only taste great but keep changing up their palate throughout the drinking process. Ballast Point Victory at Sea starts out with a prominent, slightly dry bitterness. Then it turns on a dime into a melange of sweet, syrupy flavors. Iced coffee, vanilla, oak, bourbon and dark chocolate all show up in various stages of the second half. The beer finishes with a strong coffee and slightly roasted malt finale. Its a perfect balance of confectionary sweetness and coffee and hop bitterness. 

As I drink on the palate continues to evolve. Coffee actually takes a back seat to the vanilla and woody flavors. Its not too far removed from rum. These flavors eventually are then superseded by a strong dark chocolate sweetness with slight coffee bitterness. Its all very delectable, especially as a liquid dessert (which is how we drank it). 

Drinkability: Since Ballast Point Victory at Sea is a porter its not surprising it has a smooth, velvety texture and a body thats not quite as sticky and syrupy as its 10% ABV composure might have you believe.  There is no alcohol presence in this brew at all, not even a gentle warmth (although it might explain the rum and woody bourbon cask-like flavors). The only problem? It actually finishes a little too clean! No residual drying effect despite the prominent coffee and dark chocolate bitterness. Thats a flaw I can easily tolerate, though.

Pours a deep dark bown, nearly black, but thinner than it would seem it should be.  There is a small amount of dark tan head that sticks around throughout the drink.  On the palate the beer feels richer than the appearance indicates.  The vanilla flavor is the strongest note on the palate, but the coffee is noticeable as well.  Really tasty stuff.

You wouldnt expect such pleasant sophistication from the accompanying skeleton graphic label on the bottle. But, the frothy tan head and opaque color, not completely jet black though, when poured into a snifter, revealed tantilizing notes of chocolate, smokiness, and carmel. Goes down smotth with little bitter aftertaste. Rather, thr resonance on the palette is pleasant.
I might compare it with Choklat, but Victory has a more studied and merged character that holds well in all areas as an enjoyable delight.

Bottle.  Black with a light-medium light brown head.  Aroma is of roasted malt, strong coffee, cocoa.  Taste is sweet, with more coffee and roasted flavors, bourbon, and just a little vanilla, no alcohol whatsoever.   Roasted bitter finish.  Full bodied, very smooth, incredibly easy to drink for its ABV.
huge roasty vanilla flavor, tons of coffee on nose and vanilla. The vanilla is slightly overwhelming keeping this from the 4s. Although, very very good beer.

If you like Speedway stout, this a simlar version with a slight bit of smoke added. Huge flavor and great finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Old quick review from 2009 - The mixture of coffee and vanilla in this porter is just spot on and the mouthfeel is amazing.  Easily my favorite porter.

Full flavor with solid coffee, vanilla and cigar favors.  Goes down smooth but a tad filling.  12 % catches up quickly.  A great desert beverage or nightcap. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours black with small tan head. Smell of vanilla and caramel. Taste brings more vanilla with hints of coffee and caramel. Slightly boozy.  This is an awesome beer.
Best Porter I have ever had.  Huge vanilla bean nose, huge vanilla bean taste, then a chocolatey, slightly bitter coffee and berry finish.  Unbelievable beer.

This one was in the cellar for a while.  Tasted in late November 2011 from a capped 22oz bomber bottle purchased at Sun Devil quite a while ago.  Pours opaque black with an average brown head that slowly recedes to thin lace.  The nose is predominantly vanilla, along with coffee, dark chocolate, and overall generally darkly roasted malts.  The flavor features the sweeter vanilla and chocolate notes up front, moving to the bitter coffee, and roasted coffee beans.  The body is full and creamy with average carbonation and a long bitter coffee, vanilla, and malty dark chocolate finish.

Thanks to petesuphi for sharing the rest of his bottle with me. One of my all time favorite porters.

A - Pours jet black with a fluffy two finger tall tan head leaving light streaks of lace down the glass.

S - Smells of rich coffee, sweet vanilla and chocolate and the ever present dark roasted malt. This ones nose is absolutely intoxicating.

T - Starts off with a big dose of dark roasted coffee slowly giving way to a nice mix of vanilla and milk chocolate sweetness. The smooth feel really makes this one easy to drink. Finish is a mix of sweetness and dark roast, lignering on the pallet for some time.

M - Heavy body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Smooth feel with a sweet / roasty finish that clings to the pallet. Goes a bit flat at the end of the glass otherwise pretty good.

O - I could drink this every day no problem. The flavors are spot on and the alcohol is all but undetectable. I am glad I picked up a few of these to last the the rest of the year.
Very strong coffee presence with a hint of vanilla. Not too oily with perfect carbonation. This beer is very good at hiding the alcohol taste but leaves a hint that goes well with the roasted coffee.
bottle. pours thin black with medium off white head. aroma of vanilla and coffee. taste is super espresso/coffee with not much vanilla showing up.

Pours dark with a thick creamy head. Leaves good lacings. Vanilla, coffee, and smoke fills the nose. Good body with hints of vanilla followed by burnt toast and coffee. Finishes a little dry. Bourbon version is better, but this could be my daily drinker.

Big coffee flavors and aromas but the vanilla is hardly present. From there it was a pretty standard imperial porter with big malt flavors The coffee lent a pretty nice bitter aftertaste, but it wasnt really balanced. Enjoyable beer nonetheless.

Found this beer to be remarkably appealing and easy to drink. Perfect balance of coffee flavor that does not over power the need to taste something that resembles a "beer". Had on tap in my shop in Wake Forest, NC. Interested in comparing the taste from the bottle.

Poured into a snifter from a 22 ounce bottle un-dated.

A: Beautiful pitch black body with a dense tan head that compliments this perfectly. This beer simply looks amazing.

S: This smells absolutely wonderful, theres a perfect balance of vanilla and fresh roasted coffee here, reminds me a lot of vanilla cake actually with coffee. This is wonderful, my only complaint is wishing it were a tad stronger.

T: Absolutely wonderful, theres bready vanilla flavor into a silky rich cocoa coffee flavor. Its as if Im sipping on a mocha cappuccino with some vanilla flavoring. This is complex, intense, and very easy to drink.

M: Thick and syrupy with light carbonation, this is filling and feels great.

O: This is hands down the best porter Ive ever had, I have no complaint with this and will be buying one every time I find one.

Pours very dark brown, just under black. Dark tan two finger head. Looks yummy! Smells like coffee, roasted malts come through, and a tiny bit of vanilla. Taste like coffee with a splash of irish cream, and bright hops help make it interesting. I am so happy that the vanilla is not overly done, it is there, but not distracting you from the other flavors. You might even over look the vanilla if casually tasting it. But this is such a deliciously good beer, Id hate to know some one if just mindlessly drinking it away. Very enjoyable!
Wow, theres quite a bit of chocolate in this beer I get. Very smooth, doesnt taste as strong as it is. Very tasty.

22oz bottle - Dark tan 2.5 finger head which has good staying power. Really dark, nearly black body. No light shines through. Aroma of a milky coffee latte drink. First flavors of that of strong black coffee rounded off with hints of vanilla. Coffee bitterness lingers on the palate. Perhaps lingers a little too long for my taste. Think the uniqueness comes out of using brewed coffee rather than simply grinding some beans and tossing them in the kettle. Very drinkable as long as you like black coffee. If not, you might want to move along to something else.

Chocolatey aroma with light vanilla notes.  Full bodied chocolatey (with light vanilla notes) and a nice roasty finish that lingers.  Pours black with khaki-colored head that settles.Earlier Rating: 5/9/2010 Total Score: 4.2Roasty dominance with a bit of wood and a light vanilla tone.  Deep brown in color.  Vanilla and char with a caramalt and roast flavor.

Notes: GABF 09

Pours black with a thick, fluffy tan head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, creamy, chalky, dry/ Taste is creamy, chocolate, vanilla, long black coffee finish. Surprisingly simple in its execution; amazing in its delivery. This is one of the best porters Ive ever had the privilege of tasting. If you find it, you must try it.

This is the best imperial Porter Ive tasted. Its big, bold, sweet, and marries the flavors of coffee and vanilla very well. I cant say enough good things about this beer. My only complaint is that all you can tase after this beer is sweet vanilla and coffee.
Bottle shared at Proof.  Black pour.  Coffee and chocolate aroma.  Taste is milk chocolate goodness - tinny vibe.  Really good.
22oz - If somebody asked me to describe porter, I would use this.  Dark but not impenetrably black, lighter body in the glass, roasted notes and a watery, refreshing finish.

22oz bomber poured in a snifter. Pours a solid black almost like used motor oil. Nice creamy tan one finger head. Aromas of espresso, chocolate and a fresh cup of black coffee. Definitely a big coffee flavor upfront. Some cocoa with a slight hint of vanilla in the background. Pretty distinct alcohol in there too. Mouthfeel is slightly oily. Overall this is a great beer. Probably one of the best imperial porters Ive had. If you can find it...pick it up.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2013 On tap at Devil Craft, Shimbashi care of TimE. Black with an off white head and texture is oily. Nose is bold strong black expresso coffee, sweet coffee liqueur like Kahlua or something, definitely an alcoholic kick. Taste is sweet coffee liqueur, bitter roasted coffee, alcoholic. Very nice. Too sweet for some but just right for me. Its a sipper but a nice one. Rerate at Bruces Bday at the Craft. From a 3.9 to a 4.2.
Tap at the brewery.  Black pour.  Aroma of roasted coffee and cocoa powder.   Taste is a ton of cocoa, some roasted flavors, and a little alcohol.  Medium carbonation and body.

Roasty, chocolate, molasses, slight alcohol, wood.  Deep black in color, light tan head, oily lacing on glass.  The flavor is chocolate up front, molasses sweetness, roasted coffee, wood.  Very nice.  Thick in body, oily mouthfeel.  The finish is roast, pine, citrus, alcohol warming.  Excellent.  Equal to its hype.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2014 Had it on tap at Bluepalms then purchased at Bevmo, had to ask for it the folks at Bevmo where hidding this.

Poured into a snifter

A: Pours rich, creamy with a beautiful 2 finger brown head.

S: Vanila, espresso and roasted malts.

T: Let just say this is super flavourful vanilla upfront lots of vanilla followed by coffee and chocolate with some roasted malt. Vanilla took control out of all the other flavors and I liked it.

M: Creamy and thick, heavy mouthfeel with low carbonation and low bitterness in the end. 

O: A dessert beer, so flavorful and creamy very nice. This is my favorite porter.

A porter stronger than most. The flavor really comes out as it gets closer to room temperature. I know this is obvious due to the high abv but the flavor change is even more dramatic than with other strong porters. This beer is smooth considering its high gravity origins. The coffee and vanilla bean add to the flavor. They add to the smoothness and a little complexity. However being a high priced beer it must pass a little extra scrutiny to justify the extra dollars. Well if all that extra cash was for the vanilla and coffee Ild say leave it out. Its good and while the taste is complex it seems to be missing something.

Poured from a bomber into an oversized wine glass.  Some numbers stamped on the neck but I cant figure out the bottled on or best buy date.  Pours with lots of brown frothy head.  Little to no lacing.  Aroma is of alcohol and vanilla with a little bit o coffee.  Mouthfeel is moderate and slightly greasy.  Not much carbonation especially after sitting out a while.  Taste is really, really hot.  Like sniffing rubbing alcohol. Other flavors are vanilla extract and coffee.  This could have been a very good beer.  All the parts are there but its way too hot and has this artificial vanilla flavor to it.  As of now, its just decent with a very good aroma.

Bomber. Black as the depths of the ocean in appearance with a half-inch of cappuccino foam. Very strong dark roast coffee and espresso notes in the aroma along with a touch of vanilla bean and bittersweet chocolate. The taste is much the same with a strong emphasis on roasted malt, coffee and vanilla flavors in addition to some dark chocolate and rum in the background. Mouthfeel is full-bodied, creamy and slightly viscous with just the right amount of carbonation and alcohol. Overall, its a seamless blend of coffee, vanilla and booze that improves with each sip.
(bottle) black with tan head. Aroma of roast malt with hints of vanilla, lots of coffee. Flavor is overwhelmingly coffee, some roast malt and hints of vanilla.

Bottle from mashmaster.  Thanks Tom!!  Aroma has notes of vanilla, roasted malts, espresso, dark chocolate, caramel and some hidden citrus hops.  Very dark brown hue that sits black in the glass.  Very small tan head that almost completely diminished and left little lace.  Palate is full bodied with average carbonation.  Overall a very nice imp porter.  Loved the nose and the flavor but would have liked the carbonation to be a little more subdude and the head to be a little more pronounced.  Enjoyed it.

I thought this was really good.  A little smoother than their imperial stout, and a little thicker too.  Dark, roasty, not too hoppy and improves as it warms.  Lots of chocolate in the palate, and pretty sweet as well.  Note: I had aged this one about a year.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2012 Simply one of the best out there. As expected the nose is dominated by fresh roasted coffee, a dash of herb-like woodiness and the subtle presence of vanilla. Pours black with some brown hues if held to the light. Off-white foam bordering on a light tan. Taste matches the aromas. Up front there is a lively dose of roasted coffee with a dash of chocolate. The coffee really livens up your palate. The finish is full of dark chocolates and earthy hops which balance this beer nicely. Feels like a porter should on the palate. Full bodied but not syrupy, nice carbonation. Get your hands on this, it is amazing. One of my favorite beers.

2 dec 2011, bottle. Black and clear. It is a black coffee with some sweet element that I wouldnt have said vanilla without reading the bottle. Med creamy body and moderately fizzy. Much sweeter to taste. Definite vanilla notes. Biggest flavour is certainly black coffee but the vanilla and a bourbon cask certainly sweeten the coffee bitterness. Really nice
Pours an opaque black color with a soapy tan head.  Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, and vanilla.  Coffee flavor upfront with a sweet vanilla ending.  Very nice porter with a great body!
Skyview V, 11/11/11.  Courtesy of Footbalm.  Black color with a small head.  Aroma of vanilla and coffee.  Sweet vanilla and sugar flavor.  Malty and chocolatey.

Bottle thanks to Sean. Pours a dark brown with a brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has lots of coffee notes with some roasted malts and dark grain. Flavor begins full of coffee with roasted malts and a hint of sweet chocOlate.

Location/Date: November 2011 ratings catchup, split bottle with Dave.
Appearance: Pours opaque black with red head.
Aroma: Aroma of coffee, sweet and maltiness.
Taste: Similar to aroma, coffee, malt, some bitterness, sweet.
Palate: Medium body.
Summary: I really like porters, and really enjoyed this beer. Thanks Dave!
Pours dark chocolate black with a nice brown head. Aroma is intense coffee, dark chocolate, and roasted barley. The taste is thick and rich, alcoholic, very strong for a porter. Very good.

Pours a jet black color with a short lived dark brown head.The aroma was of roasted malt,coffee,cocoa and vanilla.The flavor was of roasted malt,coffee with vanilla.The body was full with a bitter coffee aftertaste.Overall a very good beer from Ballast point.

This is a beauty!  Pours very dark with a light brown head with nice retention.
Lacing all the way down as you sip and savor.....balancing rich coffee,creamy vanilla and BIG porter roastiness.  Finishes earthy, resinous hops, and mildly sweet and ashen.  Imperial indeed!

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2012 Date: November 11, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: MN Gathering @ Skyview V Dark brown pour, roasted chocolate and coffee, some bourbon and vanilla as well.

December 21, 2012 - got a bottle from Joe.  Dark brown pour with nice head that lasted.  Moved appearance to a 5, but kept everything else the same.  The alcohol is present, just not the bourbon I mentioned in my initial rating.
On tap at Barley and Hops Great full body. Aroma of vanilla, bourbon and roast chocolate. Smooth and easy to drink

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2013 Bottle at MN Gathering @ Skyview V. Super dark brown pour with small soapy head. Aroma of rich oak and mild coffee. Medium slick palate. Taste is oak, bourbon, and roast. Awesome.
Nice dark body.  Suprisingly non-offensive aroma for a coffee beer.  Soy, sugar, malt, and the barest trace of coffee.  The body  is rather harsh.  I can barely taste the beer over the coffey.

22oz bottle.  Pours almost completely opaque with creamy brown head that leaves lots of patches throughout.  Aroma is coffee and strong alcohol early, but mellows to feature a lot of chocolate and vanilla with some nutmeg.  Very creamy; taste is, predictably, coffee and vanilla with lots of alcohol warming.  Roasty, boozy finish.  This one caught me off guard, I really wasnt expecting it to be as good as this.

On firkin at Toronado. Black with a creamy light brown head. Big vanilla bean chocolate and coffee aroma and taste with a dry bitter finish. Earlier Rating: 1/22/2008 Total Score: 4ON tap at Stone.  Ruby brown with a creamy tan head.  Coffee, chocolate, and caramel aroma.  Rich bitter dark chocolate and espresso taste.

The vanilla is well balanced with the earthy bitterness of a great Imperial Porter. Cant wait to get my hands on more later this month! Releases seasonally, and I can never seem to make my stash last all year. One of San Diegos gems!

Ive been waiting to open this one for a while, and Ive finally found the right time: Alone in my apartment, during the weekend.

So.

Poured into a NoVA Beerfest tasting glass, because I can.

The smell comes out of the bottle as vanilla and coffee. From the glass, vanilla and cocoa. This is a recipe for a beer that panders to me.

Appearance: Dark with very little head, which was slightly off-white. Dark means mostly opaque by the way.

Taste: Oh dang. Vanilla, some coffee, but whats also apparent is the hops bitterness, which I wasnt expecting. Huh. A slight roastiness comes through, which fades into an absolutely amazing cocoa/vanilla dream.
As for the palate, I actually took another sip of this one just so I could feel it again. Its smooth, medium/light carbonation, and a roast cocoa taste that just lingers forever.

Overall, I have to say this is probably the 2nd best beer Ive had in the last 4 or so months. Wonderful!

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2013 Nice and dark, medium thin head with a little lacing.  Mostly vanilla on nose.  Taste was full on vanilla, then chocolate, then a long coffee finish.  Really cool progression and full bodied beer.  Terrific beer.

>>>Rerate:  On cask at Blind Tiger, NYC.  Amazing creamy rich vanilla and semisweet chocolate.  Like a liquid desert.  Incredible.
Pour black with nice head and lacing. Nose is coffee and black malt. First sip is espresso, molasses, roasted malt. Finish is oak and dry hops. Very little vanilla. Very nice beer.

Bottle, from trade. Pours a tar black body with a small creamy khaki-hued head. Nose is strong filter coffee, milk chocolate, cocoa, nougat, creamy nutty tones and hints of deep malts. Taste is much like a mocha cake, with lots of filtered coffee, mocha, coffee liqueur (like Kalhua) and hints of cocoa and vanilla. Well-hidden alcohol. Reminds me a lot of Haandbryggeriet Costa Rica, actually. A solid coffee porter, which isnt really my style but this beer still deserves props for its flawless execution.

Bottle at Chris Os Pre-GBBF Shindig 2011. Dark brown color. Very aromatic coffee and chocolate in the aroma. Roasty flavor with chocolate, coffee and nuts. Warming with a bit of alcohol sharpness. Lots of coffee and chocolate in good balance.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 An exceptional brew that blew my mind... it was an unexpected treat that involved me asking the bartender "what the hell style is that beer" to which she responded "i have no idea, let check it out" ... poured to sampler glasses... i took one swig and said "yeah, uhh... ill take a full glass please"

A: Dark brown/black body.. moderate khaki head.. nice coating on the glass.

S: Bam! Vanilla. Bourbon. Chocalate. Roasted Coffee. Rich caramel. Slight oak. Booze. Cola.

T: Yeah it tasted like the nose! A frigging smörgåsbord of incredible flavors. Blended to perfection. Each flavor popped yet didnt drown out the others. At 12+ the booze was present in a way which accentuated the flavors rather that killing the tastebuds.

M: Medium-heavy on the palate. Good finish. Nice carbonation. Delicate for such a big beer.

D: Something about porters make me struggle... but this one was rather remarkable...

Sample on Day 2 of the Aces & Ales Strong Beer Festival on 08/13/2011. Pours black with a medium rocky beige head that burns away slowly. Rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of espresso, vanilla and dark chocolate. Medium to full body with flavors of roasted coffee, charred malt, vanilla/chocolate and hops. The finish is roasty with a vanilla mocha aftertaste. Enjoyable beer all around.

Poured a dark black, with little tan head.  Aromas of chocolate, vanilla, and a niice bouquet of coffee/espresso.  Taste like the aroma, but coffee is not overpowing, and has a nice booze flavor as the beer warms up.

660ml bottle (ChrisO Pre-GBBF2011 "Donkey Dork Lord" Shindig)
Chocolate orange aroma, lots of vanilla. Super soft and smooth, but also with pleasnt carbonation. Super rich chocolate orange taste. Massive retronasals. Quite tingly finish. Covers 10% well. Great stout.

Bomber.  Black onyx pour with a short deep brown head and lots of lacing.  Strong aroma of freshly roasted coffee.  Plenty more coffee in the flavor along with dark chocolate, butterscotch, caramel and vanilla.   Full body and a sweet, flavorful, slightly bitter finish.  Excellent porter.

Bottle at chrisos Pre-GBBF Shindig 11. It pours opaque black, with a thin beige head. The nose is medicinal, vanilla, chocolate milk and dark chocolate. The taste is medicinal, coffee, vanilla, chocolate, roasted malt, herbal and jagermeister, with alcohol warmth in the finish. Full body and medium carbonation.

Rich dark brown/black color; Medium to heavy creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, rich chocolate, & vanilla; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, dark chocolate, espresso, vanilla, hops, and some caramel; The alcohol is well hidden; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, this is a meal - excellent porter.

Pours a deep dark brown, almost black, with thick tan head.  Smells of coffee,chocolate, and roastiness with notes of vanilla.  Taste is mild bitter with some sweetness.  Alcohol is hidden well.  Palate is full bodied and a little sticky and smooth.  Overall, a nice porter, well balanced and I like how it is not too sweet.
At Chriso Pre Gbbf 2011.  Lovely black beer.  Intense dark choc some coconut but the intense choc is lovely.  Really good beer.

Brown with a small tan head.  Aroma of sweet coffee and chocolate.  Coffee hits the palate first, followed vanilla sweetness and milk chocolate.  Medium body and appropriate carbonation.  I wanted more body on this beer.  I would have liked this better if it was an imperial stout with coffee and vanilla.

RBSG 2010 on the bus. Dark brown brew with a decent brown cap and speckles. The chocolate aroma is just plain old stupid - so much rich chocolate! Cream, vanilla, weak raspberry and some stiff yet smooth coffee. The flavour is not a let down either - its huge all around. Burnt things, incredible chocolate, loads of roasted malts, a little bit of coffee, slight alcohol vanilla and a never ending finish. Silky smooth liquid oozed into my liver. Awesome.

Pours thick black with nice creamy tan head, aroma has notes of bitter coffee grounds, some chocolate, cookie, some milk sugar with notes of chocolate, vanilla as well.  Taste is nice balanced coffee and chocolate, slighting more towards the coffee, with a nice malty backbone with a nice bitter dry finish.  Delicious, delicious dessert beer.

Pours a dark brown color with a tan head. Has a vanilla, coffee smell to it. It sort of taste like a chocolate chip cookie with some vanilla and coffee mixed in. Im not a huge porter guy but this one I liked.
Robust earthy tones with a sharp malt aroma. Black color with a small tan head. Sweet beginning with a light pine bitter middle fading lightly in the finish.

Pours deep and dark but not opaquely brown with a lasting, medium sized tan head.  Initial aromas of coffee and earthy hops.  Vanilla is distinct, but in the background; also some light tinges of alcohol.  It also has some caramelly and brown sugar aromas with a touch of espresso and burnt character.  Very smooth and creamy mouthfeel and flavor up front, which leads to a dry and roasted, almost burnt flavor at the finish and aftertaste, but it is restrained from being overly acrid.  Toasted and roasted flavor with caramel and vanilla mid palate.  Very clean fermentatoin for the most part.  A touch of dark fruit character from a bit of age, not from the fermentation process.  The finish is dry from the combination of perceived bitterness and dark malt character.  The mouthfeel starts out smooth and creamy, but finishes on the dry side from malts and alcohol, which is very well hidden.  Fuller medium body; lower medium level of carbonation.  Overall a very, very well made beer!  The vanilla and coffee compliment the base beer, rather than overwhelm it.  I wish I had more than one bottle, and I should have saved this one to share with others...

your head weights about 10 lbs .. . Pours a deep plum brown, medium foam, sticky lacing .. . lots of vanilla and roast, some tar, coffee grounds, and a chestnut after christmas .. . i enjoyed this quite a bit but one was enough .. . and Ill leave you with what we all came here to see: hardcore nudity!

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2013 Completely opaque black with chunky brown head resembling the moons surface. Chocolate, vanilla and coffee are married well and prominent - slightly more vanilla than the others. Dense, dark flavors coat every part of the mouth. Chocolate and coffee more pronounced now than the vanilla. Deeper complex flavors than expected from the aroma.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2011 I got this from an in person trade with Boxcar  (BA).  I really owe him for this one.  This beer completely kicks ass.  This is the best combo of vanilla and coffee that Ive ever tasted in a beer.  Lots of cocoa as well. Extremely smooth, balanced, and full bodied.  And its almost immoral how easy this is to drink at 10% ABV.  Great stuff.

Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark black color with a large foamy orange-brown head that lingered and left good lacing. The aroma was strong coffee followed by light cocoa and vanilla and with a toasty and roasty malt undertone throughout. The flavor was strong coffee and moderate notes of toasted marshmallow, cocoa, and vanilla with moderate floral hops underneath. The finish was very long. Fairly full bodied and creamy in body. Excellent.

22 oz bottle. Dark brown with a creamy light tan head that sticks to the glass. Aroma is heavy milk  chocolate with some coffee and vanilla. The flavor is rich chocolate malt with lots of roasty coffee and a light vanilla/alcohol heat at the end. Full body with average to low carbonation and a smooth, creamy mouth feel. Great beer, had this super fresh and I have to say it tastes better with about 9 months on it.

Its poured into my nonic pint glass and it arrives a pitch black color.  There is a maybe one finger light brown head that sits on top.

The nose gives me a lot of cocoa and vanilla.  Im surprised not to get any real coffee aromas in this.  So far so good in my book.

The taste is a lot of the same cocoa and vanilla flavors but it does make way for a mild coffee taste.  More roasted malt character in there as well.  A creamy body makes this not feel thin and watered down.

Dark brown pour, minimal head. Smell is coffee and vanilla. Ditto for the taste, with a decent amount of roast as well. Slightly sweet, but not too much. Medium mouthfeel, as expected for a porter. Very good brew for the style.

Bomber split with sherm1016....thanks!  Pours dark brown...almost black.  Nose is sweet with a little bitter coffee hint.  Taste is a good balance of the sweet vanilla balanced with the more bitter coffee....would be too sweet without the coffee...very well done....wish we could get this around here.

22oz bottle in trade with Dankbeers619, split with dwm1034.  Pours a dark brown with a tan head that quickly recedes.  Aroma is sweet, vanilla, a little roasty.  A little heavy on the palate with light carbonation. Flavor is sweet and bitter, vanilla, coffee, roasted malt.  Very balanced and very tasty.

One of the best beers Ive ever tasted, Its full bodied and strong, good bubble retention on the tongue, the cold drip coffee character is amazing and the vanilla is subtle and just right, defiantly a beer designed for long, cold, lonely nights at sea.

The aroma is all coffee, and the smell grows as you pour the beer into a pint.  Some chocolate, but mainly strong, black java.  Looks black as Satans heart, with a head as brown as Satans molars (I assume he smokes heavily.)  Tastes divine, a vanilla latte of a beer that integrates coffee and vanilla perfectly into the thick, dark depths of an Imperial Porter.  Creamy as a milkshake but  without cloying sweetness, this beer will put many a RIS to shame.  (3/20/09)
Wow is this good!  Very dark brown and appetizing as can be.  Rich everything here.  Malted out the ying yang.  Coffee, espresso, dark fruit, vanilla, etc.  This is good!

Black color with dark tan beige color with touch of red. Espresso like aroma with strong vanilla notes. Extremely creamy texture with a strong and wonderful coffee flavor and followed by some oaky vanilla and mellow tobacco.  Was saving this for a special occasion and today is one. Go America!!!

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2012 Bottle ----> Highball glass. The thin head leaves the glass into thin, yet fine lacing. This beer poured thick and VERY dark, maybe the darkest Ive seen yet. The aroma was pleasant and thick on the nose. First sniff picked up notes of rich dark chocolate, followed by light spiciness - the tip of that scent being fresh coffee and otherwise, roasted malts and a hint of vanilla. The carbonation level was perfect, making this bounty of fresh flavors seem creamy even. The flavor was very balanced, offering the bitterness of roasted malts with a nice splash of sweet cocoa nibs. This is one beer I look forward to trying, as of now I am a fan of  Ballast Point brews!

Bottle Wavers1 thank you greatly. Pour thick dark brown/black great brown caramel head with outstanding lacing. Aroma coffee, vanilla, chocolate, cocoa, like hot chocolate on a winter night. Taste like drinking melted chocolate bars, rich, roasty, dark/milk chocolate, cocoa, coffee, vanilla, caramel, hints of bitterness. MF smooth super silky creamy full body very faint carb. So rich and decedent very very good exactly what description describes and it is also scary balanced. Could drink this all the time everyday one of the best beers Ive had.

Shared bottle with Madvike.  Thanks Matt!  From the sounds of this it is everything that I want in a beer.  Aroma is vanilla and coffee.  Unfortunately the aroma is better than the taste.  All the flavors are there but nothing seems to blend well together.  The only thing that truly sticks out is coffee grounds.  A let down for what I expected...

Bottle from peteinSD...thanks man! - Pours deep black with a thin tan head. Lots of sweet vanilla with smooth, muted coffee, dark roast, and a bit of sharp heat. Taste is very dark burnt roast, vanilla, a touch of coffee. Finish is pretty bitter coffee, with vanilla creme and a bit of lactose. Honestly this sounds and smells better than it tastes. Its rich and decadent, but I couldnt drink too much of this.

I didnt much care for the creepy drawing of the skeleton on the label.  Why do so many breweries put these unappetizing picture on their labels?  The label also talks about joining forces to conquer your palate - and it does that!  Black pour with a foamy head that drops pretty quickly.  Dark bread and a good shot of coffee in the aroma, a little yeast too.  The flavor is simply great.  What a delicious beer!   Prominent coffee, vanilla, chocoloate, caramel, some acidity, a fair amount of sweetness.  A wonderful, subtle interplay of flavors happens here, yet everything is balanced and smooth.  This goes into my little collection of elite brews for sure.
Cask at Get Real NY. Dark brown, aroma is coffee, vanilla, bitter chocolate, lots of malt. Taste is bitter, coffee. Would like to try again.

Bottle courtesy of Styles. Pours opaque brown/black. Aromas of vanilla, and coffee with hints of chocolate. Body is medium light. Flavor is chocolaty coffee with hints of vanilla. Very smooth, and dessert-like. A little on the sweet side.
Dark brown, no head, spotty lacing. Aroma is dominated by vanilla extract, light chocolate. Flavor again dominated by vanilla, not much else. Not my thing.
Pitch black with a brown head. Vanilla, coffee, chocolate and fusels in the a powerful and potent mix. Easy to drink though, but very powerful. Great beer!

Bottle: Poured a pitch-black color stout with a thick dark brown foamy head with good retention and some very nice lacing. Aroma of aromatic coffee and light astringent note is more dominant at first then anticipated. Taste is also a nice mix between some dry roasted malt with dominant notes of aromatic coffee and with a dry finish. Body is quite full with a thick body and a creamy texture with good carbonation and no apparent alcohol. Very well brewed with loads of complexity while still sustaining a good drinkability factor.

Excellent dark beer with a creamy thick head.  Pours very dark and instantly aromas of vanilla, chocolate, coffee and booze.  After drinking so many imperial stouts, an imperial porter is a nice change.  Excellent flavor.  Impressed overall.

Appearance: blacks and burnt browns. Dark khaki head fades into a solid collar bordering a thin film. Swirls with crema lace.

Nose:  coffee and vanilla up front and center. Rich fudge in the back. Brownies with dates. Black earth. Chewy and creamy. Burnt molasses underneath and along the edges. Whole vanilla beans with a touch of heavy cream; cooked cream. Black fudge cookies and dark chocolates. Undertone of dry dense European chocolates. Vanilla weaves through everything while coffee is more subtle.

Palate: creamy, frothy, and cakey. Long fudge and coffee, espresso especially, and whole vanilla bean finish  burnt and roasty, dry. Dark fruit meat in the back and sides of each swallow while the tang of dates sits squarely on the top middle of tongue. Vanilla bean root weaves in and out just like nose. Burnt, ashy, tarry underbelly offers solid support. Moist along the sides and dry along the top. Faint black earth. Lovely as it warms up. Slightly oily mouthfeel. Cocoa coated black cherries; dry earthy tannins of stones. Meaty prunes and figs.

Final Thoughts: amazingly complex and delicious drinkable. The interplay of flavors is like a professional orchestra in terms of direction and purpose and fluidity. The more Ballast Point I taste, the more I love their brewing prowess.

Pours a solid black with a thinnish mocha head that sticks around for a bit. Smells of coffee right off, layers of vanilla, milk chocolate, and roasted grain hidden in there as well. Taste is like a half and half milkshake. Lots of milk chocolate and vanilla mix up front followed by some coffee and a lingering roasted coffee and chocolate finish. Full bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and light carbonation. Great Porter, maybe a bit on the sweet side, but certainly very tasty. Call it a desert porter.
UPDATED: SEP 8, 2013 Finally had a bottle of this that clicked with me, really nice coffee aroma, thick silky mouthfeel, not too sweet, a bit boozy but very good overall beer.
UPDATED: JUN 23, 2012 Had this again and re-rating it and giving it a higher rating. Nice almost woody flavor, the cocoa and the coffee are both big, nice vanilla notes.
