Pours a heinous black color with a fading tan head and lasting ring. Burly bittered dry aromas with a strong coffee and boozy vibe.  Slight vanilla and chocolate scents are the top slice of a layered and deep bouquet.  Spent coffee and chocolate flavors are present as well as a pronounced bittered piney backbone that strikes down the palate. The rounded flavors emerge to elicit some fruited slightly souring sparkled notes to reveal a lasting drying finish.  Very ncie

Ballast Point
Victory at Sea Porter
Pours black with a medium tan head and ok retention. A little oily in appearance. Aroma is notes of roasted nuts, wood and vanilla. Mild coffee on the nose. Flavor is roasted malts with a smooth vanilla finish. Mild booze. Nice and drinkable.
22oz bottle. Pours dark black, tan head.  Great chocolate/coffee roast aroma. Taste is a bit too vanilla, slightly sweet aftertaste

A little too sweet for my taste, but have to give props where props are due.  Tremendous coffee and semi-sweet chocolate aroma.  Mouthfeel is velvety smooth.  10% abv is well hidden.  A top notch brew.

Obviously an extremely good beer but not to my taste - the vanilla charicter seemed a little overwhelming which made it seem slightly artifical and the chocolate was too sweet for the beer to be ballanced.

Poured into a pint glass. Big thanks to Khazadum for this. 

4.0 A: Pours a black color. Two fingers of light brown creamy/frothy hybrid head. Average retention and some lacing. Good enough.

4.5 S: Not surprisingly the strongest aromas are coffee and vanilla. Sweetness gives the illusion of coffee with cream. Plenty of toastiness, with some roastiness as well, some grainy malts, semisweet chocolate, and caramel. Very nice.

4.5 T: Tastes a lot like the nose which is a cup of strong coffee with vanilla cream. The bitterness seems to come from mostly the coffee and its moderate strength at best. Again, roasty and toasty, grainy, caramel and toffee, and quite tasty. Booze is hidden well.

4.5 M: Heavier medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Super creamy and smooth. Nearly perfect. 

5.0 D: This one drinks well from start to finish. Flavor is great as is the mouthfeel and this doenst seem like its 10%. Good beer overall and easily the best Ive had from BP. Sculpin doesnt even come close.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-01-2011 01:33:30
Huge chocolate with cocoa dominate taste. Having a hard time distinguishing this from an imperial stout. Good job.
Sweet caramel taste going down with roasted coffee notes that linger on the tongue.
Chocolate fudge with marshmallows, man. Smells like it, taste like it. Maybe some Baileys, too. Perhaps a little bit of bitterness in the finish, but mostly sweet and heavy. Good Stuff...

Draft at Barleys Taproom in Asheville NC. Jet black beer with a thin tan head. Scent is sweet/roasted malt and massive amount of chocolate. Taste is coffee and loads of chocolate. Into chocolate? Go for it.....

Bottle.  A solid black color with a rich foamy brown head.  Loads of vanilla and toasted malts, chocolate, and coffee in the aroma.  Rich and full bodied with vanilla, warming alcohol, and coffee pouring through.

Bottle split with linh, Vi, and Thi for Chinese new year. Pours pitch black body with thin off white lacing. Aroma is sweet vanilla, coffee, and mild roast. Mouthfeel is very well balanced with notes of vanilla, wood, alcohol sharpness, and coffee, but also a great dose of fresh, bitter hops.

Poured stout black into my tulip glass with a dark khaki head with a thin lacing.   The smell is amazing, up front loads of coffee, chocolate roasted malts, and a subtle vanilla.   Cant stop inhaling it to the point some almost went up my nose.  Id like to chop it up and take one Steve-o style but my better judgement got the best of me this time.  Its a sneaky beer in my eyes it tastes exactly how it smells and in that order.  Its a silky smooth texture with great after taste with a slight hint of alcohol (but barely).   Definitely not sludge like a stout but delightful feel for a porter.  This is an awesome beer and only wish they would they would release one with real vanilla bean and not just flavoring and set it in bourbon barrels for a few months.  Then it would be the perfect imperial porter in my eyes.  I might have marked it a bit high on the points but I attribute that to the skeleton parrot on the label ;)

Bottle; Pour is Dark Brown/Black with a frothy tan head. Terrific Roasted coffee bean nose - Bitterness is present up front - It does bite the tongue - Coffee beans and vanilla mesh with cocoa and brown sugar. An earthy quality takes form - Incredible logo, btw . Anyway - this brew is fantastic.

Pours a black coffee brown with a creamy lacy head. Coffee nose, with brown sugar, vanilla, hint of chocolate and alcohol. Taste is coffee, brown sugar, vanilla, hoppy bitterness, and chocolate. Finish of coffee, and bitter hops. Overall a stellar beer.

Wall-to-wall black with a creamy beige head. Some coffee black shades show up on the edges when swirled in the glass. Some lacing. Vanilla beans, creamy chocolate, roasted malt and fruity coffee. Theres a lot of good stuff going on. Some booze heat in this fresh bottle. Starts sweet like a chocolate milkshake and transitions to a bitter note combining roast and coffee. The finish is nicely bitter and sticks with you for awhile. Creamy, thick and wonderful. Some booze burn in the finish.
Pours black with medium sized tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, coffee, vanilla and roastyness.  Taste is like chocolate milk, exceptionally smooth.  Warming finish.  Exceptional.

Bottle: &nbsp Nearly black, looks like an Imperial Stout, thin foamy dark beige head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Absolutely wonderful aroma of coffee, rich roasted malts, vanilla, and graham cracker. &nbsp This smells great! &nbsp Warming up front, coffee, vanilla bean, some dark chocolate, roasted malts, a little marshmallow and graham cracker. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp Not as heavy as I would have hoped. &nbsp Lingering roasted malts, dark chocolate, and a bit of heat. &nbsp The aroma is great, and is a bit more interesting than the taste. &nbsp Regardless, great beer! &nbsp Could have used a bit more vanilla or at least sweetness on the backside. &nbsp Did have a mild bitterness that lingers... needing some more vanilla me thinks. &nbsp Otherwise good stuff. &nbsp Thanks Ron for the bottle!

Bottle. Moderate malt notes of toasted, dark chocolate and coffee with cream, light hops and yeast aromas of resin and earth, with background notes or toffee, charcoal and a big hit of vanilla. Head is average size, frothy turning creamy, light brown with fair lacing and good legs and is mostly diminishing. Color is very dark brown, almost black. Flavor starts lightly to moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly sweet and acidic and moderately to heavily bitter. Palate is on the fuller side of medium, creamy with a soft carbonation and a moderately alcoholic, and lightly dry yet sticky finish. Mouth-filling with tons of flavor and essence to go with a perfect palate, the vanilla really stands out in this Imperial Porter.

bottle from Sams Quik Stop. Great aroma, Malty, vanilla, coffee, chocolate. Blackish Brown color, great head and good lace. Sweet bitter flavor. Thick Body, smooth oily mouthfeel, bitter dry finish. Damn, thats tasty, great vanilla and coffee mix. Wonderful.....the whole thing was great
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text:
On tap at Small Bar, San Diego.

Aroma: Roasty, chocolate, coffee.

Appearance: Black pour, light tan head, good lacing.

Taste: Chocolate, roasted coffee, vanilla, malty, hint of alcohol, nicely bitter finish.

Palate: Medium-full satisfying mouthfeel.

Overall: Excellent, very flavorful, good depth, lots of character.

Great aroma of chocolate and roasted malts.  Perfect color with a great tan head that lingers and leaves nice lacing on the glass.  Taste is very bitter chocolate with a strong coffee presenceand the alcohol is well hidden at first but is more noticable the more you drink.  Medium-bodied palate.  This is a pretty good porter.

Dark dark brown, almost black, viscous, smaller head... Loads of coffee, mild dark fruits, some vanilla, a little roast, very very complex... Very nice flavor, roast, vanilla, coffee, cream, some subtle fruits... Medium to medium full bodied, lingering vanilla with a little slickness, creamy... Excellent...

Fantastic coffee brew! Pours black with creamy tan head.  Aroma is strong coffee.  Taste is coffee, chocolate and vanillla.  Rather bubbly on the tongue for a porter, but very nice nonetheless.  Havent sampled many from BP, but this one is fantastic.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2011 First Sculpin, now this fine IP.  Pours deep dark brown with a caramel colored soapy head.  Has an aroma of roasted coffee, caramel and the perfect amount of vanilla to round it all out.  Has a sweet chocolaty taste with that coffee bit and bitter hit, with nice vanilla notes through the finish.  You are left with some coffee notes as well.  Medium mouthfeel.  Damn tasty.  If you love coffee beers this will send you flying.

Dark pour, small beige head, that doesnt stay around for too long, but laces decently. The smell is sweeter than I would expect. Coffee tones and roasted malts. Sweetness must be from the vanilla. Taste is coffee forward, with the vanilla coming up after. Dry aftertaste, the coffee sticks around for a while. Full bodied and creamy, which I didnt expect. My last Vanilla porter was way too watery for me, this really surprised me in a good way. I didnt want to put this down. Really, really good. I want another one already.

22oz at Toad in the Hole in Goose Island stem. Jet black with medium tan head. Big chocolate aroma fronts a few roasty and lactic notes. Vanilla quickly presents as the dominant flavor, but gentle chocolate and spiky caffeine are there in quantity too. Medium body does not betray its hugeness. This is a beer whose descriptors read more like a maduro cigar.
there is a soapy and a overly burnt flavor that lacks for this to be something that is outstanding. the flavor does have interesting flavor of coca malts and some wood and other flavors. not too bad

The aroma is very toasted with coffee, vanilla, and alcohol. The appearance is dark brown with a tan head. The taste is like the aroma with an over burnt acidic coffee taste. The palate is smooth. Overall its a decent beer but I dont like the burnt coffee thing.

Bottle - pours a very dark near black color with a smallish tan head. Usual porter aromas of coffee and vanilla. Flavors of coffee, vanilla, licorice. More carbonation than expected, but not much on a relative scale. Alcohol is very apparent, and it finishes with a tad bitter-slightly hoppy finish. Good porter, but mildly disappointed  after reading all the reviews. I enjoy less alcoholly, not as bitter finishing porters... Maybe a touch too "imperial" for my taste.

50cl bottle stolen off eBay since someone closed out an auction early New Years morning. Pours a rich, dark chocolate brown with a small, foamy brown head. Nice lacing and alcohol on the glass sides. Pretty nice aroma of vanilla, chocolate, cold espresso and green hops. Pretty creamy mouthfeel. The coffee really picks it up in the flavor with just a hint of the vanilla. Nice though because neither flavor seems "forced" or like an additive. Tasty and absolutely no hint of the 10ABV.

Bomber shared with a friend. What an amazing beer this is! Huge roasted coffee oak and rye aroma; dark dark brown. The taste is enormous with sweet grains that make us want to pull the grains out and make a rye or pumpernickel bread. The palate is just creamy silk and velvet, incredible. 
An overall GREAT beer. I LOVE this!!!!

Poured from the bottle into a goblet, nice aroma of coffee and chocolate. The appearance is somewhat of a hazy-black color, with a minimal head. The taste is sweet and bitter, with a smooth coffee-like aftertaste. The beer is pleasing to the palate and has a lot of different flavors... i.e.  vanilla, roasted nuts, coffee, chocolate.

Black pour with a decent beige head.  Good lace, ok retention.  Beautiful aromas of fresh coffee, creamy milk chocolate, sweet vanilla and some roasted dark malts.  Big coffee presence throughout, light vanilla, almost like chewing coffee grounds bitter finish.  The finish was smoothed a bit by the sweetness from the vanilla.  Hints of booze in there too.  Smooth creamy mouth, light carbonation.  Fantastic stuff, a top in the style for sure.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2011 bottle at Hashigo Zake --


Oh yea, coffeee and vanilla, this is a dessert drink; -- 

dark brown and opaque, very dark brown frothy head and heavy lacing; -- 

this is slightly sweet but heavy giving the sweetness a pronounced character, it has a mild bitterness and hints of sourness and salt giving it a very rounded flavour; -- 

full body, big body, thick and creamy texture, carbonated without being overdone - a nice zing, big finish long and bitter and coffee and vanilla; -- 

Does not disappoint, this is a really exceptional beer. But you would not want to drink three or four in a row -- it is rich. If there is a beer liqueur, this has to be one of them.

Bottle pours deep brown/black with a khaki head.  Aroma is jam packed with goodness showing notes of chocolate, vanilla, smoke, roasted malt, coffee, and campfire marshmallows.  Flavor shows the same.  Overall body is moderate to full, viscous, and finishes with a nice dark chocolate/roasted malt bitterness.

In short: An over-the-top vanilla and cacao lovefest.  Good but a bit too much
How: Bottle 22oz.  Consumed when about 1 year of old.  Sent to me by nbutler11.  Thanks a lot Nick.
The look: Near black body topped by a small tan head
In long: Intense nose of cacao, vanilla and burnt malts.  That nose is really intense.  Taste is even more intense, too much so.  A ton of vanilla, a lot of cacao, caramel, roastiness, marshmallows, a cup black coffee, dark liquorice, booze.  Alcohol is rather apparent.  For the first half of my bottle I thought this beer was very good.  But during the second half of the bottle the vanilla and marshmallows were getting a bit too much for me.  Cloyingly sweet too.  I am no wimp and I can (and do) drink bombers of big imperial stouts on a regular basis.  Dark Lord at 15%?  Bring it on baby.  But the Victory At Sea is a beer that can only be enjoyed in small quantities.  And because of that my score is not very high.  Im not sure what they name the beer after but we can probably rule out the Iraq Occupation.
Poured black with white head that faded quicklysmelled sweet smokey coffee and vanilla tasted about the same

From a 22oz. bomber. Pours deep place with a thin tan head which quickly dissapears. Smells of vanilla, oak and coffee. Tastes nutty with carmel and some roastiness with a nice hoppy back bite. Very easy to drink. Really good on cold winer day.

Bomber about a year old poured a clear dark reddish brown with a lasting tan head with great lacing. Aromas of milk chocolate, vanilla, light roastiness, light coffee and light carmel. Palate was medium to full bodied and smooth. Flavors of milk chocolate, vanilla, mocha, light roastiness, light carmel and a hint of coffee with a smooth lingering milk chocolate finish.

12/11/10.  Bomber courtesy daknole!  Opaque black pour with a thick caramel brown head that fades to a film fast with plenty of lacing.  Huge coffee aroma with dark chocolate, sweet vanilla, a bit of caramel, and a touch of booziness.  Awesome flavor that leans more towards sweet vanilla that balances better with the coffee than the aroma did... really tasty!

22oz bottle, purchased at Papago Brewing. Pours a deep, cola-brown color with a reddish tinge; slight, fine-bubbled, light-tan head with decent lacing and retention. Solid, chocolatey and dark roasted malts in the aroma; light notes of ash and bitter chocolate; some modest red fruit notes; basic, but solid and enjoyable imperial stout aroma. Medium-full body; modest carbonation; minimal alcohol showing through, well-integrated as a vinous component; lots of darker chocolate and roasted malts, cola and some modest touches of caramel and hints of a burnt malt character; overall, not a particularly effusive imperial stout (nothing compared to something like 50/50 Totality or even Rasputin), but still pretty enjoyable and neither acrid nor overly burnt. Maybe a touch too much roasted bitterness for the amount of flavor, and there is a bit of warming alcohol as this warms. Lasting finish of burnt and roasted malts, milk and dark chocolate; lingering roasted / bitter ending to this.

Pours chocolate with ruby edges. Nose is chocolate, vanilla, coffee, some dark fruits. Very sweet, lots of coffee on the palate. Bitter coffee finish as well.  Very nice stuff.

From sample pour at local December 2010 tasting.

Received in a trade with bmanning and consumed in the summer of 2009.

A: Poured a very dark brown, nearly black, with a short tan head.

S: Lots of roasted malt paired with coffee, vanilla, and a bit of chocolate.

T: The vanilla comes through quite a bit and in comes the chocolate with a bit of sweetness, followed by a dry coffee/espresso and plenty of roasted malt.

M: Fairly full-bodied with moderate carbonation.

D: Very, very drinkable. Quite complex and added yet another tally to the number of amazing vanilla-infused beers that Ive had.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-01-2010

This is an awesome beer. Just enough coffee to add to the flavor but not take over. The Vanilla stands out and creates a smooth finish to this awesome beer. Truly worth the effort to track one of these down and the only bad thing about this beer was the fact it was my only bottle. Awesome!
Pours a dark brown with short lived tan head. Great coffee aroma. Tastes of roasted coffee with vanilla accents, but not overpowering. Wonderful, but would likely taste even better aged.

Originally had a churchills on tap and recently able to buy a few bottles. looks like cola with a little fizz when poured but flattens out quickly. vanilla aroma is pronounced. taste bitter chocolate and coffee flavors. this is a great beer for $8 per bottle.

Picked up a bomber bottle at Spirits of St. Germain in La Jolla, California, and tasted it from a snifter.  It pours a very dark and murky brown.  Head is tan, and fairly thin and short-lived for me.  Smells and tastes like a coffee shop, and I mean that in a good way.  The sweet, roasted coffee aroma is huge...coffee dominates the taste at first as well, but is soon complemented by the vanilla and chocolate flavors, and a nice maltiness.  Theres also a raisin-like dark fruit flavor that enters to accompany the lingering, mild bitterness of the finish.  Its medium-bodied, and fairly lightly carbonated--this gives it a somewhat velvety feel, but I wonder if my particular bottle might be slightly less carbonated that its supposed to be (this might explain the thinness of the head as well).  Regardless, Victory at Sea is very good overall; especially good after a light meal or when the weather starts to turn colder.

Found at Albertsons in San Diego.  Roasted coffee and chocolate waft off this black beer with a dense, tan, persistent head.  Rich milk and dark chocolate creaminess hit you on the first sip followed by light vanilla flavor and sweetness, and then a deep roasted/charred malt flavor.  Beautiful, well balanced bitterness follows up, probably both from hops and from the dark roasted malt.   Even through this heaviness, theres a fresh grain husk flavor that comes through and makes what could be an over the top dark beer surprisingly refreshing.   It says 10% ABV, but it sure doesnt show it and goes down smooth as silk.  Comparable to Old Rasputin with a coffee/vanilla flavor thrown in.   This is one great beer.
From 22oz bomber.  Pours a very dark, nearly black with a dark tan head.  Smells of coffee, burnt malts.  Loads of coffee in this beer overpower the vanilla flavor.  Smooth, drinkable.

Dark black pour w/ a huge frothy dense light brown head w/ dense sticky lacing and a good amount of visible carbonation.  Full creamy palate w/ a light silkiness.  Aroma has a light touch of bitter dark coffee some light toffee sweetness and a hint of vanilla.  When it warms up a more milky chocolate aroma comes out.  Its quite nice.  Flavor is slightly sweet, lactose milk chocolate w/ a lightly bitter finish from the coffee and a light vanilla in the aftertaste.  This stuff is just delicious!

On tap.  A very dark pour, with a small tan head.  Coffee!  Thick and full mouthfeel.  Some chocolate malts in their as well, and a smoothness that was unexpected for this style.  Well-balanced with some hop bitterness, but the specialty coffee malts are front and center.  I think this would make one hell of an irish car bomb.

Flight at Capones. Pours obsidian, onyx black with a wispy, airy, wildly laced head. Aroma of vanilla, coffee, chocolate, toffee, noble aromatic hops, and some serious roast. Full bodied with a smooth, sweet, well-balanced mouthfeel. Finishes with a bitersweet bite and slight booziness. Outstanding Imperial porter.

On tap. Jet black pour with a dense tan head. Powerful chocolate aroma with lots of coffee to back it up. Flavor is heavy on the coffee. Chocolate is evident early, but it fades into a somewhat bitter finish. Surprisingly light palate considering the ABV. No traces of alcohol at all. Im glad the ABV was printed on the menu so I knew what I was getting myself into. Pretty good overall, but the flavor just wasnt what I was hoping for.

bomber from lagunitasfan. pours black with a tan head that reduces to a ring. aroma of coffee, vanilla and roasted malt. the flavour is very much dessert coffee. bitterness from the malt, and coffee and hops. very well hopped with noticeable citrus hop flavour showing. like ddc aphro, ddc peche, and st creme brulee all mixed together.

Bottle. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty coffee aroma with hints of vanilla. Dry roasted malty coffee and vanilla flavor with hints of chocolate. Has a roasted malty coffee and vanilla finish with hints of bitter chocolate in the aftertaste.

An uber kool label adorns this bomber I just received.  Topped the old Val Dieu snifter off with this decadent crude which bubbled up a small tan head.  The nose was big vanilla, coffee, and bitter chocolate.  The taste is fantastic.  Big semi sweet chocolate, vanilla and coffee flavors sweep over the decks followed by a dark roasted malt finish.  What an amazing brew.....

Bottle shared by SoLan. Pours black with a brown head. Nose is big vanilla and bitter coffee flavors and roasty malts. Flavors are coffee, roasty, dark fruits, and slight vanilla with a nice hoppy finish. Nice beer if you love coffee. Great beer.
Bottle, thanks tarheels! Pours pitch black with a big tan head and lots of lacing. Mouthfeel is creamy with notes of chocolate, coffee, vanilla. Excellent, complex beer.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours dark brown in color with a small wispy beige head.  The aroma is as advertised: coffee, vanilla, and chocolate.  Deep roasted malts and hints of dark fruits are also present.  The flavor has the roasted malts being more prominent.  Ample chocolate, coffee and vanilla make for an enjoyable experience.  This gets better as it warms.  Earthy bitteerness with a touch of char come out.  Finish is dry roasted vanilla coffee.  Medium-full body and scary smooth.  Absolutely no sign of the ABV.  

Enjoyed 7/30/09 (and again on Fri. bus RBSG 10)

Shared on the RBSG bus. Pours a deep black with a decent head that leaves some lace on the glass. The aroma is all things black molasses, chocolate, lots of raw coffee bean, some raisins, and some vanilla. The flavor is chocolate and vanilla with some coco bitterness and deep roasty tones with a mild booziness.
Thanks to someone on the RBSG bus! Thats damn good. Really rich chocolate/coffee. Very decadent.

Bottle, on the Friday Bus Trip at RBSG 2010. Pours cola brown, moderate off-white head, poor lacing. Nose is spicy hops, almost oriental in terms of aroma, with notes of ginger, pepper and 5-spice coasting above the expected coffee, roast, and chocolate. Mouthfeel is akin to chocolate syrup, plus the earlier spiciness, and more coffee. Needs time, but still plenty good right now.

Black pour with brown highlights and a small loose white head.  The aroma has loads of vanilla and coffee with some faint dark fruit.  Thew flavor is smooth milk chocolate, vanilla, candied figs, smoke, wood and lots of alcohol.  Thinnish body, oily, soft carbonation and some alcohol warming.

On tap at PP Solana Beach.  Black on black in the glass with an initially nice brown head fading to the sides.  Massive vanilla laid over coffee in the aroma (smooth smooth smooth).  Taste is heavy (but well-balanced) vanilla supported by coffee, sweet malt, and thinning alcohol with a hint of raisin.  Exceptional beer and definitely the best Ive had from Ballast Point.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2015 bottle at home ... from cquiroga ... deep black ... big bubbly head ... down to thin lacing ... big soft chocolate vanilla nose ...chocolate front ... big vanilla ... light sweetness ... fairly rounded ... full flavoured ... but nothing overpowers... 4.0Bottle at home ... deep black ... small tan head ... soft sweet toffee malt  (that i dont like) nose ... dark roast ... big vanilla ... quite sweet ... full on ... dark sweet roast ... little powdery chocolate ... 3.8Keg at brewdog agm 2015... Dark roast... Thin tan head... Dark chocolate coffee roast malts nose.. Dark chocolate roast.. Dark malts... Soft chocolate roast.. Dark bitter coffee roast 4.0... Tap at brewdog... Dark black... Thin tan lacing... Soft coffee chocolate roast nive 4.1

Bottled. Pitch black coloured. Dense brown head. Aroma of vanilla, sweetness, roast and vague coffee. Flavour of roast, sweetness, coffee, vanilla, chocolate and vague smoke. Medium to full bodied. Has a vanilla dense roasty bitterness in the end. Quite nice. Thx to snojerk321 for this.

Bottle with big thanks to Tytoanderso.  Midnight black pour, lasting light brown carbonation and an aroma strong dark chocolate and a little smoke.  Flavor is also plenty of bitter chocolate, vanilla, roasted malts and a little smoky and thin on the finish.  Although finished a little thin, was extremely well balanced for a 10% ABV beer.  Thanks again Tyler for sending this beer my way.

$9.99/22oz. The Wine Stop. Honolulu,HI. Pours black with a nice tan head. The aroma at first is coffee roast then some vanilla, and smells real nice. The taste is shockingly like vanilla ice cream with espresso syrup on top. Kind of like a root beer float but instead of soda they used coffee . The mouthfeel is so creamy you can still feel it in your mouth well after each drink. Seriously I have never tried a beer that tasted like it had vanilla ice cream in it, this did. This is a very sweet beer and is dessert.

Serving: Bottle. 
It pours almost black with a thick tan head.  The nose is very roasty with notes of coffee, some herbal hops, and a bit of chocolate.  The taste has loads of coffee, a pleasing back bitterness, earthy hops, dirt, milk chocolate, and a touch of alcohol.  Medium to rich mouthfeel with average carbonation leading to a lingering, bitter finish.  Overall its an excellent porter that maintains great drinkability and has a great use of coffee flavor without being overbearing.  Highly recommended.

sample at SAVOR on 6/5/10.  light black pour with a small tan head.  coffee nose with chocolate and roasted nuts.  big chewy smooth body with vanilla, more nuts and coffee.  nice carbonation on the tip of the tongue.  roasty, vanilla, caramel, chocolate filled finish.  awesome beer.

Weird aroma of aloe, bark, and golden rod. Garnet brown, thin beige head. Aloe dominated flavor of dark roasted malt, with traces of coffee. Point for originality, but there was a hop flavor that was far beyond piney and did not work for me at all in this porter. Do people really like this beer that much?

Bottle:  The aroma has lots of roasted coffee, moderate vanilla, chocolate, and a hint of fruit.  It pours a dark brown with some orange highlights with a small beige head.  The flavor starts with caramel, chocolate, and light vanilla.  The finish has moderate roasted coffee and some faint burnt notes.  Medium bodied mild carbonation and soft mouthfeel.

Had the opportunity to try this during the Black Friday event at Capones.

Appearance: Pours black with a minimal khaki crown that shows little retention or lace.

Smell: Wow this is one lovely smelling brew! Loads of coffee and vanilla over a nicely roasted malt. Some chocolate makes an appearance but its more of a supporting role.

Taste: Very good blend of coffee, vanilla, roasted malt, and chocolate. So close to a 5.0

Mouthfeel: Enough carbonation and very creamy!

Drinkability: The flavors are bold and the abv is in double digits, but its delicious tasting with a rewarding mouthfeel.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 11-29-2009

UPDATED: APR 15, 2011 Pours black with carbonated tan head. Full nose of vanilla bean, coffee and chocolate. Taste is slightly less satisfying than the nose, but still high quality. Its a combination of smooth chocolate and harshly burnt dry vanilla bean. Some malts. The taste gets smoother and less harsh the further down the bottle.
Draft. Black with orange tan head. Aroma is burnt, unsweetened and bold and like the Marlin Porter it is sticky but burnt and coffee. Simple but great!

Bottle. 

Black with a pale beige head. Small lacings.

The aroma is quite intense with notes of vanilla and coffee, and surprisingly much malty fudge. 

The flavor cranks it up a notch. Its full-bodied and nicely carbonated, and up front there is lots of smooth sweet vanilla and fudge. Then, dry coffee and roasted malts kick in along with some chocolate, leading the way to a bitter finish of roasted malts, coffee and vanilla. An eventful flavor profile and quite full of character, but to much sweet vanilla for me. Almost reminds me of overly sweet liqueurs associated with ladies way older than me.

Growler; thanks to weeheavySD for the trade; pours jet black with thick tan head fading quickly to the edges; huge coffee aromas with rich chocolate, vanilla beans and booze roast; lots of oats too with an explosion of coffee goodness; just killer all around; smooth, thick, roasty and sweet; vanilla cookies, chocolate and sweet coffee; kind of the perfect beer on many levels and glad to get some big samples with the growler; certainly lived up to my lofty expectations

Bomber; thanks to toncatcher for this trade; now out in bottles, I was interested to see how it stacked up to the growler I received earlier; same dense black pour with thick tan head; huge nose of vanilla, bourbon, coffee and sweet roast; tons of sweet coffee again but the body here is not as full as before; also much dried in the finish; velvety nose with a little astringency showing up in the nose; rich wood and sweet vanilla; more caramel too; damn good though

A: The pour is a beautiful black color with a rather nice layer of mocha colored foam, but no lacing to speak of.

S: The aroma is full of coffee and vanilla, as one might expect from the name of the beer. There are also a lot of roasted malt and chocolate.

T: While the nose was spectacular, the flavor is just as good (maybe even a little better). The coffee and vanilla flavors really come out as the beer warms up a little, as does a great chocolate flavor. The roasted malts are present throughout as well.

M: A rather full body and smooth mouthfeel. The carbonation is low to moderate, which helps out the aforementioned feel on the tongue.

D: This is a dangerously drinkable beer. I didnt really detect any alcohol and its just such a solid beer that you cant help but keeping going back to it.

Rating #1300. Bottle from a trade with with cbkschubert. Pours a very dark brown color with light brown head. Strong aromas of coffee, chocolate and vanilla. Roasty flavor with sweet milk chocolate and vanilla. There is some coffee in there but not as much in the flavor as there is in the aroma. Full body with soft carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. Very nice. Thanks Craig.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z3ZAGBL6U
Pours dark brown with big espresso head. Aroma is like hot chocolate with marshmallow. Big vanilla taste followed by milk chocolate. Ends with minor coffee bitterness. A truly special beer.

Bottle shared by Eric, thanks 
Appearance: Black with a small tan head and some lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts, vanilla and coffee 
Taste: Silky mouthfeel. Roasted malts, vanilla and chocolate 
Very nice beer. The vanilla comes through strong but not overpowering.
Thanks to footbalm. Wow. Sex and candy. Beautiful color, coats the glass and your licking muscle wonderfully.  Exciting lacing. Tastes like coffee in your Lucky Charms cereal. Simply delicious.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2015 draft.  nose is mild vanilla bean, light milk, medium roast, overall pleasant and without flaws but lacks depth.  sticky and oily texture up front, more astringent (still only a minor annoyance) medium roast in the back.  somewhat rough and parched at times, the carbonation is a little disjointed but its not much of a fault.  char, coffee, roast, etc.  overall somewhat simple (stale nose is the biggest complaint) but I appreciate its quietness.

22oz  Courtesy of ygtbsm94.  Thanks for the bottle, Brad!  Black, thick khaki head.  Caramelized vanilla bean and roasted coffee aromas warm to soft swirls of milk chocolate toast and crème brûlée.  Deep burnt vanilla coffee and dark chocolate flavors round to a roasted caramel-like finish.  Full bodied, soft carbonation, bittersweet finish.  Great beer

Very dark, perhaps more opaque than some porters. Aroma of coffee, vanilla, malt. The deeper coffee and roasted nut flavors hit first, followed by the vanilla. Fairly heavy, though the alcohol content is masked a bit. Very nice.

Pours Black with medium sized brown head. Aroma of fresh vanilla, milky chocolate, espresso beans. Amazing, inviting....velvety body gives rise to a vanilla aged milk chocolate shake with alcohol. Huge lactose, huge chocolate.  Wonderful vanilla finish. The alcohol aftertaste is perhaps its only flaw. Lucious and among the finest porters created

Bottle (shared with Tweety)...  Poure black with a tan head.  Milky, cocoa, malt aroma.   Tasted like chocalate milk with an iced coffee tone towards the finish. Malts crept in, and a tiny, roasted bitterness.  Creamy, vanilla bean, chocalate.

bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  pitch black with a thick khaki head.  nose is vanilla, roasted malts, rich chocolate, and more vanilla.  great on the palate, flavor is very vanilla, roasted malts, light chocolate, and a heavy  coffee finish.

(22oz bomber via trade with LagunitasFan) pours clearish espresso brown, thick tan head and excellent lacing. Nose of vanilla extract, cola, nuts, light coffee aromas. Taste of huge vanilla extract, dry coffee and cocoa powder, and semisweet chocolate. Medium body with a very creamy finish.
bomber shared at DLD-black pour -brown head -aroma and taste of vanilla, coffee, roasty, -sweet finish

tap at RnH - Pours dark and murky with a dark head. Coffee, roast, creamy and dark, thick and chewy. Love that mouth feel. Smooth and tasty. Has a nice piney hop that so rarely comes through in darker beer. Tasty and well balanced.

Thanks to Lt. Dan for sharing this at DLD. Deep thick black pour with a dark brown head. The vanilla hits your senses first, followed by the roasted malt, and coffee. The sip sent an explosion of flavor reminiscint of the flavor you just took in. Creamy, chewy, the beer coated my mouth. So good.

A- Opaque nearly black body that pours with a nice 2-3 finger tan head. Head fades eventually to a thick collar but leaves plenty of lacing behind in the glass.

S- Nose is very sweet and vanilla is certainly the main character. Coffee beans are definitely present as well and make up the background of the nose.

T-The initial flavor is subtle and offers a subtle vanilla sweetness with a touch of dark malt backbone. The finish is full of vanilla sweetness with some coffee undertones-but then just as the sweetness almost becomes too much a moderate roasted malt bitterness comes through to balance all the flavors. The slightest alcohol heat can be detected as well.

P-Medium to high carbonation and medium weight-silky smooth body.

O- This is 10%???? Really??? I thought I was drinking atwater vanilla java porter until the finish. This is a well rounded balanced coffee porter with ABV nearly undetectable.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-06-2010 02:20:17

Bottle.  Consumed the sunday morning after DLD.  Decent beer, but not what Im looking for in a beer.  Some nice booze, chocolate and coffee notes to this as well.  The vanilla is definitely front and center.   For some reason vanilla flavored beers never sit right with me.  They tend to come across as overly sweet and artificial.  While this beer may be well crafted, i just wasnt feelin the vanilla.

22oz. bottle served in a snifter. Poured a deep brown with a finger of tan head. Coffee, chocolate malt along with a bit of hops in the aroma. Lots of chocolate in the flavor. Rich and smooth, medium to full bodied. Some piney hops in the middle. Vanilla in the finish. Finish lingers fairly long. Also some drying from the hops in the finish. Solid beer, but the coffee stout/porter thing just doesnt do it for me.

Growler fill at CBX. Pours dark black with a fluffy, dark tan head. Definite smell of coffee (but not overpowering), slight oak age/vanilla mixed in as well. First sip is overwhelmingly coffee flavored, but again, its not a strong/overpowering feeling. I think the vanilla and a bit of sweet chocolate flavor helps mellow the coffee. This helps mask the alcohol content as well. This is one of the most balanced coffee "related" offerings I have ever tasted. Not a huge aftertaste, but enough to remind you of your last sip.

Pours almost black with a huge head which settled quickly. Good lacing remained throughout. The nose was milkshake - chocolate and vanilla, caramel, with a noticeable roasted malt and coffee. The mouthfeel was creamy and a perfect thickness for a porter. Taste was carmel, coffee, vanilla. The finish contained some bitterness, smoke and a mild and pleasant alcohol warming. i would not be able to sip at this all night but will definitely seek it out again - an excellent porter.

Tap at Rattle n Hum. Poured jet black with a delicious looking tan foam head, like a cappucino. Nose has lots of vanilla, a hint of booze, and roasted malts. Very inviting. Im wondering if its going to be too sweet. It might be too sweet. The vanilla really hits hard and almost has an artificial flavor. After a few sips and some warming the vanilla is less distracting. Very full bodied. A bunch of roasted malts. The coffee really shines in the finish which is long and bitter,and a tad sweet.

On Tap - 3rd in flight of 4. Very dark brown. Lots of coffee and chocolate in the aroma. Most amazing balance between malt and bitterness. Silky wonderful on the palate and only goodness in the finish. Please sir, can I have some more!

Tap at Rattle n Hum. Outstanding. Pours dark brown with a thick, dark beige head. Aroma of cocoa, lightly roasted malts, some vanilla. Flavor is phenomenal. Tons of chocolate - think chocolate milk with extra syrup. Hints of oats and vanilla. Modest roastiness in the tail. Finishes sweet and long with nice bitterness. Amazingly smooth and creamy with average carbonation. Mildly warming - really the only noticeable impact of the ABV. Probably the best Imperial Porter I have ever drank.

The potent aroma includes creamy vanilla and chocolatey malts. The dark chocolate black color has a fluffy, snaking, creamy, crimson cocoa head - its perfect. The flavor starts as roasted malts and then the vanilla comes in strong with notes of coffee. It finishes quite boozy though with a nice punch.
On tap at rattle n hum during the ballast event.  Loaded with chocolate and espresso roast... Body is full and creamy.  Absolutely awesome.

Darkest porter I have ever seen, cream colored head with lots of lacing. Aroma of bitter black cofee, oats, oaky vanilla, bourbon. flavor is hot and alcoholic, whiskey burn, roasty. Overall this is badass. $8 bomber! at Hamiltons San diego.
Draft and Bottle. Black pour with tan head. Aroma is light but mostly vanilla. Mouth feel is smooth and flavor is full, porter with vanilla overtones. Nice brew.

Bomber shared by Enniskillen from Bevmo, Gilroy. Nose of chocolate, coffee, and light vanilla. Black with a medium, lightly lacing tan head. Flavor is heavy, dark, coffee and some background chocolate.

Pours up jet black with a receding deep tan head. Aroma is an intoxicating blend of coffee, chocolate, and an almost bourbon like rich sweetness. Taste is explosively coffee and chocolate, with the vanilla contributing a great richness and smoothness. Still finishes up dry enough to prevent it from being cloying. A world class imperial stout.

Black with a nice tan head.  Aroma is heavy on the vanilla and oatmeal, roasty, with caramel, toffee and light alochol.  Taste is fairly sweet with oatmeal up front, light alcohol warming, nice hoppy background, chocolate.

Black pour ruby hue with a tan creamy head .... vanilla and roasted coffee aroma .... taste of vanilla and roasted coffee, chocolate very silky and a little oily mouthfeel with a light bitter finish .... light lacing a little acidic from the coffee but very tasty well balanced porter no trace of the abv

(Bottle, thanks anders37) Pours black with a small brown head. The aroma holds coffee up front with notes of gravel, parsley and light jalapeño oil. In addition, notes of vanilla ice cream, light caramel and roasted malt. A whisper of hops. The flavour is light sweet to dry, medium bitter and light acidic. Vanilla, roasted grain, chocolate  and coffee. The mouthfeel is round and soft with a light astringent sting. Lingering aftertaste of burned, earthy and light acidic malt and coffee. Medium to full bodied.

Really? I havent rated this?  This rate is on tap at Blue Palms.  Deep dark brown with a one finger tan head fair retention. Aroma is a big sweet vanilla vs cold coffee and roasted malt aroma, brown sugar, and alcohol heat.  Flavor follows with a nice sweet/coffee chocolate thing going on--sweet, but never getting too sweet.  Very light soy sauce thing going on.  Semi-dry,  bitterness at a 3.  Full body with light carbonation.  Very good.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text:
Appearance: Pours a midnight brown with a khaki frothy creamy head.

Aroma: Dark roasted coffee (brewed), light but noticeable caramel and vanilla notes.

Taste: Black coffee, vanilla custard, dark burnt malts and spicy hops.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied, slick and modestly carbonated.

Overall: World class and super tasty.

This is a fantastic beer.  Off the tap at Najas in Redondo Beach, CA.  Nice and thick, robust toasted malt flavor with hints of coffee and vanilla.  I could drink a ton of this beer.  Would recommend to anyone.

@RichmondX Gathering Thanks decaturstevo-22oz bottle-pours a thin light brown head and black color.  Aroma is dark malt-coffee/roasty/chocolate.  Taste is dark malt-coffee/roasty/chocolate, nut, acidic bite, vanilla.  Occasional.
Black pour with creamy tan head and lace. Huge coffee/espresso aroma. Large coffee, vanilla, roasted barely, and abv on the flavor. Medium/full bodied with good carbonation. Very nice beer.

Bottle  Pours a good deep black with a nice tan head.  The head lasts well and laces excellnetly.  Has a good aroma of chocolate, coffee, mocha, and hints of vanilla.  Carbonation is perfect.  The flavor is awesome.  Blended perfect.  Good hearty coffee, with hints of vanilla and nuts.  Some chocolate.  The alcohol is unnoticable.  Has a thick texture.  A full body.  Awesome finish with a good sweet aftertaste.  This is by far my favorite Porter and a great beer.

Tap at Capones. Pours a deep brown with a nice tan head. Aroma is like walking into a good coffee shop first thin in the morning, coffee, sweet vanilla and chocolate. Silky smooth mouthfeel with a wonderfully balanced array of flavors, chocolate, sweet vanilla, coffee and light roast. They hit this one out of the park.
UPDATED: MAY 16, 2010 From a 22 oz bottle.chocolate, coffee, black, So much Chocolate .the head has a brown thick Head,So much Coffee,with a hint of vanilla perfect o!

Thanks to Mrbunn for sharing this goodness. Aromas of chocolate and coffee with hop notes mixed in. Pours a jet black with a rather liht tan head. Flavor is heavy on the chocolate with light coffee background, with vanilla cruising in and out. Creamy smooth palate. yumyumyumyum.
Black color/ tan head. Big vanilla extract, coffee mocha aromas. medium body. Rich, hearty flavors of sweet nutty vanilla bean, medium roast coffee, dark roasted malts. breakfast beer. very good
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Pours an opaque deep brown with a thin brown head and beautiful lacing from the 22oz. bottle: USA just tied Canada for the Olympic gold medal championship game with seconds left!!! Rushed rating...  Nose of vanilla, coffee, molasses, roasted malts, and pipe tobacco. Flavor of vanilla latte, caramel syrup, roasted malts, molasses, and some tobacco. Minimal carbonation with a slight back-of-throat warming. Roasted malts, bitter coffee beans, and light vanilla take the end. And... Canada just won the gold, but what a game and what a beer to enjoy it with! Drinkability: Tasty and delicious. Pairing: Rich seven layer chocolate lava cake. Or a prime rib. Rebuy: Yes. #311 on 28022010, DG.

Bottle. Pours a very deep brown, mostly black body with a thin, creamy, tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is loaded with fresh espresso beans and vanilla with sweeter chocolate malts. A trace of burnt roast and wood. Flavor is the same with the coffee playing a softer role than it did in the aroma. Still plenty of coffee, but lots of medium sweet chocolates, cocoas, and vanilla. The vanilla grows sweeter after a few minutes of warming along with more traces of burnt roast, wood, and milk sugars. Finishes rich and fairly dry with a lengthy aftertaste after a medium, silky body and a light carbonation. Overall, a solid beer. Lots of coffee and vanilla, but plenty of malts to balance.

(22oz bottle).  Pours thick and black with a nice caramel colored head.  Aroma of darkly roasted coffee beans.  Burnt coffee flavor with vanilla undercurrent that gets sweeter as it warms.  Im really enjoying this more as it warms because it balances out the heavy roast flavor.

22 oz. bottle from Plaza Liquors - Pours a clear brown color with a medium size tan head that lasts.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is coffee, roasted malt, and a hint of vanilla.  Flavor is coffee, chocolate, and vanilla.  No lingering aftertaste.  Medium to full body.  A very nice beer.

Just not a huge fan of this...cloyingly sweet!!!  Really enjoyable nose with cocoa, roasted marshmallow, and pure vanilla bean rising from the glass.  Dark mahogany pour produced a sticky latte head.  ...And then there was the flavor.  Eye-crossingly sugary with the vanilla completely out of balance.  A little thin for the style, as well.  Meh.

one of my faves, this stuff is super balanced, amazing mouthfeel, very vanillaish and sweet, but very well balanced and bitter as well. caramalized vanilla and burnt oak all over this one, plus all the usual suspects. yummy!

pours deep black with a huge mocha colored head...nice lacing and retention!  aroma has dark chocolate, coffee,  hints of dark fruit vanilla, and slight phenols.  flavor is roasty with syrupy chcoclate, coffee, dark chocolate, some burnt qualities, and a hint of citrus.  mouthfeel is rich and creamy...slightly sticky...with a slightly chocolatey and roasty dry ligering finish.  so good.

Thanks to Joenuegs for this one!  Jet black pour thin beige head and spotty lace.  Aroma is roast and in your face vanilla.  Coffee, chocolate, vanilla. roast and caramel.  Alcohol well masked.  Body is silky

Basically a black brew with a small beige foam on top. Aroma is lots of caramell, vanilla and light powdery chocolate alongside subtile notes of liqourice. Flavor is huge vanilla and sweet caramell giving way to dark and light chocolate ending on a extremely sharp and pleasant coffe bitterness that rescues this beer from being too sweet and straight forward. Still rather simple but tasty with a slick medium body.
Vanilla truffle aromas.  Booming vanilla and coffee flavors.  Medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish.  Delicious!

Bottle courtesy of Kevin at Grape and Gourmet. Pours near black with a short brown head. Aroma is vanilla, coffee, pipe tobacco, roasted malt and molasses. Taste is more vanilla and coffee with lighter tobacco, roasted malt, caramel, soft alcohol and light brown sugar. Mouthfeel is that of moderate carbonation with a slight warmth. Body is medium overall. Ends with more bitter coffee, roasted malt, lighter vanilla and tobacco and molasses. Very tasty!

22 oz. bottle shared at Grape & Gourmets 4th Anniversary (thanks to GandGKevin).  Dark brown to black pour.  Strong roasted coffee aroma with just a hint of vanilla.  The taste is almost the opposite with strong vanilla bean upfront and espresso in the background.  I didnt notice the alcohol.  An outstanding beer.

Bottle.  Pours black with thin tan head.  Huge coffee nose.  Taste is dominated by chocolate, roasted malt, and coffee.  Has sharp coffee bitterness.  Minimal vanilla noted.  Was expecting more vanilla flavor but it is still very good.

22oz. Bottle. Coffee aroma. Pitch black appearance with a small tan head. starts out creamy with huge roasted chocolate flavor. The vanilla flavor does not shine as much from the bottle as it does from draft. Very robust brew with medium carbonation and hints of licorice at the end.

(Sample Date: 1/16/2010   Source:Decaturstevo)   Coffee with chcolate and roast in aroma. Black with medium tan head. Coffee with some dark fruitiness and carmelized sugar in flavor. Vanilla comes out in the finish. Light astringency and moderate bitterness. Very nice beer.

Wow! Delicious imperial porter! Aroma was great. Strong vanilla with coffee undertones. Pour was a nice black with a 2 finger tan head. Taste was a big and full mix of coffee and vanilla. The vanilla hits you in the front and the coffee dominates the aftertaste. Very strong and biting carbonation. Very warming and nice. Great beer
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: bottle poured a dark black in color with a hefty one finger brown head that dragged down the sides of the glass nicely. aroma has roasted malt, coffee, fresh vanilla, chocolate, and some cream. nice soft coating texture. flavor has a lot of chocolate, roasted coffee, light bitterness, very natural vanilla, and cream. the mouth feel is great and for such a high abv. beer the alcohol is totally subdued.

Pours a gorgeous black with near perfect tan head.  Great roasted malt and coffee notes in the nose, accompanied by some light vanilla tones.  Flavor contains a ton of chocolate and coffee, with vanilla and roasted notes arriving later.  Beautiful balance of sweet and roasty with just the right amount of coffee in the background.  Great brew.

The pour is a dark brown opaque body under a thick, tan head.
Vanilla and chocolate join the coffee and malts in the aroma.
The flavor follows the aroma with light roast malt bitterness delivered with a smooth, full-bodied palate.

On tap at Hamiltons. Has a big dark beige head to this black, black beer. Mild coffee but big chocolate. I find this a bit off-balance with far too high and alcohol level. This has a long biter roasted finish. The beer burns just too bad. Or is it that the beer burns just too good?

On draft at Capones in Norristown, PA.  Had this one right after another great imperial porter, Founders Rye Whiskey Aged Porter.  As with the latter,  the porter character is excellent, but in this brew the coffee and especially the vanilla elements really jump on the tongue.  another outstanding beer from Ballast Point.

Pours an opaque black color with a small tan head that recedes to a fine film. The aroma is big and bold with coffee, mocha, dark chocolate and ash. The flavor is much like the aroma, but with vanilla rolled in.

dark brown with a tan head .  Smells of chocolate, cream , vanilla and coffee. Flavor is similar, with more chocolate that combines a nice bitter note Great alcohol presence, lovely example of an imperial porter. One of my favorites

Dark Brown pour that sits black in my Rock Art Tulip.  Aroma is sweet milk chocolate, Creamy coffee, Vanilla bean.  Great flavor concentration, Intense bitter coffee is balanced by sweet chocolate and vanilla.  Robust mouthfeel, some warming alcohol.  This is Really intensely flavored but also well balanced and not too boozey.  Really really good

Bomber. Pours a dark brown color with a foamy tan head that recedes to a light film with sporatic lacing. Nose is heavy coffee with some dark roast and chocolate and vanilla bachground. Palate is full and foamy with rich chocolate notes and some really nice hershey syrup laces. Big full flavor that is not over done but brings it. Finish is dry and lovely, nice and chewy.

Bomber purchased at Papago Scottsdale AZ. Thanks Daknole for the tip. Pours solid black with a nice brown head.  Nose is very bready, chocolately, burnt malts. Taste is very nice-with chocolate, toffee, a nice refreshing alcohol bite and a great malt base. Full thick body with a taste that lingers all way down. This is a well done beer-I should have bought more than 1!!!
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Was blessed to get this one at the Richmond 10th gathering.  Almost pitch black on the pour.  Coffee, vanilla almost roasted malts on the nose.  I taste lots of coffee and more coffee.  I also get the strong taste of the roasted malts in there as well.  Full bodied beer.  Great lacing on the glass.  Just a great beer all around, thanks Stevo!

Lovely opaque black with khaki brown head. Nose is luxurious with layers of vanilla, chocolate ice cream, and a smoky/roasty quality. On the palate the vanilla is really in your face with a smooth roasty character that brings the malt forward, and an espresso/coffee like quality towards the finish and aftertaste.

Pours black with a foamy brown head. Wonderful aroma of coffee, vanilla, and roasted malts. Its got the same tastes as the smell as well as a little bit of bitterness and that punch of alcohol to finish things off. Nice full body. Overall it excells at its style and is another wonderful addition to the Ballast Point lineup. Definitely worth the price of admission.

Pours dark brown with a khaki head. The aroma is a mix of strong black coffee with hints of chocolate. The flavor is black coffee with vanilla and some chocolate. The coffee and vanilla merge together very well to make a very good beer. The mouthfeel is very creamy and the carbonation is low.

Dark as the sea bottom producing a sizable head. Strong aromas of coffee and toasted vanilla beans. Full body with excellent carbonation. Copious amounts of roasted coffee and cocoa drowned the senses while a neon vanilla flashes life into a lifeless Davey Jones. This is a meal to be rationed sparingly. I hold my chalice high in honor of those who were victorious at sea. Arrhh! Trumpola!

Location: On tap at the Brewery, Linda Vista Location, 1/7/10 


Aroma: Lots of roasted coffee, some chocolate, vanilla, and alcohol

Appearance: Dark brown/black colored beer with a light brown head, some lace

Flavor: Taste is somewhat sweet with a drop of bitterness

Palate: Medium-full body, with a nice long duration and a creamy mouthfeel

Overall Impression: 
I dont have a ton of notes down on this one, just the components, but I remember liking this one quite a bit, and thinking it was my favorite of the non-IPA beers, and definitely one of the best things I tried at Ballast Point.

Completely black pour with a nice beige head that looks almost as if it came out of a nitro tap- thick and luxurious. Aroma holds tons of milk chocolate, caramel, lactic cream notes, vanilla and coffee. Flavor is similar, with more great chocolate that combines a nice bitter note with lactic sweetness. Great alcohol presence, lovely example of an imperial porter. This is excellent stuff.

Utterly black pour with an old Greg creamy beige head. Almost nitro-esce. Simply beautiful. The aroma is like a river of caramel with a torrent of milk chocolate, vanilla, delicious lactic cream, and espresso.  Powerful and pronounced- true to the style and savory. The flavor is decidedly roasty with copious lactic sugar and coffee. If it wasnt for the lactic sugar, this would be bakers chocolate mess of deliciousness. The palate is epically thick and rich with a creamy mouthfeel and supple finish.

I drank this from a 22oz bottle into my Rochefort chalice.

The beer pours black with a medium tan head. There is nice carbonation as it rises about 3 fingers of creamy head. It lasts a couple minutes and has great lacing that sticks from the top of the glass to the beer.

The aroma is medium, mostly roasted coffee, but not overpowering. In the middle you get the glimpse of vanilla, lake a cappucino. Wish it was a little more dominant. 

The taste is good, but way to overpowered with coffee from start to finish with a bitter roast finish. I want the vanilla to come out to play more, along with some other complexity please?

The feel is good, very lasting, but limited drinkability because of the overwhelming coffee.

Overall, this is pretty good but if they toned down the coffee a bit it could be world class.

In addition to the obvious coffee and vanilla aromas, there is a distinct herbal hoppiness in the aroma.  Flavor is, as you might imagine, nice dark roasted coffee with a subtle vanilla backing and more herbs in the finish.  Ever see the music video for Foo Fighters "Learn To Fly"?  This is what the coffee must have tasted like.

Bottle from Boston trip.  This is big coffee, and definately flavoured vanilla.  The coffee is good, I am not a coffee drinker or fan, but it was done well for what it is. So yes, big in flavour.  Above average mouthfeel.  Big coffee aroma.  Still most quafable.

Black, brown at the edges.  Aroma is absolutely fantastic, blend of vanilla and some coffee.  Great.  Could sniff this all night.  Flavor is a match.  Vanilla and astringency is the tiniest bit too high for me to go totally up for this, but it is a heck of a good beer.  Richmond 10th, courtesy of stevo.

Bottle from Maniacs Richmond Tenth Gathering.  Nice dark brown pour with some brown head.  Nose is not a particularly good coffee for my taste.  But the flavor is great.  Vanilla and coffee blend nicely.  Lots of roast, almost burnt. Tasty.  Awesome label art to boot!

22 ounce bottle courtesy of decaturstevo. Thanks! Pours a dark brown color with a thin head. Fair head retention and lacing. Aroma of rich dark coffee, chocolate and roasted malts. Taste is dark roasted malts, caramel, rich coffee and fairly strong vanilla notes, which as a vanilla freak I enjoy greatly. Some leather notes as well. Medium-full bodied.

Pours a deep brownish black with a large light brown head. Aroma is vanilla beans, coffee, chocolate, roasted barley. Flavor is chocolate, coffee, roasted grains, cocoa nibs, a touch of vanilla. Good amount of chocolate and coffee bitterness but not too chalky like many coffee beers. The coffee is very present and compliments the beer nicely. Good stuff.

22 oz. bottle from a trade with fidelis83- thanks, Jeremiah!  Pours very dark brown, almost black, with a small tan head.  Aroma is heavy on coffee and vanilla, with notes of chocolate, roasted malts, earthy hops, and brown sugar.  The flavor is also coffee and vanilla (this thing delivers what it promises), and also has some earthy notes, hops, roasted malts, and chocolate.  Medium-full bodied, with low carbonation and a flat cola mouthfeel.  The vanilla pops more and more as this gets lower and warmer, and the alcohol is hidden.  This was the 8th beer of 10 in a tasting I held for some friends, and we paired it with some homemade brownies; turned out to be a great dessert beer.  I could also do it with dinner, but it would have to be a hearty, simple meal.  Great imperial porter.

Bottle from Sams in Durham.  Nice to see this one available around here.  Pours nice and black with a softly foamy light mocha head.  Nose is beautiful... lots of vanilla, for sure, but not just mild vanilla spice -- more like the bean.  Fruity in a way I didnt expect. Some chocolate and coffee.  But this is different than most imperial stouts/porters.  Cant get over how fruity the vanilla character is.  Silky smooth palate.  Yum.

Sampler at the brewery.  Aroma is coffee and leather.  These two are so strong in the nose that the vanila gets shouted down.  Flavor is outstanding; smokey, strongly of rich dark coffee beans, leather, cocoa, and vanilla.  Just plain awesome.

On tap at Ballast Point.  This was a very pleasant surprise.  Dark brown pour with a little bit of a beige/tan head and aromas of coffee and leather.  First sip reveals much more, however... loads of coffee and chocolate up front (but its got a fairly creamy texture and not abrasive at all) with a vanilla and cream flavor showing up in the finish.  Amazing stuff...
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Simply outstanding. One of the best porters Ive ever had. The aroma is terrific. Coffee grind, vanilla, and chocolate. The taste is something to behold as well. The first sip is very much like a coffee stout, but finishes like a porter. Sweet and robust. Full of flavor, that lingers on the tongue well after it has gone down.

Bottle from Beverages4Less. Pours black with a 3-finger tan head. Aroma of coffee. Full bodied with creamy carbonation Coombination of coffe and vanilla leads to a nice dose of bitter chocolate. Just excellent.

Shared by bhensonb. Pours dark brown with a beautiful thick tan head and a coffee with cream aroma. The flavor is contrasting chocolate and vanilla with a bit of cherry and some oak. The finish is dry and fairly bitter.
Pours a dark brown (near black) body with a small tan head. Aroma of coffee, vanilla, nuts, and roasted malt. Flavor of coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, and vanilla
Coffee hue-like appearance and dark, roasted chocolate aroma.Upfront the taste was very malty and roasty. Ending with traces of vanilla makes for a smooth finish.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2010 22oz bomber brought to a tasting in Dec 2009. Pours pitch black with a thin, deep brown head. Good retention. Good lacing. Aroma is coffee, roasted malt, ehh I cant get too much else out of it. Taste is still too hot. Very boozy. Lots of warming. Hard to get much out of it at this point. Bubbly, biting on the palate. Good definitely take kindly to some barrel aging or cellaring for 1-2 years. Disappointing. Need to retry this when my other bottles start to peak. 6/5/7/3/12=3.3Tap at the brewery. Doesnt look as beautiful with scant lacing. Aroma is wonderful tropical, green coffee beans. Taste is less spicy as the booziness is cut by lots of sappy, resinous wood, dry oak. Still biting, bubbly on the palate. 8/4/7/3/13=3.522oz 2009 ed from 7/2010. Pours a beautiful deep brown to black with a healthy, dense, rocky, deep brown head that has excellent retention and lace. Booziness is gone. Still very cedar, wood resin heavy, relatively dry, a bit spicy, excellent rich coffee character and raw cacao. Much more refined with 6+ months sitting in the bottle. So definitely hold onto your bottles for a little bit once they are released because this beer definitely gains from it. 8/4/7/4/14=3.7

Bottle thanks to Dominic. Pours pitch black, thin dissipating head. Big cocoa nose, dark berries. Very chocolaty flavour, turning coffeeish later. Deep flavours, vanilla awesomeness. A massive body and great balance of flavours make this an astounding beer.
Poured very black, smooth, lots of chocolate, vanilla, coffee, roasted malts.  #1000 for me!

22oz bottle.   Black with a medium tan head that leaves moderate foam and a touch of lace.   Not inky though with some mahogany around the edges, which I guess is an argument for it being a porter (whatever that means).   The aroma is great, with lots of coffee and maybe even more vanilla; almost like a mocha with a shot of vanilla syrup.   Im having Starbucks flashbacks, and I like it.   Plenty of milk chocolate as well, and the vanilla aids in the impression of an immense sweetness.   Did I already mention the vanilla?   I got more coffee at first, but the vanilla is really coming out over time.   Forty-five minutes in the glass, and this begins to resemble vanilla extract.   I love that stuff.   The flavor is sweet, but not thick or sticky (wait, thats a mouthfeel).   Coffee, poser dark chocolate, and lots of vanilla.   Fresh coffee, which is always a nice touch.   Just enough bitterness to balance the sweet, and no astringency or discomfort.   Medium-full body with carbonation that falls somewhere between medium and low.   Just a hint of alcohol warmth in the finish, but very integrated and smooth for a ten percent beer.   Leans more heavily on the coffee, and especially the vanilla, than I was expecting, but this is fantastic stuff.   A true dessert drink,  (or morning depending on how you roll, and I do have a slight caffein buzz) but one that is not overly sweet or thick.   I could drink a fair bit of this, with alcohol being a welcome limiting factor before any abrasive flavor characteristics.   Ballast Point just nailed in on this one: full of flavor, yet balanced and super drinkable.   The vanilla is almost silly at times, but I love the stuff and it really works with the rest of the beer.

Wonderful brew here.  Deep brown body with a large, frothy head.  The aroma is delicious vanilla and coffee scents.  The taste is a creamy vanilla infused coffee.  Not too roasted or harsh at all, but full flavored.  Perfect body and carbonation.  A great treat.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2009 Black pour with a fading frothy head. Aroma is coffee and vanilla extract, roasted malts, sweet bread. Tastes of bitter dark chocolate, packaged hot coco mix and vanilla extract. Overall it tastes pretty artificial, or at least like vanilla extract poured into a porter. Bitter and light bodied.  Not great.

Bomber. Opaque black with a half-inch of lasting creamy foam. Aroma is coffee and bitter cocoa with some light cream. Flavor is big with vanilla, balanced by some bitter cocoa, peppery citrus, and coffee. Medium-heavy body is smooth and roasty-dry.

Amazing beer. The aroma hits you as soon as the glass is delivered. Hard roasted malts with heavy notes of chocolate, coffee, and vanilla. The flavor is delicious with smoke, roast, vanilla ice cream, espresso, chocolate. Well balanced flavor profile. I cant say enough how much I enjoyed this. I imagine the barrel version is incredible as well.

On tap at Capones. Dark brown, almost black, with a thin tan head. Smells of coffee, cocoa, and general roastiness. The flavor is coffee, oak, vanilla, and roasted grains. Medium-full body. Lots of coffee at the finish. Very yummy.

On draft at Capones. Pours a clear black colour. It had no head when it got to my table so Im unsure if it had one when it was poured from the tap. Smells of coffee, vanilla, malts, and chocolate. Vanilla, coffee, oak, malt and chocolate flavor. Ehhhh.

Bottle via trade with toncatcher. Deep opaque brown-black body, medium clumping tan head. Vinous nose with notes of coffee, roasted malts, and vanilla. Vanilla hits the palate first, backed by roasted coffee beans and licorice. Robust body. This really reminded me of drinking a cold, carbonated, flavored coffee. And, no, I dont mean that in a bad way. Exceedingly competent but falls short of greatness.

Bottle shared by nimbleprop: Pours a mostly opaque black with a thin ring of wispy light tan head.  Aroma of rich complex vanilla and coffee with sweet dark caramel undertones.  Starts with a rich full malty sweetness and earthy vanilla and dark caramel well balanced with bittersweet dark chocolate before a mildly warming complex chocolate coffee finish.  A very good imperial porter.

Bottle 22fl.oz.Clear dark red brown color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, light brown head. Aroma is heavy malty, roasted, coffee, cacao, wood, vanilla, chocolate notes. Flavor is heavy sweet and moderate to heavy bitter with a long duration, dry cacao and a peppery finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20091114]

22oz bottle shared at the DC Local tasting.  Pours a slightly watery otherwise opaque black with a spitty tan head.  Nose is big on coffee, wood, smoke, brown sugar.  Flavor is sweet and delicious, vanilla, brown sugar, caramel, cake icing.  Finish is sweet and sticky.  I enjoyed this a lot.

Pours a very deep dark brown while pouring out of the bottle but looks pitch black and completely opaque in the glass with only the slightest hint of mahogany edges when held to a light source. Foamy one finger light tan head that has decent retention, only slowly settling into a lasting cap and ring that leaves sheets of lacing in its path.

Sweet chocolate malty aroma with a very nice roasty character and subtle vanilla. These combined aroma produce a tootsie roll like chocolate coffee scent that is mouthwatering. The roasted coffee bean presence becomes more prominent when it warms. Subtle hops become evident beneath the lactic, silky chocolate notes. Very complex aroma, hopefully the flavor lives up to it.

Chewy silky malt dominated full body with a huge roasted coffee bean presence. Lots of silky chocolate malt and some subtle mellow vanilla notes but the flavor is a bit overpowered by the very intensely strong deep roasted coffee, espresso bean. Hints of oatmeal, toffee, very burnt toast and licorice with a nice dry bitter hop character in the finish. I cant overemphasize how much of a strong burnt/roasted coffee presence there is. Its a bit too harsh for me and extremely bitter, taking away from the silky chocolate and vanilla notes that I liked so much. Alcohol heat mid-palate that becomes stronger at the end of the swallow and produces some warmth in the finish. Pretty complex but a bit one dimensional for me. Recommended for fans of roasted coffee and big coffee beers.

Courtesy of Brad. Dark brown with a medium deep beige head. Sweet aroma with burned malt, coffee, dark bitter chocolate and vanilla notes. Sweet powerfull flavour with burned malt, bourbon, dark bitter chocolate, vanilla and coffee notes. Finished dry.

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of KimJohansen. Pours black with a warm reddish/orangey note and a creamy light brown head. Hard roasted malts in the nose. Solid body, massive hard roasted malt - almost charcoal - that eventually manages to battle and win the cloyingly sweet and unpleasant vanilla notes. Ends with a warming alcohol and a massive malt bitterness - almost astringent. 141109

Bottle, 10%. Vinous aroma, a little fresh coffee and some vanilla. Almost black colour, red shine. Distinct vanilla flavour, sweet, but not as sweet as other barrel aged ones. Distinct alcohol note, a bit rough, but balances the vanilla and sweetness off nicely.

22oz bottle, thanks nimbleprop.  Medium tan head atop brown-black body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, coffee, light sugar, vanilla, roast.  Taste is moderately sweet, coffee, some vanilla, alcohol, light roast.  Smooth medium-full body with low carbonation.

Bottle at the release of Flaming Fury.  Pours black with a medium tanned beige head.  Coffee and vanilla abound.  A touch of acrid bitterness keeps the coffee and vanilla from being overpowering and the result is delicious.  Very smooth, and very tasty.

Bottle from Stefanje, iirc. Pours a nice black/brown with a dark tan head. Nose is peanuts, cordial cherries, ovaltine and roast. Taste jumps out like dark rum laced with cocoa and vanilla, finishing remarkably dry for as sweet as it is going in. Damn this is some fine stuff.

Amazing porter with tons of redeeming qualities. Large frothy brown head forms on top of a thick, black body which leaves plenty of hearty lacing. Abundant aroma of roasted nuts, vanilla, cherries, chocolate, and a great woody after scent. Sweet and creamy with a filling and sturdy body. Very malty flavor dominated by dark roasted goodness. Plenty of dark fruits with hints of black strap molasses, coffee and cream as well as a subtle chocolate flavor.

Sampled at GABF.  This was one of the highlights.   Black pour with creamy tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, vanilla, coffee, light roast.  Flavor is smooth: nice dark chocolate, vanilla, coffee.  Really, really tasty.  Smooth, delicious beer.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2009 Sampled at GABF several times over and also at Boonville, once out of the bottle, then again on tap at Rose & Crown in Palo Alto.  Pours black with a small creamy tan head.  Aroma is coffee, chocolate, vanilla, and roast.  Flavor is incredible with fresh, creamy, chocolatey mocha, vanilla, and some caramel and roasted malt.  Great balance.  This is pretty much to imperial porters what Sculpin is to IPAs.  Medium-full body with a smooth palate, somewhat low carbonation, and only mild coffee astringency.  Overall an amazing beer.

Bottle, thanks to alexanderj.  Black pour with very little head.  Aroma is strong coffee grounds, some bitter chocolate, and vanilla.  Flavor is pretty acidic, mostly from the coffee flavor; vanilla is noticable, and there is just a sliver of sweetness.  Bitter coffee aftertaste.  I thougth the coffee was a little too overpowering in this.

Pitcher pour at 2009 GABF. Pours a tiny mocha head, over a black/brown (SRM 38) clear body....nose of coffee, chocolate, vanilla, minimal hop tones....taste heavy coffee, chocolate, cocoa with loads of vanilla....mouth feel thick heavy, carbonation added creaminess. A big, heavy, rich, satisfying brew. Tasting 9/26/09.

Bottle. Much thanks to danielcurtis81 for sharing on his wedding week. Pours pitch black the faintest brown edge and some fading bubbly beige head. Aroma is sweet roasted malt, coffee and vanilla, very inviting. Taste is relatively smooth and sweet dark malt, with a good vanilla flavor that almost leads to some oak and bourbon notes. Coffee component is nicely placed as well. Very nice porter flavor and style.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2009 Bomber from Sparky27. Pours really dark brown with very small tan head. Aroma is loaded with coffee with some roasted malt and caramel and smidge of vanilla. Flavor is dominated by coffee with roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, and caramel. Finisher with some bitterness from coffee but there is an underlying sweetness to it. Mouthfeel is thick and syrupy and carbonation is a bit low. This is bordering on imperial stout. Really solid flavorful brew. Coffee lovers dream.

Served cold from tap at brewery. A coffee vanilla imperial porter, this beer literally tasted like cold coffee infused with alcohol. My girlfriend said it was heavenly thick, syrupy, coffee and chocolate! I thought it was the second best brew consumed at the brewery, but since Im not a huge coffee drinker, the dominant flavor would have to grow on me if I were to drink it regularly.

Pours black into a snifter. Mocha pancake head with excellent retention leaves sheets as it slowly recedes to coat surface. Espresso, cocoa and vanilla aromas. Dark roasted espresso, dark chocolate and vanilla. Less body than expected, but makes it nicely drinkable..

Bottle shared by alexsdad06.

Poured dark brown color with an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate roasted malty, vanilla and chocolate aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy dark roasted coffee sweet flavor with medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate to long duration.

Solid complex beer.

Bottle thanks to smokepot23!Dark brown body with a large coffee head, gone quickly. Nose has lots of rich, dark chocolate, also some coffee. Vanilla is a minor player. Flavor is somewhat sweet,  lots of coffee, vanilla, and some chocolate. The coffee adds a nice bitter bite to balance through the finish. Smooth body. Very nice balance here, the interplay of the rich chocolate and bitter coffee notes taking the beer further than most of these kinds go.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2009 At Toronado SD, MAN was this good! Like liquid Whoppers with a touch of vanilla & coffee. A bit of chili pepper in the nose but not in the flavor. Velvet smooth and creamy all the way around.
Bottle shared by mspindler..Pours black with a beige head.. Aroma is lots of cold coffee and vanilla.. Flavor is dark chocolate, coffee and vanilla.. Very smooth beer.. I want more!!

7/23/2009:  Ballast Point Victory at Sea Coffee Vanilla Imperial Porter has semi-sweet chocolate, hints of espresso, and plenty of vanilla in its aroma.  Its appearance is near black in tolor with a tan-colored head that deposits ring-like lacing on the glass.  The flavor consists of dark malts, hints of chocolate, strong acidic coffee, and loads of vanilla bean.  Mocha comes through in the finish.  To be honest, the vanilla is a bit overpowering as it is not balanced by any of the other flavors.  To make matters worse, this medium-bodied beer feels a bit thin.  Is this a good beer?  Yes, but I dont think its anywhere near being great for me.  I didnt like it nearly as much as the majority of the recent ratings or as much as those who sampled it with me...
22 fl. oz. bottle shared by alexsdad06.  Rating #161 for this beer.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2010 bomber from CBX. pours a gorgeous, slightly oily, jet black with a thin, mocha brown head and great lacing. aroma is outstanding with big, dark, roasted coffee, vanilla extract, sweet cream, dark chocolate and toasty malts, with  hints of tart, vinous fruit and spicy cinnamon. flavor is simply fantastic...4 months in the cellar has served this one well...huge, dark roast hazelnut coffee, sweet vanilla, toasted coconut, cinnamon, and toffee up front with a hint of dark fruit, smoke, burnt toast, and roast on the back end leading to a long, bittersweet roast coffee finish. palate is nearly full bodied and amazingly slick with an elegant touch of boozy warmth from the 10%. overall, a great imperial porter.
Draft at The Thirsty Monk.  Pours a lacing tan head with a dark brown body.  Smells of cocoa and coffee.  Flavor is cocoa and coffee.  Finish is strong vanilla, coffee, and a little dry.

Pours black with thin, dark ruby highlights and a 2 finger creamy mocha head. Aroma is huge on coffee, roast, roasted nuts, caramel, milk and dark chocolate, espresso, light toffee, dark caramel, floral and herbal notes. More caramel, vanilla and nutty notes come out as it warms, along with some toffee.
