Flavor is caramel sweetened espresso, rich caramel, super rich vanilla pudding, nice roast, some woody notes, burnt/toasted white bread, vanilla creme chocolates, a little char, nice toasted maple char and a little dark fruit. As it warms the vanilla notes become a little stronger than I would have liked, but doesnt get in the way too much. Finish is roast, vanilla, smoked/roasted nuts, some bitterness, very smooth espresso notes and a little char. Palate is medium-think with a slick entry, very dry finish and light, but appropriate carbonation. Really, really good stuff, I would love to see what the bourbon barrel version is like. I could see it smoothing out the vanilla, or making it even more sharp and over the top.

Yet another treat from "hannont". Colour... very dark brown. Nose... COFFEE with notes of vanilla and toffee. Palate... Whoa! Big coffee hit, up front! Vanilla comes in quickly then a wave of roasty malt, caramel, and toffee, and finally a looooong, smackingly dry finish, reminiscent of what port [wine] shippers call, "grip". Nice!

Appearance: Pours a dark brown, near black body with a wispy, fairly small-sized, beige head.

Smell: Deeply roasty nose with some possible perceived hints of added black patent malt as well as eager, oh-so inviting notes of everyones favorite: coffee, vanilla, and chocolate.

Taste: Dark, roasted malt flavor with a double shot of espresso, chocolate, and reasonably strong, smooth accents of vanilla beans. Subtly sweet. Earthy, predominately roasty bitterness present, particularly as it begins to grow in charred malt qualities upon slight warming. Drying, roasty finish with one last, final departing touch of vanilla.

Mouthfeel: Medium-full body. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: I enjoyed this one. Its about as smooth as a man with a pencil-thin mustache. The listed ABV% was never an issue at all.

22 oz bottle acquired via trade. Pours out like black coffee with a one inch, quickly fading tan head and pretty nice, thick lacing. Aroma is entirely vanilla and coffee in equal measure, no room for anything else. Flavor lets some chocolate in to play with the vanilla and coffee, but not much else. This sucker is thick and delicious, I wish Id traded for more!

Thanks to goldtwins for sharing - vanilla, toffee and cocoa in the nose  - leafy bitterness - creamy mouthfeel, medium body, well-masked alcohol - quite a bitter coffee flavor, but not astringent - vanilla bean sweetness rides in under this - slight alcohol warmth in the finish - some cocoa and roasted nuts - not too bad.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2010 bomber shared by psprings too far in!

pours a nearly black shade of dark reddish brown with a tan head a nd a bunch of spotty lacing. 

pretty simple aroma of coffee, vanilla, chocolate and roasty grain... simple yet delicious!8/4/6/4/1/3.6
finally! on tap at pap 2/18/10.
big time coffee in the nose along with buttery vanilla, roast, spicy graham crackers and some dusty oats.

the flavor is nice and rich from the vanilla but balanced nicely from the roast and hoppy dryness. grassy, spicier and fresher than the bottled version.

the medium body is a bit oily yet roast cuts it and hops dry it out. 8/4/8/4/16/4.0

unfortunately, the palate is too far on the sweet side... and a bit artificial. or, at least too much oily vanilla flavor mixed with dark chocolate, toasted coconut, roasted grain, licorice, coffee and some similar nuttiness with an almost bitter/acrid finish. 

the body definitely has some substance to it... medium-full with nice carbonation to make it rich yet easy to put away. 8/4/6/4/14/3.6

This one poured a dark dark brown color with a smaller tan head. Aroma was coffee chocolate and lots of vanilla. Flavor was a strong burst of vanilla, then some sweet chocolate notes, followed by a nice coffee bitter finish. This is some pretty damn good stuff.

Draft at the brewery. A pitch black beer with a thin tan head. The aroma has notes of sweet malt, roasted malt, and lots of chocolate. The flavor has strong notes of coffee and chocolate as well as medium notes of roasted malt.

I started my morning out with this brew. Poured into a pint glass it produced a good two fingers worth of coco colored head that went to a sparse lace. The body of the brew was its obligatory black with no light coming threw at all.

The aroma of espresso and sweet chocolate were really pronounced in this brew. There was a slight bourbon vanilla smell in there as well. The flavors were interesting as well the vanilla helped cut the bitterness from the coffee and roasted malts. The feel in my mouth was medium to full with good carbonation.
This is a good brew not to spectacular I had better in this hybrid style. It is worth the try and I would not turn it down that is for sure. I killed the bomber with no problem with brunch myself so drinkability is fine

Bottle at Thrashzone. 
Black with a nice frothy lacing. Coffee-smoke-caramel nose with a bit of vanilla, though that smells like cheap extract. Flavor of cheapish vaniulla extract and coffee. Decent orasted malt but the vanilla is a no-go.

Bomber, shared with Bram.  I had been waiting awhile to finally try this beer, and I dont think it disappointed.  Pours viscous dark brown with a small but resilient brown head.  Aroma is of very sweet dark chocolate, cocoa powder, and coffee.  Similar, but less sweet to Southern Tiers Mokah.  Upon sipping, one is greeted with a chewy, full-bodied mouthfeel, prickled slightly by carbonation.  This beer also leans primarily chocolate-sweet, especially inially.  The mid-palate brings in toasted coffee to the mix.  The finish is full, yet with an interesting dryness.  Some mildly coffee-bitter notes emerge as well, but not enough to override the sweetness of this brew.  Interesting, very flavorful, and ultimately successful.

Robust Series...yeah! Pours out blacker than black with a dark brown head. Strong smell of coffee and rum and vanilla. Was expecting more of a sweet taste but this floored me with its bitterness. So bitter that it bites. Double bitter dose from the hops and those coffee beans. Cacao, dried fig, tobacco and lots of smoke...taste reminded me a little bit of Back Flag (another pirate/ship oriented moniker). The taste was very stout-like and the presence was hardcore on the tongue; but the body remained true to its Porter style and was quite smooth and sort of light in its own hairy way. I liked this stuff but not sure I could recommend it to all of my other beer loving sailors. Aaargh matey, more for me then...

Bottle shared by psprings at hellbillys holiday tasting.  Nice deep brown pour with a creamy small head.  Nice aroma of coffee, coconut, chocolate and vanilla.  Slightly sweet flavor with all of the above and a bit of nuttiness and alcohol.  Very good stuff!  Thanks Paul.

Tried this beer twice and really tried to like it, probably cause of the high score. Couldnt do it. Big coffee, vanilla, roasted malts and chocolate from the nose. The mouth is big vanilla and big chocolate notes and just a touch cloying and fairly sweet. Its just so over the top, it like made for hopheads that have ruined their palates on hoppy beers.  Love big beers, but this is just too much of everything. Apparently I am not getting that it is supposed to be a dessert beer, so I tried it with dessert the second time I had it and that didnt improve anything. Way over hyped.

Deep brown beer with a thick sticky tan head.  Aroma is great.  Lightly tart on the nose with a bit of vanilla and soft cocoa.  I dont get a whole lot of coffee although it is still quite sweet smelling.  A bit of light vanilla and a soft cherry fruitiness on the finish.  Its a decent beer, but of dont really get the hype.

Bomber shared by psprings at hellbillys holiday tasting.  Pours a deep reddish brown with a thin tan head.  The nose is vanilla, coconut and coffee.  The taste is chocolate, coffee and vanilla.  Medium bodied.  Good stuff  reminds me of Maui Coconut Porter.  Thanks Paul!

2009 Bottle - Thanks Snojerk321! - Pours out thick and deep brown with a lt tan head...aroma is dark roast, dark fruity malt, burnt cocoa and cream...flavour is similar, with vanilla and coffe nuanced but nowhere close to overwhelming, charred bitterness on the back end helps distract a bit from the alcohol bite...this was just about everything I love in an Imp Porter!

Poured an opaque black color with small, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, vanilla beans, smoke, chocolate, burnt wood, and nuts.  Taste of roasted malts, bitter dark chocolate, vanilla bean, smoked wood, and a fair amount of alcohol.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a clear dark brown body with a small creamy light brown head that faded to a wispy film.  The nose is a great mix of dark-roast coffee, roast, chocolate malt, a little alcohol, and just a little vanilla.  The flavor is much heavier on the vanilla than the aroma would suggest.  A little too heavy even, it makes me think Im taking a shot of vanilla extract.  The coffee and roast are still there in force, but the vanilla is just really overbearing.  Finishes with a bit of astringency and a shot of alcohol warmth.  Medium to full bodied with a nice creamy texture and soft gentle carbonation.  Overall, this just missed the mark for my tastes.  Way too much emphasis on the vanilla.  This would be awesome if they tuned down the vanilla a few notches.

Bottle, courtesy kiefdog. Dark reddish pour, thin white head, thick braids of lacing. Vanilla nose, caramel, some chocolate, and very hot. Chocolate flavors, bourbon, vanilla, some distant coffee, slight hoppy bitterness. Full-bodied, balanced and pretty interesting.

Great ring lace on the glass from the substantive tan head.  Dark, dark brown color where no lace passes.

Lots of coffee and a little bit of cream.  Basically, mocha in aroma.  Low level of sweetness...reminiscent of good cocoa.

Lots of powdered chocolate in the flavor.  Sweet and bitter from the malt.  Rich body with a relatively low level of carbonation.  Almost chewy.  The aftertaste is complicated: Notable hop bitterness with some dark chocolate malt and sweet milky flavor.  Deceptively high in alcohol.

Bottled at Thrash Zone, Yokohama, Japan.  Opaque black, beige fairly coarse head. Milky chocolate strikes first. Near full bodied. Vanilla and chocolate dominates tar, coffee steps in to accompany the vanilla. Mid sweet with long salty finish.

22 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with Smokepot23.  Pours a very dark brown, not quite black, with a moderate light brown head that lasted through the first third of the glass and left a few spots of lace. Very pleasant aroma of coffee and vanilla. The flavor is again coffee along with some vanilla.  Roasted malt is also present in the flavor.  Some coffee bitterness at the finish.  Mild warmth from the alcohol at the finish as well, especially as the beer warms a bit.  Enjoyable.

On tap @ OBriens Pub: Black color with a firm layer of head which left behind in its trail a very sticking lacing along the glass. The aroma was a delicious olfaction of vanilla and cocoa which put my taste buds into alert mode. However, the flavor was to strong and rich with chocolate chip sweetness and over bearing cough syrup flavors that made me regret I ordered such a large serving of this beer.Earlier Rating: 5/16/2009 Total Score: 4.3Bottle from South Bay Drugs: Poured a pitch black liquid with a creamy layer of tanned colored head. Aromas are all right and score a perfect score to my nose for the delighting and strong pleasant scent of espresso and memory of a coffee ice cream. The flavors are sweet and decked with a rich roasted malt and coffee profile. There are also is a notice of vanilla lurking in the background of all the richness of the malts as well as hint of chocolate syrup. Alcohol presence is less damaging on the palate which makes me choose the bottle version of this over the tap.

Sampled April 2009
A vigorous pour into my 25cl tulip glass produces a dense, creamy, darkly browned crown of froth that rises three fingers in height.  The head leaves copious amounts of dense lace on the sides of my glass as it slowly subsides.  The beer is almost pure black in color, but does have a touch of brown to it.  When held up to the light the beer shows just a touch of an amber hue to it around the edges, but I wouldnt really say that it is passing any light through.  The aroma has the coffee leading off along with roasted malt notes, but it has a soft backdrop of vanilla that becomes more noticeable the longer I spend smelling the aroma (though it never goes beyond subtle).  The vanilla accentuates a solid dark chocolate aromatic note here and it also helps to soften the sharp, roasted grain and coffee notes.  The nose  has quite a rich, satisfying, even satiating quality to it.

As the beer hits my tongue I notice that it has a rich, satisfying heft to it, though it is not quite as heavy as the nose might have suggested; it is still a sipping beer though.  Vanilla flavors accentuate a malt sweetness as well as a dark chocolate flavor.  Bitter, roasted coffee flavors are found in the finish and can get a touch acrid at times.  The bitterness from the dark malt and coffee flavors really lingers on in the finish.

This beer has a nice balance to it, between the vanilla notes and sweetness up front and the roasted, biting notes towards the finish, but it can seem a little simplistic at times.  The vanilla really helps this beer shine; the roast malt and coffee notes would be too aggressive, too acrid and too bitter without the vanilla.  This is definitely a nice after dinner sipping brew and I find that I am quite enjoying it.

22 oz bottle big thanks to Smokepot23. Pours a dark brown color with a medium brown head. The aroma is great; initially heavy coffee notes, later more vanilla and fruits come in. The flavor is also initially lots of rich milky coffee, vanilla, and lots of rich fruitiness come through as it warms and your palate get used to the coffee. Light sour, roasted malts and bitter chocolates in the finish. Very nice at about 50 degrees Fahrenheit. Light alcohol warmth and a nice medium mouthfeel.

Sampled via 22-oz Bomber at Dark Lord Day 09 and available at table 4. Pours a dark cola brown brew with an average beige head that has excellent retention with some spotty lacing. Aroma of roasted dark malt, flowery hops, with a decent cold coffee in the background. Taste is medium body, flavors of toasted dark malt, some chocolate, toffee, a hint of vanilla and coffee. Finish has a nice balance of coffee, chocolate malt and toasted dark malt aftertaste, plus a little alcohol warmth.

From  Lagunitasfan thanks homie.  Pours dark with a frothy tan head.  Taste is mainly coffee and a touch of vanilla notes on the aftertaste.  Great fuckin beer overall, probably the best Ive had from this brewery so far.  I really enjoyed it.

22 oz split on brothers bday. Wow this is probably one of my favorite beers. Smells like coffee and vanilla with a lil bit of dark fruit. The taste has a ton of coffee followed by some vanilla. Has a great alcohol feel to it but a little thin. Still one of my favorite beers ever would drink this badboy everyday if i could.

Black witha  beige head.  Coffee, vanilla, roasted malts, light cocoa aroma.  Bittersweet chocolate, vanilla, roasted malts, dark fruits, and coffee.  Pretty hot on the alcohol.  Good though, would have it again.
Bottle.  Pours a dark brune body with a tan head.  Vanilla coffee rinds, hints of dark chewy fruit.  Licorice, Charleston chew, tawny wood vanilla and coco.  What a delicious brew!

On tap at Ballast Point a while ago.  Didnt realize it was a different beer than the bottled version.  Color was black with a brownish head.  ARoma of vanilla, coffee, roasted malt, alcohol and chocolate.  Flavor was the same with a good dose of coffee and vanilla.  Not sure which one I like more; probably about equal in my mind.Earlier Rating: 3/15/2009 Total Score: 3.9Bottle.  Poured a dark dark brown color with a smallish light brown head.  Aroma of roasted oats, cocoa, wood, vanilla, chalk, with a good amount of coffee (especially in the finish).  Some really nice, and a bit unusual , aspects to this beer.  The two most pronounced elements for me was a coffee middle that gave way to a lingering vanilla presence in the finish.  Flavor was very robust.  Alcohol was well hidden, for twelve percent, but you could definitely tell it was there.  I am not sure I am love with this beer however.  I just think there is a bit too much vanilla in the finish.  Still very nice though.

Liked this one a bit less than the bottled version.  Deep black with tan head.  Nose was very heavy espresso, dark malt, licorice, hops.  Tasted of coffee, bitter hops, dark malt, mild oaky and vanilla hints.  Got a tad hot late.  Solid.Earlier Rating: 5/6/2009 Total Score: 4.2Bottle from Craft.  Deep black pour with tan head.  Nose is dark malt, choc/coffee, vanilla, licorice.  Tastes dark malty, with a heavy coffee, backup vanilla, and backup hops.  Stays pretty bitter, with the coffee dominating.

From stefanje via trade.  Poured ultra dark brown with a dark tan, almost brown head that had nice persistence and average to above average lacing.  The aroma was a whiff of vanilla and chocolate with lots of coffee.  The flavor was dominated by the coffee but balanced fairly well by the swirling flavors of chocolate, vanilla and smoke.  Medium bodied mouthfeel.  Sweet but never offensive.  Didnt notice the 10% ABV.  Good stuff.

22 oz bomber. Pours black with a huge light brown head that dissipates quickly. nice lacing. aroma is coffee, dark roast. Taste is very strong coffee with hints of vannilla. Dark chocolate. Very thick mouthful  with a nice burn Thanks to the 12% abv.

Source:  On tap at Kellehers Irish Pub in Peoria. Glass: Poured into a snifter. Appearance: Poured jet black with a one finger brown head that quickly dissipated.  Aroma:  Huge notes of cocoa, vanilla and a hint of coffee. Flavor: Strong coffee, cocoa and a strong vanilla finish. Palate:  Medium/full body with a bit too much carbonation, but a silky smooth mouthfeel.Overall:  This defines dessert beer.  Vanilla is prominent in both the nose and mouth.  Excellent beer.

22oz bottle poured into tulip
Beer pours black as an earth wind & fire concert. Head is thin and fizzy and falls fast. Smooth lacing and a small halo is left behind.

Smells of cocoa and faintly of coffee.

Taste is very strong on coffee, not so much on vanilla, but you can really taste the roast. The coffee is strong, but smooth.

Hands down my favorite Ballast Point beer to date.

A little too thin on mouthfeel. I wanted this one to be a little creamier.

The alcohol warmth is perfect. You really dont get too much alcohol on your pallet, but it hits the back of your throat and chest and is pleasantly warming.

I will probably pick up a case of these in hopes to drink it next winter when it gets cold enough to really appreciate this style again.

Bomber.  Pours a dark black with a thin head- lasts most of the time.  Aroma is potent with dark roasty nutty chocolate and tons of sweet vanilla, with a good amount of coffee and slightly herbal as it warms- almost gets a bit annoying from the big vanilla though as you drink more.  Flavor is dark chocolate - vanilla with marshmallow, toffee and molasses big sweetness, dark chocolate, some roast and coffee hints,- vanilla is still big with a bit of green throughout- toasty and a big non- drying chocolate finish.

22oz bottle thanks to drewbeerme.  Pours black in color with a tan head.  Coffee, roasted malts, sweet chocolate, rich espresso, and grassy pine aromas.  Coffee, sweet vanillas malt, roasty and lightly bitter with a touch of hops.  The vanilla didnt seem overbearing and all around a good beer.

Thank for sharing K-man. Pours a deep black with a small light brown head. The head dissapates quickly but leaves moderate lacing in my snifter. Wonderful aroma of vanilla,coffee,chocolate and hints of wood. Velvety mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Sweet and bitter.  Awesome beer.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Dark brown with ruby edges, off white head dissipates quickly. Nose is big coffee malts, roast, vanilla, touch of cherry. Flavor is bigger coffee than expected from the aroma, chocolate, vanilla, dark fruits, finishes sweet.  Full-bodied, thick texture, low carbonation. Complex and flavorful coffee porter that is east drinking despite the abv.

Thanks kiefdog for the share.  Pours cola brown with an off-white head.  Nose is malt, vanilla, booze, and chocolate with noticeable coffee and whiskey.  Flavor is whiskey, vanilla, booze, chocolate, roasted malt with some vanilla in the finish.  Medium-bodied and enjoyable.

Bomber back from bruisin ales. Head is a quickly dissipating tan one that leaves a decent lacing. Dark chocolate and wood aroma. Man is that chocolate aroma spot on. It takes me to a special place. Vanilla comes through in the flavor with a bit of roastiness as well. Body is surprisingly light but the roasted coffee bitterness sticks with you for a while. Pretty tasty desert beer and a typically crappy offering from a San Diego brewery.

Bottle shared with JoeTheYounger.  Pours a jet black with a creamy short tan head.  Aroma is hot chocolate mix, vanilla and a good bit of coffee.  Flavor is strong with alot of coffee and roast, vanilla is powerful but not overbearing, and a nice sweet background supports all of the above.  Palate is velvety smooth but not too thick and the smooth carbonation provides a nice creaminess.
Pours out black with lots of foam. Great roasty smell. Taste is mostly coffee and vanilla. Nice balance. Great beer.

Bottle: Very deep brown with a deep khaki film of head. Big aroma, but balanced. Charred espresso roast meshes with the vanilla and a dark malt chocolaty note. Slick body, big but not cloying. Charred coffee upfront blends well with the smooth vanilla bean character. Both the coffee and vanilla presence are smooth and very natural. Theres plenty of heavy dark malt to back both as well. Pretty tasty and cohesive blend of bitter espresso and sweet vanilla- works well together, but use this one  in moderation.

Bomber. Pours fairly black with spotty lacing and a small head. Smells like some good stuff: lots of sharp, roasty coffee with cacao and distinct vanilla. The palate is just medium heavy. The ashy, burned coffee flavor is great, but why is there so much vanilla? Its a very sweet, vanilla/sugar powder note and it is so sticky it subtracts from the beer. It gets pretty overwhelming after a bomber for sure. The drier coffee and cacao notes keep me in for a few snifters, but man. Too much vanilla.

Bottle, courtesy juiceisloose. Pours a deep murky brown/black, leaves a little lacing with a small off-white head. Vanilla, coffee, smooth roast and chocolate nose. In the flavor this is a vanilla bomb, too sweet for my taste. Vanilla could have been more bearable if this wasnt so sweet. Medium body, a little heavy on the carbonation.
Pours a dark brown close to black, thin head. Heavy vanilla nose. Too heavy. Sweet malt flavor with a lot of vanilla notes. Not bad.

Bottle courtesy of gibby. Pours a dark murky brown to black with thin tan head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, ripe dark fruit, toffee, light notes of honey and vanilla. Flavor is sweet and roasted with notes of chocolate, vanilla, coffee, ripe dark fruit, faint caramel and toffee. Generally medium body with a pleasing malty and sweet finish.

Poured from a bottle and gave a deep brown black color with a miniscule tan head. Aromas of chocolate and sweet malt. Super smooth in your mouth. Thick and full bodied. Rich dessert like flavors of vanilla, cocoa, coffee, almond, caramel. Kind of ice cream flavored like. Very good long finish. Great beer to end an evening and sip!!

mmmm...this didn’t quite sit with right with me. Probably a beer to sip at home, rather than drink at a beer party. Big vanilla nose and very smooth. This one rushs straight to your head. Interesting in its own way. A dessert beer

Courtesy of kiefdog. Pours deep darkness with thin tan head. The aroma is charred malts and coffee to go along with highly roasted malts (somewhat short of charred) and a hint of molasses. The taste begins as a sweet malty caramel pulse and quickly moving into charred malts and coffee. Toward midway a tasty note of vanilla surfaces to join the roasted to burnt notes. Yummy brew, I didnt notice the ABV at all.

Bottle shared with mspindler. Hot chocolate smell with notes of vanilla extract. Very great balance of chocolaty goodness with vanilla and caramel. Dark color with nice brown creamy head. Very great porter, very smooth.

Courtesy WeeHeavySD. Pours a very dark brown color almost black with a small, foamy tan colored head that spots of lacing behind. The nose shows lots of dark chocolate, fresh roasted coffee, and hints of vanilla. The flavor follows with the dark chocolate and roasted coffee up front with the creamy vanilla coming through to balance things out. The moluthfeel is full bodied and almost creamy with good carbonation with a lengthy roasted chocolate finish. The alcohol is well hidden in this as well. A really tasty brew that I hope to try again sometime.

Bomber, courtesy juiceisloose.  Pours a dark, lightly translucent, chocolate mahogany color.  A small, foamy, khaki colored head leaves wet lacing spots behind. The nose shows big, dark cacao malts infused with roasty espresso, heaps of vanilla, and creamy oats.  Flavors show the same elements, but the vanilla really pushes through and takes over as the dominant component.  Dark chocolate and deeply roasted caramel are quite sweet, with the roasty coffee struggling to keep up. The body is more than substantial, but syrupy and somewhat cloying at the same time.  Tasty stuff, in small doses or as a dessert, but I dont know how much of this sweet brew I could finish.

courtesy of kiefdog
Pours dark brown
Aroma plenty of coffee, roasted malts.
Taste, vanilla is present but doesnt overwhelm the taste, some roasted malts, coffee, light touch of chocolate.
This is some fine tasty beer.
Highly drinkable at 10 abv.

Bottle shared by Paul. Dryish pomello aroma with a ton of vanilla that almost completely dominates the aroma. Flavor is once again completely dominated by vanilla, I like it but this is completely one-dimensional. I can drink it, for sure, I mean I like it, but there is nothing here but vanilla.

This is some good stuff.  Pours very dark, nice head retention.  Plenty of coffee in the aroma, vanilla isnt as noticeable as the coffee.  A very roasted, complex flavor, with coffee dominating.  Definitely worth seeking out.

bomber thanks to weeHeavySD.  Pours black with a light-brown head.  Nose is potent coffee and some cocoa.  wow!  taste is coffee, coffee, coffee.  Fantastic tasting coffee.  Thank God I like coffee.  Mouthfeel was thick and creamy, more so than most porters.  Liked this a lot.

Pours a black espresso with chestnut tinges around the edges.  Light tan head is a little on the short side with large, loose bubbles.  Coffee nose is ultra-prevalent on this one.  Its almost a one-sided affair until your nose down in it.  Fresh ground espresso, bitter sweet chocolate, a nice clean roastiness, smoke and a hint of sweetness.  Enticing.  I dont detect much in the way of obvious vanilla, but the  overall aroma is explosive.  Flavor is not complex but is very bold.   The dark roasty coffee notes are hot on this one and again take the forefront.  Semi-sweet chocolate, scorched caramel, toasted walnuts, and smoke all jump out in the middle of the palate.  The finish is bitter initially but quickly checked by a backlash of sugars.  Vanilla is definitely subtle but leaves its presence on the finish.  I feel its not so much of a flavor component as it is used to  amplify  the sweetness of the residual sugars and balance out the bitterness.  Wonderful medium-densie body.  Great big and bold!

Bottle.  Damn fine beer.  Damn fine.  Almost a black pour with a small light beige head.  The coffee is the first thing that hits your nose, then the wonderfully roasted malt, vanilla, and some chocolate tones set the table for what is going to be a very nice drinking experience.  The mouthfeel on this beer is very nice.  The coffee and vanilla work in harmony and the chocolate and roast give this beer wonderful complexity...this is a super beer.

(22oz bottle, courtesy of blutt59)  Pours a dark brown (near black) body with a small tan head.  Aroma of coffee, vanilla, nuts, and roasted malt.  Flavor of coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, and vanilla.

Thanks to JuiceIsLoose for the taste.  Good stuff.  Aroma, of course, is coffee and vanilla.  The flavor has a bitter kick of strong coffee, with just enough vanilla sweetness to balance things out.  Very good.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2009 Bottle.  More like "a humilating defeat at the hands of a short ship."   Smells like copper, tastes like copper.  Bad bottle?  Ill have to have another someday to see if this was just a freak thing.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Bottle thanks to Hophead22. Poured black in color with lots of coffee chocolate and malt in the aroma. Taste is lots of coffee, vanilla, roasted malts, and very smooth going down. Way to easy to drink at 10%!! Great beer.

Bomber poured into a tulip.

Pours dark, dark brown out of the bottle and settles in black in the glass underneath a big tan head that leaves good lacing and hangs on as a cap for a while.

The aroma is really nice and big on this one with the subtle sweetness of the vanilla balancing perfectly with the massive roasted coffee smell.  Lots of dark malts underlying the other aromas.

The taste is a bit sweeter than the aroma.  The initial tastes are of big roasted coffee and dark malts.  The vanilla is subtle to start but really comes on strong in the finish and leaves a very sweet finish.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied and very smooth with good carbonation.  The finish is sweet but slightly dry with the roasted coffee character.

This is a very good porter with some very bold flavors and aromas, dominated by the coffee but with the vanilla reallyl coming through in the taste.  Great beer.

Bottle shared by wolf at SL. Black in color, nice lilttle head. Nice aroma of roasted malts and chocolate. Taste is coffee, vanilla, chocolate, and roasted malts. Way to easy to drink. Light/medium texture. Creamy smooth. Ballast Point makes some really good beers and this was one of them. Thanks to wolf and hophead22...

Another huge thanks to Smokepot23.  Crushed with Jakebra.  One delicious beer.  Nose of coffee, vanilla, chocolate.  Flavor has the same but chocolate is more extreme.  Thick, roasty, complex, and awesome.

Bottle from the Scripps Ranch location.  Nose is more subdued than the tap version, but still smacks of coffee and the addition of light vanilla is nice.  Flavor is much the same, but the coffee shows through even more - kept light on the palate by the vanilla.  Make no mistake, this doesnt have the distinct vanilla flavor one might expect: instead, the coffee and vanilla are unified exquisitely, eliminating the bitter, semi-sour sensations often imparted by the bean.  This is very drinkable.Earlier Rating: 1/23/2008 Total Score: 4.7Absolutely!  Ab-So-Lutely!  I looked for a bottle of this everywhere I went for months, but finally found it on tap at the Stone World Bistro.  Dear Lord, yes!  Its like coffee that can get you hammered!  This loses minor points on Palette/Flavor because its not at all complicated: its coffee; and one more overall because its brilliantly tasty, but I dont know if I could drink it every day.  An absolute masterwork.

22oz from Carrboro Beverage Company. Having wanted to try this for quite a while, I was expecting to be underwhelmed after the recent arrival of KBS. But I have to say that this brew is nearly on a par. Thick creamy pour, motor oil and coffee head. Sweet vanilla notes are very subtle in the nose, a nice surrogate for the barrel usually favored in this style. Creamy body, almost oatmeal stout-like. Coffee is delicious, seems like its cold-filtered. Rich and complex base porter is satisfying in its own right, but the interplay of dessert beer flavors is really scrumptious.

Bottle: pours dark black with a frothy tan head, aroma of coffee, chocolate, vanilla and malt, taste is chocolate, coffee, vanilla, very smooth and rich, a bit of a bite from some hops in the finish.  Seems very much like a stout to me but whatever...good stuff.

Bottles in trade from ROBORB and  TURDFERGUSON.  Thanks!!  Pours black with light tan head.  Smell is strong coffee, chocolate and a lot of slightly artificial vanilla, but not too overwhelming.  Taste is the same but with a hoppy, dry finish.  Lots of coffee, chocolate and vanilla, as expected.  A touch too much vanilla, but still pretty tasty stuff!

22 oz bomber.  Pours a dark cola black with a medium tan head.  Aroma of baking chocolate, vanilla, malt and warm alcohol.  Taste of baking chocolate, fudge, malt and a distinct vanilla flavor.  Nice warming alcohol finish.
22 oz bottle. Strong coffee, chocolate and vanilla flavors. A very thick meaty porter. This has a very good sweet/dry balance going on. Slightly has the flavor of vanilla flavored coffee.

22oz bottle. pours black with tan head. nose of vanilla, lots of vanilla, caramel, bakers chocolate. flavor of lots of vanilla, roast, chocolate, caramel, a touch sourish. med body. just too much going on and a lot of vanilla, which vanilla notes that arent subtle isnt my thing.

The aroma is lacking, with just a bit of vanilla coming through.  Luckily that is there in the taste.  A nice dark pour with a creamy tan head that sticks around throughout.

Fairly delicious and exceedingly drinkable, except for the fact the sweetness get to you a bit after awhile.

A fantastic, if a bit thin, mouthfeel.  I suppose this is why its a porter and not a stout.

Bottle from kylefleeger.  Ive been waiting to try this for quite awhile, and was not dissapointed.  Pours oily black with a brown head.  Smells amazing. Brimming with coffee, cocoa, vanilla, and roasted malts - all of which carry into the flavor.  Very sweet, but balanced by a note of dryness on the finish.  The best Ive had from Ballast Point.  Truly great stuff.

22oz. Bottle:  Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, chocolate, light vanilla, hops, oats, and slight caramel.  Poured black in color with a small brown head that lasted around the edges.  Opaque.  Flavor is lightly sweet and medium bitter.  Tastes of roasted malts, coffee, vanilla, chocolate, light piney hops, caramel, slight resin, slight tar, slight vanilla, and a hint of alcohol.  Medium body.  Chalky, slightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Lightly sweet, moderately bitter, roasted, caramel, coffee, and slight vanilla finish is slightly dry.  10%ABV is totally hidden.

Bottle thanks to blutt59.  The look is brown to black in color with a good beiged colored head. The smell is malts, coffee, chocolate, chocolate covered coffee beans, and very roasty.  The taste is super roasty, malts, coffee, and chocolate.

Bottle... This beer rocks!... Pours midnight black with a small, creamy, beige head. Good retention. The aroma is a luxurious swirl of chocolate, espresso and vanilla. Full-bodied with a velvety mouthfeel and gentle carbonation. Flavorwise, dark chocolate, espresso and charcoal stand out. Lots of residual sugar, but plenty of hop and black malt bitterness to balance things out. Lengthy, moderately charred, acrid and bitter finish. Thanks to darkguardian for sharing the bottle of this world class beer!

22oz bottle. Huge Coffee nose wafts out of this bottle before it even hits the glass. Pours almost totally black with a small tan head. Huge coffee, with some definite hints of vanilla bean, chocolate and  caramel. I sipped this right after the pour but then left it to warm to near room temperature and I highly recommend people do this, this beer opens up immensely at near room temp. Huge chocolate up front with a delicate roast in the middle. Big malty vanilla notes at the backend and a lingering moderate bitterness. So balanced, so tasty. So damn good. One of the very best imperial porters Ive ever had. Not to mention I think this should age quite well. Very highly recommended

Pours a dark black, with tan head.  Very sweet malt, caramel, toffee, milk chocolate, lots of vanilla flavor, coffee, and some roastiness.  Vanilla is dominate in the brew.Earlier Rating: 3/5/2009 Total Score: 3.9On tap at Stone Bistro.  Really sweet and chocolaty.  Very tasty and strong, with roasted coffee beans, milk chocolate, peety malt, vanilla, oak, and hints of bourbon.  Really nice desert beer.

Bottled shared by tjthresh, thanks man! Been wanting to try this for awhile now. Pours a vicious looking deep brown with a tan head. Aroma is full of coffee and vanilla. Almost like a fountain style vanilla Coke. Flavor is much the same, with vanilla being the dominate flavor, but the coffe providing a big backbone. A nice burnt grain on the back end. I would be very interested in trying the other versions of this.

22oz bottle.  thanks to andrew for this one....pours close to black with a thin light tan head....aroma of heavy roasted coffee and sweet vanilla vapors ....flavors of coffee infused goodness with a nice lingering vanilla essence.  creamy mouthfeel with light to medium carbonation. Earlier Rating: 3/7/2008 Total Score: 3.8growler from the man working at the PP Bottle Shop which i believe i recall him saying that it was the last of the keg....i really liked the nose in this one. fresh coffee grounds, extremely roasty and just a great coffee essence to it....poured a dark brown, almost black, and softer around the edges.  head was minimal....outside of the strong coffee and chocolate flavors, i found it somewhat thin overall and this sample had little to no carbonation....decent and im sure it would have been better if taken from a fresh keg.

22 oz. Nearly black pour, cream colored head with a small amount of bubbly lacing. Aromas roast malt, hints of woody vanilla. Tastes similarly with much more assertive vanilla, coffee and some caramel. A little bourbon like booziness, but not bad at all. Definetely a sipper right now. Close to creamy mouthfeel. I bet this will age very nicely. Been very impressed with Ballast Point, this one did not disappoint.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: 22oz bottle. Pours dark brown/black with a moderate sized, creamy, light brown head, some lace. Smells of sweet malts and vanilla, roasty malts with just a hint of coffee. Theres more coffee in the taste. Flavor is of sweet roasty malts with a pretty big coffee flavor, slight coffee grounds with a hint of vanilla. Full body, pretty smooth, good carbonation.Earlier Rating: 2/23/2008 Total Score: 4.1On-tap @ Churchills 2/22/08. This beer is pretty damn tasty. Pours a thin looking, dark brown/black color. Creamy brown head that leaves good lace. Smells of roasty coffee and malt. Tastes of creamy, sweet coffee and roasted malts. There is a little alcohol burn on the finish. Mouthfeel is somewhat thin, carbonation is vibrant.
Bottle from beverages 4 less.  Overpowering coffee flavor distracts from subtle oak, vanilla, and milk chocolate flavors.  Tone down the coffee and this is one great brew.

bottle thanks to blutt59.  poured black with a tan head that laces the glass.  aroma of dark roasts, vanilla, coffee, and toffee.  flavor of vanilla, dark roast, coffee, and alcohol.  nice slick body with low carbonation.  good stuff, want more please.

22oz bottle (thanks Josh for sharing). Poured a dark black color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of coffee, vanilla, chocolate, and some nuttiness. Tastes of vanilla/vanill beans, chocolate, coffee, and some roastiness. Alcohol content overall well hidden. Body was thick and oily.Earlier Rating: 12/6/2008 Total Score: 4.2On tap at the 2008 Strong Ale Festival. Poured a dark brown colo rwith a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of coffee, vanilla -vanilla creme-, lightly earthy, coffee, and chocolate. Tastes of coffee -coffee grinds-, chocolate, and roast. I like coffee in my coffee beers, and there was definitely coffee in this one.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2012 Rerate:  22 oz. bomber.  Pours a deep black with a foamy tan head.  Aroma of dark coffee, chocolate, and vanilla, wood, roasted malts, and some booze.  Taste is loaded with coffee, vanilla, chocolate, wood, dark fruits, and a little alcohol.   Has a full body, with a creamy mouthfeel and a warming, bitter finish.  overall, a fantastic imperial porter that is even better then I remember from the first time I tasted it.

Pours a deep black with amber notes and a medium bubbly tan head.  Aroma of vanilla bean, coffee beans, light alcohol, chocolate and nuts.  Flavor of loads of vanilla, almost vanilla cream soda, coffee is there, but vanilla is up front.  Getting some chocolate and nuts as well.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2009 22 oz bomber from Capones. Pours a deep dark brown with a smaller beige head with some nice lacing. Aroma is rather sweet with lots of vanilla, chocolate syrup, nuttiness, coffee grinds, artificial sugars. Flavor is roasty and artifical sweet vanilla that grows on you along with some coffee and chocolate. Full bodied with strong carbonation and average alcohol warming for a beer that is only 10%. I love roasty and sweet but somehow this beer seems to clash and not mesh the way I was hoping.

22 from Tylers Bottle Shop. Pours a nice dark black, allows some light on the pour. Head is a finger thick, creamy, chestnut brown. The nose is very nice, rich, very chocolaty, coffee, roasty, mild alcohol, molasses, notes of vanilla. The flavor is very nice, more of a grain/coffee/hop bitterness comes through but is balanced well by the body and other flavors. Rich and chocolaty, coffee, vanilla shows more with warmth and adds a very very nice character. Alcohol starts to come through and shows with a warming finish. Very full and creamy mouthfeel. Very tasty.

Pours a great, thick black with a creamy tan head that lasts for quite a while.

Huge vanilla on the nose with notes of chocolate syrup and childhood sweets.

Very smooth chocolate, espresso and vanilla in the taste. The coffee has minimal astringency (huge pet peeve for me) and the taste is nicely backed up by a tootsie roll chocolate sweetness. The coffee/espresso notes nicely balance the sweetness. This beer is over the top in many ways, but so very well put together.

Mouthfeel is smooth, creamy and appropriately carbonated. 

Drinkability is very good. 

Highly recommended. Great on its own, great barrel aged, etc.

22 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a crema head.  Nose is molasses, vanilla bean and coffee.  Silky medium body with light buzzy carb.  Taste is vanilla, coconut, chocolate and plum with distinct chewed coffee bean.  Big, bold flavors that balance nicely.  Perfect for dessert.
Bottle thanks to blutt59. Black in color with a decent sized beige head. Aroma is of coffee, roasted malts, vanilla, and dark chocolate. Taste is of coffee, roasted malts, vanilla, and dark fruits.

Bottle thanks to blutt59. Pours a deep, dark brown with tan head. Aroma of dark roast, some vanilla, and some wood. Flavor is sweet, dark roast, some wood and dark roast bitterness, as well as coffee. Mouth feel is full body with low-medium carbonation. Overall, very interesting, very tasty.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2009 Bomber from JohnnyJ.  Pours opaque dark brown with a light brown head.  The nose is huge with coffee.  Huge.  Really huge.  Hell, theres even some vanilla.  Really, its the same with the flavor.  Coffee and vanilla.  I could really do without the vanilla.  Theres a roasted bitter finish.  Full and fluffy body.
22 oz. bottle, thatnks Alex. Pours Dark brown, with a a light brown head.  Aroma is coffee, roasted malt, and vanilla. Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, vanilla, and chocolate. Nice creamy medium body.

Wow!  22 oz bottle from Bevmo Mission Valley.  Dark like a mofo.  No light penetration in front of a backyard spotlight.  Barely discernable red-brown highlights arond the lip of the class.  Nose is malt sweetness and dark chocolate.  Taste is dry cocoa, malt, and coffee.  Theres a bit of sweetness that is immediately drowned out by the bitter sweet cocoa flavor.  Great malty finish.  The smallest hint of hops.  Great beer.

bottle, pours dark brown almost black with a nice brown swirled head, aroma has coffee, roasted nuts, flavors of roast coffee, darker fruits, nutty, vanilla oaky smooth finisher, I did prefer the original howeverEarlier Rating: 3/21/2009 Total Score: 4.3draft at Sea Rocket, black walnut colored with perfect tan head, aroma of coffee and cocoa, flavor of roast coffee, rich dark chocolates, cashew butter, very good finish

Bottle from Carrboro Beverage Company.   Nice to have this as a "local" beer. Pours dark brown with a small tan head and adequate lacing throughout. Nose and flavor come through with a nice blend of vanilla, coffee, roasted malts and hops.  Everything is relatively well with the vanilla characteristics perhaps showing the most, but not to the point that they are unpleasant or cloying. .  The palate is amazingly creamy and silky smooth. Not overly bitter or overly sweet like some imperial porters.  Well balanced and pretty tasty for some a high gravity brew.  Would like to try the "original" someday to taste the difference.

Pours thick and black.  Tastes of highly roasted malts, espresso, slight vanilla in the background.  Light head with little retention or lacing.  Overall, a great beer.  If you like strong porters, youll love this one.

22oz bottle from BevMo! Mission Valley.  Pours a very dark brown, almost black with a good sized chocolate head.  Big coffee nose with hints of vanilla, chocolate, and coffee.  Flavor was a little boozy with a big coffee influence.  Im not sure why they didnt bottle the original recipe?  This one is not quite as good. Earlier Rating: 1/30/2008 Total Score: 4.2On tap @ San Diego Brew Co.  Very deep brown almost black in color, head was beige and about 2 fingers.  Coffee, coffee and more coffee on the nose.  Some smoke, vanilla and wood chips present as well.  Hefty mouth feel and more chocolate was present on the finish than initially.  One of My favorite Imperial porters!

Bomber shared at the decadence release

Huge nose of vanilla and coffee followed up by a smooth & creamy flavor of vanilla, chocolate & coffee. Earlier Rating: 8/1/2008 Total Score: 4.2On tap at Ballast Point for the RBSG 2008.

Great coffee flavor, tasty tasty brew. Easy drinking.

Bomber from La Mesa Market. Pitch black in color. Strong roasted coffee aroma. Not a whole lot of vanilla in the nose. Very smooth and thick. Lots of burnt/roasty maltiness and tons of bitter coffee. Quite tasty. For some reason I cant really taste any vanilla. Good stuff.Earlier Rating: 3/21/2008 Total Score: 4Tap @ Hamiltons. Poured black in color. Smooth body. Huge coffee aroma. Tastes like a somewhat sweet iced coffee. Quite tasty. Alcohol is very well hidden.

22oz. bottle, with thanks to stefanje for the unexpected box!  Pours a dark brown with a moderate tan head.  Aroma is cold pressed coffee, espresso, chocolate and light vanilla.  On the flavor the vanilla comes more front and center, with more chocolate, espresso and some caramel.  Overall I agree with others that the vanilla is a bit too amped up on this, but still a nice beer.  Thanks again Stefan!

Tap at the Old Grove location 10%. Dark pour with a very creamy tan head. Lots of coffee in the aroma, dark roasted malts as well. Flavor was alot of coffee as well, slightly sweet some caramel and a little vanilla, very smooth and very tasty
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: 5th official rating of this version, Bottle I got today at the Homebrew mart location.  Im looking forward to seeing the differences between this and the original and how much the Pours a rich black with a nice light brown head that fades into a nice island.  Nose is sweet with a lot of vanilla and coffee, and a nice malty kick.  Taste is rich and very sweet with kicking coffee and a lot of vanilla.  For me, this is clearly different than the original version, the vanilla comes out in a big way.  Its not a terrible thing by any means but the vanilla is almost omnipresent.  This is tasty but Id take the original any day.  Earlier Rating: 12/2/2007 Total Score: 4.5PP Strong Ale Fest 07, Beer 1 day 2, quite a way to start a day.  Ive been wanting to try this after Bartzilla told me his Girlfriend roated the coffee for it.  Pours black with a thin tan head.  Nose is huge, full of mocha and coffee and chocolate.  Taste is strong, mocha, chocolate, coffee, and a hopped edge.  this is killer.

Bottle thanks to multiple people in the BA Decadence release tasting line. Pours with a small light brown head and a very dark brown body. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, vanilla and cocoa. Taste is vanilla extract, smoke, chocolate and a few dark fruits. Lots of vanilla. Smooth mouthfeel, light carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2010 650 ml bottle from Freddy. Pours an opaque black color with a small tan head that recedes to a fine film. The aroma is big and bold with coffee, mocha, dark chocolate and ash. The flavor is much like the aroma, but with vanilla rolled in. This very much reminds me of the old Olfabrikken porter with extra coffee and vanilla added. The mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. The finish is long and cloying with lingering vanilla. Overall: Call it local bias, but I am blown away by this brew. Thank you Ballast Point. Highly recommended. RErate 12-24-10 -- recent release still holds up to previous high standards.

Growler. Thanks, SuzyGreenberg!~ Wow, awesome beer. Jet black. Dense creamy tan head. Huge coffee nose--not all dark roast, but some real bean fragrance. Chocolate there as well. Creamy medium body. Silky oatmeal quality to it. Tons of coffee and chocolate. Little bits of dark pitted tree fruit here and there. Some campfire and ash, but very faint. Amazingly smooth for the abv.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2009 Tap at Toronado, San Diego.  After I started drinking the beer, I talked with the guy next to me at the bar.  Turns out Jesse is the roaster at Caffe Calabria (only a half block from Toronado - gotta love North Park) which provided the coffee for this beer.  He explained the details of how Ballast brewed with the coffee he provided.  Anyway, I liked the beer so much that I had to get a growler fill at the Scripps Ranch location.  

Pours an almost pitch black with 3/4 inch of tan-colored head.  Nose is more cocoa powder than coffee.  The taste starts with chocolate then moves into the coffee -- a nice roasted coffee flavor that is balanced well, not too strong.  Slightly bitter in the finish.  This is a very big beer at 12% but the alcohol is hidden well.  

Caffe Calabria also provides the coffee for the Offshore Porter from Pizza Port (Solana Beach).  But this is much better.  Altogether a great beer.

Pours black with brown edges, and a short, bubbly tan head. Spotty lacing. Fresh-brewed strong coffee aroma with roasted (and slightly burnt) chocolate malt. Some vanilla and cream as well. Big coffee taste. Strong and black, wtih the malt taking just a little off the edge. Creamy middle, with the vanilla and some caramel poking through, giving it a melted milkshake taste. Reverts to a bitter coffee finish. The mouthfeel is deceiving. Its appropriate for the style, but the taste makes you want something a little thicker.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2009 Sampled 3/14/09. 22 oz bottle. Pours a deep dark chocolate with a deep tan head. Very aromatic with vanilla and coffee. Great coffee flavored porter that taste like is has a big ol scope of vanilla bean ice cream in it. Mouth is smooth and creamy. A little hot but a pleasant hot. Excellent beer!

Draft at the brewey.  Pours black with a medium light tan head.  Smells pretty roasty, big on the coffee and chocolate malts.  Really dug the nose on this brew.  A little roasty with the big coffee.  The flavor was very chocolatey with that big coffee notes coming through as well.  Pretty full bodied.  Just a touch of some tartness in the finish which was unusual, but didnt take away from it at all.  I dug this one.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2010 Bottle at the 10th Richmond RateBeer Gathering courtesy of decaturstevo on 01/16/2010. Dark brown body with a small off-white head. Huge vanilla aroma with roast, and chocolate. Sweet vanilla and caramel flavor with some roast and chocolate. Medium full body with moderate carbonation. 8/5/8/4/16 - 4.1

On tap at Ballast Point during the RBSG Pub Crawl Tour on 08/01/2008.  Dark black body with a small tan head. Big coffee and cream aroma. Huge coffee flavor with some light caramel. Medium full body with moderately low carbonation. 7/5/8/4/15 - 3.9

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2017 Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, brown, mostly lasting.
Body is black (non-opaque, flashlight tested).

Aroma is moderately to heavily malty (coffee and used coffee grounds, Oreo cookie, roasted grain), lightly hoppy (grapefruit, resin), with notes of vanilla and alcohol.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, syrupy/creamy texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

Pretty good stuff still, thankfully. The coffee odor seems just a tad stale this time, and its less complex than I remember 2-3 years ago, but the alcohol is hidden pretty well for 10%, and its balanced and drinkable too. Not quite 4+, but certainly enjoyable for this sort of thing.

On tap @ brewery, RBSG.  Black pour, nice dark tan head.  Bitter roast and brewed coffee aroma.  Heavy bitter roast taste that is rich and stays short of astringent.  Nice dry finish with a lot of coffee flavor.  I didn’t realize it was 12% until just now.  Wow.

RBSG 2008, on tap at the brewery. Pours black with a tan head and red hues at the edges. Very roasty aroma, fresh espresso and coffee flavors. Flavor like a nice coffee ice cream, smooth and delicious. I had no idea this was 12%, you can’t taste it.

Sampled on tap at the brewery for RBSG 08. Pours a deep black, with a small tan head. Huge coffee aroma, with malt and chocolate. Taste has a lot of coffee, with toasted malt and chocolate - both sweet and toasty. Lingering toasty coffee flavors. Really delicious.

On tap at the brewery during RBSG 08.  Darkest brown with a creamy cocoa head that leaves a bunch of lacing.  Nice roasty nose with milk chocolate and vanilla.  Intense iced coffee with a roasty bitterness, some earthy herbal hops, chocolate sweetness.  Excellent beer.

On tap at Ballast Point, RBSG 2008. Dark, opaque muddy brown, almost black with a thick beige head. Intense rich, roasted coffee with vanilla in the nose. Pleasantly strong notes of roasted coffee, mocha, Kahlua, chocolate, vanilla, earthy hop character, soil/earth. Nice sweetness level - balanced bitterness from the hop roastiness combo. Satisfyingly medium to full-bodied with somewhat of an airy, medium carbonation level. ABV very well-hidden. Very good stuff overall, try this if you can.

On tap at Ballast Point.  Poured deep brown with a creamy cap of beige head.  The aroma picked up very rich coffee sweetened up a bit by vanilla bean.. dark molasses and a touch of smoke followed.. inviting.  More and more coffee in the flavor department in the form of both maltage and pervasive bitterness.. some dark chocolate and molasses down there too.. spicy at the edges with some alcohol amplification.  Heavier-bodied and warm on the palate with spicy accents and lots of coffee.  Just what I needed!

From tap at the brewery. Pours dark brown to black with a lacing tan head. Dense coffeeish aroma. Chocolate too. Herbal and solid coffeeish flavour. Dry and slight spiced. Smooth yet and mild acidic roasted malt. Lingering roasted malty finish with a nice coffee base flavour.

Draft at brewpub for RBSG. Pours deep brown/black with a beige head. Wonderful aroma of coffee grounds and chocolate. Medium to full bodies, with a nice silky texture. Flavor is roasty, full coffee and dark chocolate. Semi-dry and slight astringent finish. Alcohol well hidden. Great stuff.

nice roasty coffee nose, black color with tan head.  very big in-your-face flavors of coffee and chocolate..in fact, vivid flavors like eating a freshly baked brownie..alcohol completely hidden to me...some strong roasty flavors may deter others but i think it belongs here.  tasty brew.

Sampled at 08 BSAF. Beer is very dark brown, clear. Head is small, frothy, light brown, mostly and quickly diminishing.

The aroma is malty with light notes of roasted grain, caramel, toasted nut, toffee, cookie, moderate notes of coffee, chocolate; Hoppy with light herbal note; Trace note of yeasty basement; Miscellaneous notes of light vanilla and a trace of cinnamon.

The flavor is lightly sweet, trace acidic, lightly bitter with a long, lightly bitter, trace sweet finish.

The body is light, the texture is watery and the carbonation is soft.

Nice, big and thick.

Draught  Near no head; black beer. Pure freshly roasted coffee with a bit of sugar; moccha cookies (Café Crème) aroma. Sweet coffee & moccha, and only the sweetness and the warming betraying the alcoholload. Very slick, viscuous, and alcoholwarming. Good, impressive Imperial porter, with a respectable alcoholdash that doesnt get too spiritlike.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2009 On tap.  Poured a deep brown/black color with a thin beige head that diminished to a thin layer.  Aroma of coffee, milk chocolate, and vanilla.  Flavorconsisted of smooth coffee, roasted malts, chocolate, and light vanilla to complement even more coffee on the finish.  Full and smooth on the palate, light alcohol peaking through.  Very well done coffee porter, perhaps my favorite yet.

straight out the keg @ the ba alesmith release.thanks cquiroga!

WOW....damn good coffee flavor...and damn smooth wow...this just kills my last favorite imperial porter.....gonzo....sooo much better!

(straight out the keg @ the ba alesmith release.thanks cquiroga!)dark brown with a nice dark brown head.awesome aroma and flavor of coffee,and roasted malts.smooth and full of that coffee flavor.just like i like it.
Very good brew, very dark, roasted flavor and aroma, smooth dry finish, taste like bitter smoked coffee

On tap @ Liars Club.  I was excited to try this one as I have been hearing about it for months.  Pours a nice brown color, smell is pure espresso.   Flavor is coffee coffee and more coffee.  The beer menu at Liars Club said this was 10%, although is seemed super hot.  This was ok, but didnt really wow me too much.  Tasted like Vietnamese Iced Coffee.

On draught at the PB Taproom $3 per pint!.  Arrived an opaque darkest brown with a moderate beigey head.  Aroma is rife with coffee and bitter chocolate, along with herbs and alcohol.  Flavor is roasty bitter, hugely featuring coffee and dark chocolate, with the alcohol noticible but well hidden for 12%.  Full body and gentle carbonation.

first sampled at the San Diego Strong Ale Festival Nov 2008, an event shared with what seemed liked hundreds of ratebeerians and enjoyed mostly through a straw, since my face was a bloody mess of scabs and stitches.  I have since had this beer at a couple of places around town, and damn is it good. It has a roasty choclate aroma with cofee.  the flavor is best described as chocolate covered cofee beens, roasty and bitter with some nice vanilla notes. Ballast Point is close to my house, Can i get a keg of this?
Deep dark brown in color with a nice off white head. Sweet vanilla aroma. Sweet malty flavor. Chocolatety roasty vanilla notes. Very nice. Medium bodied. Finish is chocolatety. Very drinkable.

tap at the brewery - Pours black with a thin, long lasting tan head.  It has a huge coffee aroma and flavor which blend wonderfully with the dark roast malt base.  Its balanced, very tasty, and wow, I never would have guessed the 12% abv.  The brewer confirmed the presence of lots of coffee in this beer (obviously) and said some vanilla was used as well.  Great beer!

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2008 On [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ World Bistro: Dark brown with a small light tan head. Aroma is strong Starback coffee and dark chocolate. Flavor follows aroma with espresso and dark chocolate cocoa with a hint of vanilla and licorice and a sharp chicory like dry bitter finish. Full body is creamy with moderate carbonation.

2007 PP Strong Ale Fest:  Poured black with a tan head.  The aroma started with pure diacetyl and tart coffee.  After a few minutes it was big milk chocolate and a hint of licorice.  the other aromas are gone.  The flavor was of some tart coffee and dark chocolate.  The aroma score is for after the crud went away.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2009 
Name: Victory At Sea Coffee Imperial Porter
Date: December 01, 2007
Mode: Draft
Source: Tasting, Strong Ale Fest
Appearance: black, fine tan head, drippy lace
Aroma: dark chocolate and coffee aroma with a caramel sweetness that gives the chocolate a milky quality
Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, lots of sweetness bring out more chocolate, touch of roasted for balance, hint of sour mash tartness

Name: Victory At Sea Coffee Imperial Porter
Date: June 27, 2009
Mode: draft
Source: brick store
Score: 3.2 to 3.6
Aroma: big chocolate aroma, dark chocolate, sweet vanilla
Flavor: rich chocolate and coffee flavor, vanilla sweetness comes in to bring out the chocolate, plenty of roasted coffee bitterness

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.6/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: **4

Tasted on tap at the 2007 Pizza Port Strong Ale Festival. This Imperial Porter pours a medium black color. Medium to small sized tan head. Aroma is chocolate and coffee with a touch of vanilla. A medium bodied Imperial porter. The malts are chocolate and coffee. The hops are earthy. Nice balance. There is a touch of wood and wine as well as vanilla flavors in this beer, but the chocolate and coffee flavors dominate. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2009 Pizza Port Strong Ale Festival 07. Damn, this might be one of the most intense aromas Ive ever whiffed off a beer! Insane roasted coffee notes and sweet dark chocolate. Silky black appearance with a small beige head. Coffee and more coffee comprises most of the flavor, with noticeable subtleties of sweet milk chocolate, butterscotch, toffee and a decent hops bite at the end of each sip. I almost had a better time sniffing this stuff than drinking it. Overall, one of my favorite porters to date, and a privilege to try at the festival. Awesome, chewy, full-bodied palate that sustains the flavor. Wow, I love this. Also tried the cask version, brewed with whiskey-soaked cinnamon at OBriens in February 09.. Absolutely incredible!

Tap at the 11th anniversary.  Syrah barrel aged.  Opaque black, with a thin film of dark brown head.  Buttery coffee and cream aromatics.  Heavy coffee flavor, some residual sweetness.  Dark alefruit and an earthy roastiness.  Ruddy, earthy fruit twang manifests in the finish, peers through fading sweet coffee.  Mouthfeel is fairly heavy, rather smooth.

Draft. Blackish beer with a nice tan head. Huge chocolate roast aroma. Chocolatey, roasty, coffee flavor with slight berry fruitiness. Hides alchol well. Body feels like too much oatmeal, but was also really foamy out of the tap, Medium body. Way too drinkable. Lingering chocolate. Let me say again: way to drinkable for 12%.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2008 8/8/07: On tap at Obriens.  Waited 4hrs for this baby.  10oz taster/$3.  Strong chocolate aroma.  Tight creamy 1 finger tan head that dies slowly.  Pitches of pitch black liquid. Thick body, kind of oily mouthfeel.  Very malty aroma and taste, possibly a bit of caramelized malt.  A bit of sourness.  This was the first or second pour from the tap, so I wonder if the lines were clean, (possibly residual Nickel Stout?) (Definitely need to rerate).  A tiny bit of buttery slickness, but I wouldnt say diacetyl.  Alchohol is reasonable well hidden, but not very drinkable. 8/4/5/3/13:3.3
10/22/07:  Tried again at Ballast Points 11th anniversary celebration.  I think it was the same beer as before:  Syrah barrel aged.  Dark.  Oily texture.  Nicer, now that I know its a red wine barrel. 8/4/7/3/15:3.7
Tried again from a growler that Sean at PP bottle shop got:  8,3,7,3,14:3.5

I saw this on the make or break, and remembered I had this one and didnt rate it. I remember the dark pour and the intense flavors of coffee, chocolate, vanilla, and bourbon. Pretty intense beer. Definetly worth a try when you see it.

On tap at Ballast / Home Brew Mart.  Muy Grande!  Black as a beer can get. No light through this one. Aroma of roasty sweet coffee. Vanilla has backed off over time.  Tan head for how black the beer is.  Coffee is evident but no astringency associated. Even with the high alcohol the finish is rather dry. Mouthfeel tastes like it should leave more of a cloying effect. Dangerously drinkable. After dinner, next to a fire, with a bowl of Vanilla Bean Ice Cream.

Draught. Deep black body with a medium-sized creamy tanned brown head. Superb aroma consisting of maple, bourbon, vanilla, touches of smokey ham, and tonnes of chocolate roast.
Smooth and creamy palate. Chewy flavours including chocolate, espresso beans, vanilla sugars. Unlike the aroma there wasnt really any smokiness in the flavour. Finishes roasty and sticky with an alcohol bite. 

Enjoyed a pint at The Liars’ Club on March 23, 2007.

Brewery sample and a glass at Liars...Damn, this beer is hugggge.  A coffee brew on steroids - similar to a Speedway in terms of appearance and mouthfeel.  Really good and definately worth a try, as I think it only comes around a few times, if not only once a year.

Tap at the Liars Club: Nearly opaque with a small tan head and minimal lacing. The aroma profile displays bourbon, vanilla bean, hint of oak, milky chocolate, quick dash of smoke, some herbal and grassy hop vapours as well. Boy was I disappointed with the flavour combinations in this brew. There were the expected heavy malt and fruity notes at the beginning before a crashing volley of vanilla and oak ruined it for me. Really just too sweet and flat for what was found on the nose. A dash of espresso bitterness on the finish did little to improve my experience. The mouth feel is oily and sticky with a heavy alcohol burn. I am way against the grain here but I found this beer leaning too far towards the malt and not enough hop and coffee bitterness.

Draught chalice at the Liars Club on 3/23/07Very dark, black coffee-like appearance, with violet and crimson edges and a thin sheaf of tan head that manages to stick around for a while.  Little/no lacing.  Clarity is low.Soft, yet sweet vanilla cream-like maltiness has pieces of bitter and milk chocolate folded in to it with coffee sweeping in quickly to add dryness to the nose and a bit more hardness than is first perceived.  Light vinousness and oak notes emerge on the end, adding complexity but not any harshness, thankfully.  Sweet malts make a reprise, rich and full of milk chocolate (light lactic notes as well), with some salty roast and even a touch of delicate prunes.  Though the oak/bourbon nuances add more power to the aroma, it still comes off as smooth and rather soothing for its strength.  Maybe a touch too much on the coffee, but it is a coffee imperial porter, afterall.  Alcohol is only glimpsed briefly, after warming.Buttertoffee and strong vanilla immediately give way to a cocoa dryness, ripe with bitter coffee notes, and chocolate covered prunes/raisins.  Some said smoke was apparent, but I seemed to get more of a salty roast-like quality, with black malt bitterness and moderate oakiness.  Very soft texture, overall, however, with low carbonation.  Big pale malt backbone goes the distance and makes for a supple palate without becoming cloying.  Coffee seems, again, a bit too strong and dry, but not glaringly so, I guess.  Alcohol well-concealed with no flaws.  A nutty character either coming from the yeast or neutral tannins, adds a bit of chewiness to the texture.  Glad to have one of their beers on draught, as I was less than impressed with their bottles.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2008 Pours a dark black, no light will penatrate this porter, with a thick, creamy tan head.  Aroma of coffee.  Taste of coffee and chocolate.  This would stand up nicely to Speedway, Id love to get some to do a side by side.

Wow...this is one big, wild, quite sweet, espresso coffee Imperial Porter.  Yabba dabba doo!!  Drinking it fresh on tap now at OBriens in San Diego.  Im not a huge chocolate fan, but Im wanting a chocolate or vanilla dessert with this...anything chocolate...ice cream, cake, mousse, maybe something coconut or mango...maybe some water!!  Wow...this is a big and distinct monster of an Imperial Porter.  Would be fascinating to try it aged 6 or 18 months.  Black color, small head, aroma of a sweet espresso.  Im gonna be flying soon...gotta go!!

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2007 Holy Java!  I can taste the coffee in my colon!  Its like a coffee enema.  Its like Starbucks and Anna Nicole Smith rolled into one.  Coffee aroma and flavor was off the hook.  When it came to the flavor it was chocolate too.  This Black beer didnt have much head after being drawn from OBriens but I didnt hold that against it.    What a great beer.  Wonderful.  Is this considered Baltic Porter or does Porter cover it....
Anyway, what a great beer!  Did I already say that?  Huh must be the 12%... I asked the server for cream and sugar and a cardboard sleeve.  I guess I will be here instead of Starbucks tomorrow morning.  What a great   Beer.

On tap and growler from the brewery.  Totally HUGE porter with volumes of Caffe Calabria coffee to eloquently mask the 12% alcohol offering.  Drinks almost like an iced coffee but with the exact opposite effect, if taken in large doses, as I tend to.  The perfect marriage of coffee and ale.  Dark, inviting, delicious. This ale should, obviously, go into steady rotation. Limited supply, so hurry up!
